translated: It is said: and the teaching of the thing whose nature is not understood should be just like that.

original: tadavagatyā mithyājñānasya saṃsārahetornivṛttiḥ prayojanaṃ kriyata ityavāśiṣṭamarthavattvaṃ kriyāsādhanavastūpadeśena /
analyzed: tad avagatyā mithyājñānasya saṃsāra hetoḥ nivṛttiḥ prayojanam kriyate iti ava śiṣṭam arthavattvam kriyā sādhana vastu upadeśena
translated: By understanding that, the purpose is accomplished, which is the cessation of the false knowledge that is the cause of transmigration. Thus the usefulness that remains is [the same] as the teaching of the thing that is the means of accomplishing action.

original: apica 'brāhmaṇo na hantavyaḥ' iti caivamādyā nivṛttirupadiśyate /
analyzed: apica brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ iti ca evamādyā nivṛttiḥ upadiśyate
translated: Moreover, cessation is taught in such statements as A Brahmin should not be killed.

analyzed: na ca sā kriyā
translated: And that is not an action.

analyzed: na api kriyā sādhanam
translated: Nor is it a means of action.

analyzed: akriyā arthānām upadeśaḥ narthakaḥ ced brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ ityādi nivṛtti upadeśānām ānarthakyam prāptam
translated: If the teaching of things that are not actions is useless, then the teaching of cessation such as A Brahmin should not be killed would become useless.

analyzed: tat ca aniṣṭam
translated: And that is undesirable.

analyzed: na ca sva abhāva prāpta hanti artha anurāgeṇa nañaḥ śakyam aprāpta kriyā artha tvam kalpayitum
translated: And it is not possible to assume that the negative has a meaning which is not the negation of an action already enjoined by the nature of things, on the ground that the meaning of the negative is the negation of killing.

analyzed: hanana kriyā nivṛtti audāsīnya vyatirekeṇa
translated: For, apart from the state of indifference which consists in the cessation of the action of killing,

analyzed: nañaḥ ca eṣa svabhāvaḥ yat sva saṃbandhinaḥ bhāvam bodhayati iti
translated: it is the nature of the negative that it conveys the idea of the non-existence of what is connected with itself.

analyzed: abhāva buddhiḥ ca audāsīnya kāraṇam
translated: And the cognition of non-existence is the cause of indifference.

analyzed: sā ca dagdha indhana agni vat svayam eva upāśāmyati
translated: And that (cognition of non-existence) ceases of itself, like a fire whose fuel is consumed.

original: tasmātprasaktakriyānivṛttyaudāsīnyameva 'brāhmaṇo na hantavyaḥ' ityādiṣu pratiṣedhārthaṃ manyāmahe /
analyzed: tasmāt prasakta kriyā nivṛtti audāsīnyam eva brāhmaṇaḥ na hantavyaḥ ityādiṣu pratiṣedha artham manyāmahe
translated: Therefore, in such passages as 'A Brahmana is not to be killed,' we consider that the meaning of the prohibition is simply the state of indifference which consists in the cessation of the action that is begun.

analyzed: anyatra prajāpati trāta ādibhyaḥ
translated: Except in the case of Prajapati, Traita, and others.

analyzed: tasmāt puruṣa artha anupayogi upākhyāna ādi bhūta arthavāda viṣayam ānarthakya abhidhānam draṣṭavyam
translated: Therefore, the statement of meaninglessness should be regarded as referring to the subject-matter of Arthavada passages which are mere stories, etc., and are not useful for human ends.

original: yadapyuktaṃ kartavyavidhyanupraveśamantareṇa vastumātramucyamānamānarthakaṃ syāt 'saptadvīpā vasumatī' tyādivaditi /
analyzed: yat api uktam kartavya vidhi anupraveśam antareṇa vastu mātram ucyamānam ānarthakam syāt saptadvīpā vasumatī tyādi vat iti
translated: As for what was said, that if a mere thing is stated without being connected with an injunction of what is to be done, it would be meaningless, like the statement 'The earth has seven islands,' etc.,

analyzed: tat parihṛtam
translated: that has been answered.

original: rajuriyaṃ nāyaṃ sarpa iti vastumātrakathane 'pi prayojanasya dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: rajuḥ iyam na ayam sarpaḥ iti vastu mātra kathane pi prayojanasya dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: Because a purpose is seen even in the mere statement of a thing, as in 'This is a rope, not a snake.'

analyzed: nanu yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvar dānāt na raju sva rūpa kathana vat arthavat tvam iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that, even for one who has heard about Brahman, since he continues to transmigrate as before, the teaching is not meaningful, like the teaching of the nature of a rope.

original: atrocyate nāvagatabrahmātmabhāvasya yathāpūrvaṃ saṃsāritvaṃ śakyaṃ darśayituṃ va vedapramāṇajanitabrahmātmabhāvavirodhāt /
analyzed: atrā ucyate na avagata brahma ātma bhāvasya yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvam śakyam darśayitum veda pramāṇa janita brahma ātma bhāva virodhāt
translated: To this it is said: The continuation of transmigration as before for one who has not realized Brahman as the Self cannot be shown, because it is contradicted by the realization of Brahman as the Self produced by the valid means of knowledge of the Vedas.

original: nahi śarīrādyātmābhimānino duḥkhabhayādimattvaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tasyaiva vedapramāṇajanitabrahmātmāvagame
analyzed: nahi śarīra ādi ātma abhimāninaḥ duḥkha bhaya ādimat tvam dṛṣṭam iti tasya eva veda pramāṇa janita brahma ātma avagame
translated: For it is not seen that one who believes the body etc. to be the Self has suffering, fear etc., so it cannot be imagined that for him alone, when the realization of Brahman as the Self produced by the valid means of knowledge of the Vedas

original: tadabhimānanivṛttau tadeva mithyājñānanimittaṃ duḥkhabhayādimattvaṃ bhavatīti śakyaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: tad abhimāna nivṛttau tat eva mithyājñāna nimittam duḥkha bhaya ādimattvam bhavati iti śakyam kalpayitum
translated: overturns that belief, that same possession of suffering, fear etc. caused by false knowledge continues.

original: nahi dhanino gṛhasthasya dhanābhimānino dhanāpahāranimittaṃ duḥkhaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tasyaiva pravrajitasya dhanābhimānarahitasya tadeva dhanāpahranimittaṃ
analyzed: nahi dhaninaḥ gṛhasthasya dhana abhimāninaḥ dhana apahāra nimittam duḥkham dṛṣṭam iti tasya eva pravrajitasya dhana abhimāna rahitasya tat eva dhana apahra nimittam
translated: For it is not seen that a householder who is wealthy and believes himself to be so has suffering caused by the loss of wealth, so for him alone who has renounced and is free from the belief in wealth

analyzed: duḥkham bhavati
translated: that same suffering caused by the loss of wealth continues.

original: naca kuṇḍalinaḥ kuṇḍalitvābhimānanimittaṃ sukhaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tasyaiva kuṇḍalaviyuktasya kuṇḍalitvābhimānanimittaṃ sukhaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na ca kuṇḍalinaḥ kuṇḍali tva abhimāna nimittam sukham dṛṣṭam iti tasya eva kuṇḍala viyuktasya kuṇḍali tva abhimāna nimittam sukham bhavati
translated: And since the pleasure caused by the pride of being an earring is not seen in one who is not an earring, it is not possible that the pleasure caused by the pride of being an earring belongs to one who is not an earring.

original: taduktaṃ śrutyā 'ārīraṃ vāva santaṃ na priyāpriye spṛśataḥ' chāndo / / / iti /
analyzed: tat uktam śrutyā ārīram vāva santam na priya apriye spṛśataḥ chāndaḥ iti
translated: This is stated in the scripture: Verily, when he is bodiless, neither pleasure nor pain touches him. (Ch. U. 8.12.1)

analyzed: śarīre patite śarīra tvam syāt
translated: It may be argued that bodilessness would occur only after the body has fallen.

analyzed: na jīvate iti ced na
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: sa śarīra tvasya mithyā jñāna nimitta tvāt
translated: Because the state of having a body is caused by false knowledge.

original: na hyātmanaḥ śarīrātmābhimānalakṣaṇaṃ mithyājñānaṃ muktvānyataḥ saśarīratvaṃ śakyaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: na hi ātmanaḥ śarīra ātma abhimāna lakṣaṇam mithyājñānam muktvā anyatas sa śarīra tvam śakyam kalpayitum
translated: For the state of having a body cannot be imagined to arise from any other cause than the false knowledge characterized by the self's identification with the body.

analyzed: nityam aśarīra tvam akarma nimitta tvāt iti avocāma
translated: We have said that the self is eternally bodiless, because that state is not caused by action.

analyzed: tad kṛta dharma adharma nimittam sa śarīra tvam iti ced na  śarīra saṃbandhasya asiddha tvāt dharma adharmayoḥ ātma kṛta tva asiddheḥ
translated: It may be argued that the state of having a body is caused by merit and demerit produced by the self. But this is not so.🔽Because the connection with the body is not established, and the production of merit and demerit by the self is not established.

analyzed: śarīra saṃbandhasya dharma adharmayoḥ tad kṛta tvasya ca itaretara āśraya tva prasaṅgāt andha paramparā eṣā anādi tva kalpanā
translated: If the connection with the body and the production of merit and demerit by the self were to be established, there would be an infinite regress, as the connection with the body and the production of merit and demerit would be mutually dependent. This is mere blindness, imagining beginninglessness.

analyzed: kriyā samavāya abhāvāt ca āmtanaḥ kartṛ tva anupapatteḥ
translated: And because the soul is not the substratum of action, it cannot be the agent.

analyzed: saṃnidhāna mātreṇa rāja prabhṛtīnām dṛṣṭam kartavyam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the king and others are seen to be agents merely by their presence, we reply: No.

analyzed: dhana dāna ādi upārjita bhṛtya saṃbandha tvāt teṣām kartṛ tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is possible to maintain that they are agents because of their relation to servants acquired by the bestowal of wealth and so on.

original: na tvātmano dhanadānādivaccharīrādibhiḥ svasvāmisaṃbandhanimittaṃ kiñcicchakyaṃ kalpayitum /
analyzed: na tu ātmanaḥ dhana dāna ādi vat śarīra ādibhiḥ sva svāmi saṃbandha nimittam kiñcid śakyam kalpayitum
translated: But in the case of the soul, it is not possible to imagine any cause of the relation of master and servant such as the bestowal of wealth and so on by the body and so on.

analyzed: mithyā abhimānaḥ tu pratyakṣaḥ saṃbandha hetuḥ
translated: The cause of the relation is the false notion (of identity).

analyzed: etena yajamāna tvam ātmanaḥ vyākhyātam
translated: By this (argument) the fact of the soul being the sacrificer is explained.

original: atrāhuḥ dehādivyatiriktasyātmana ātmīye dehādāvabhimāno gauṇo na mithyeti cenna /
analyzed: atra āhuḥ deha ādi vyatiriktasya ātmanaḥ ātmīye deha ādau abhimānaḥ gauṇaḥ na mithyā iti ced na
translated: Here they say: If it be said that the superimposition of the soul on the body and so on, which are its, is secondary, not false, we reply: No.

analyzed: prasiddha vastu bhedasya gauṇa tva mukhya tva prasiddheḥ
translated: Because the well-known distinction of things is known to be secondary or primary.

analyzed: yasya hi prasiddhaḥ vastu bhedaḥ
translated: For one whose distinction of things is well known,

original: yathā kesarādimānākṛtiviśeṣo 'nvayavyatirekābhyāṃ siṃhaśabdapratyayabhāṅmukhyo 'nyaḥ prasiddhaḥ tataścānyaḥ puruṣaḥ prāyikaiḥ krauryaśauryādibhiḥ
analyzed: yathā kesara ādi māna ākṛti viśeṣaḥ nvaya vyatirekābhyām siṃha śabda pratyaya bhāj mukhyaḥ prasiddhaḥ tatas ca anyaḥ puruṣaḥ prāyikaiḥ kraurya śaurya ādibhiḥ
translated: just as the particular form possessing manes and so on is well known as the primary basis of the word and notion of 'lion', different from that, a man is well known to be endowed with the lion-like qualities of fierceness, courage and so on,

analyzed: siṃha guṇaiḥ saṃpannaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: being accomplished.

original: tasya puruṣe siṃhaśabdapratyayau gauṇau bhavato nāprasiddhavastubhedasya /
analyzed: tasya puruṣe siṃha śabda pratyayau gauṇau bhavataḥ na aprasiddha vastu bhedasya
translated: The terms ‘man’ and ‘lion’ are used figuratively in the case of the man who is a lion, but not in the case of a thing whose difference is not well known.

original: tasya tvanyatrānyaśabdapratyayau bhrāntinimittāveva bhavato na gauṇau /🔽yathā mandāndhakāre sthāṇurayamityagṛhyamāṇaviśeṣe puruṣaśabdapratyayau sthāṇuviṣayau /
analyzed: tasya tu anyatra anya śabda pratyayau bhrānti nimittau eva bhavataḥ na gauṇau  yathā manda andhakāre sthāṇuḥ ayam iti agṛhyamāṇa viśeṣe puruṣa śabda pratyayau sthāṇu viṣayau
translated: But in the case of the other, the terms and ideas are due to a cause of illusion, and not figurative.🔽For instance, in the dark, when a post is not clearly distinguished, the terms and ideas of ‘man’ are applied to it.

original: yathāvā śuktikāyāmakasmādrajatamiti niścitau śabdapratyayau /🔽tadvaddehādisaṃghāte 'hamiti nirupacāreṇa śabdapratyayāvātmānātmāvivekenotpadyamānau kathaṃ gauṇau śakyau vaditum /
analyzed: yathā vā śuktikāyām akasmāt rajatam iti niścitau śabda pratyayau  tadvat deha ādi saṃghāte ham iti nirupacāreṇa śabda pratyayau ātma anātma avivekena utpadyamānau katham gauṇau śakyau vaditum
translated: Or, again, when silver is mistaken for a shell, the terms and ideas of ‘silver’ are applied to it.🔽In the same way, when the aggregate of body, etc. is spoken of as ‘I’ without any distinction, the terms and ideas of ‘I’ are applied to the self and the non-self indiscriminately. How can they be said to be figurative?

original: ātmānātmavivekināmapi paṇḍitānāmajāvipālānāmivāviviktau śabdapratyayau bhavataḥ /🔽tasmāddehādivyatiriktātmāstitvavādināṃ dehādāvahaṃpratyayo mithyaiva na gauṇaḥ /
analyzed: ātma anātma vivekinām api paṇḍitānām aja avi pālānām iva a viviktau śabda pratyayau bhavataḥ  tasmāt deha ādi vyatirikta ātma astitva vādinām deha ādau ahaṃpratyayaḥ mithyā eva na gauṇaḥ
translated: Even for the wise who distinguish the self from the non-self, the terms and ideas are not distinguished, like the ignorant who do not distinguish a post from a man.🔽Therefore, for those who believe in the existence of a self separate from the body, etc., the idea of ‘I’ in the body, etc. is false, not figurative.

analyzed: tasmāt mithyā pratyaya nimitta tvāt sa śarīra tvasya
translated: Therefore, because embodiment is the cause of false ideas,

analyzed: siddham jīvataḥ pi viduṣaḥ śarīra tvam
translated: it is established that even a living person who knows Brahman is disembodied.

original: tathāca brahmavidviṣayā śrutiḥ ' tadyathāhinirlvayanī valmīke mṛtā pratyastā śayītaivamevedaṃ śarīraṃ śete /
analyzed: tathā ca brahma vid viṣayā śrutiḥ tat yathā ahi nirlvayanī valmīke mṛtā pratyastā śayīta evam eva idam śarīram śete
translated: And in the same way there is a Vedic text about the knower of Brahman: ‘As a snake-skin cast off lies useless, even so this body lies;

original: athāyamaśarīro 'mṛtaḥ prāṇo brahmaiva teja eva' bṛha / / / iti /
analyzed: atha ayam aśarīraḥ mṛtaḥ prāṇaḥ brahma eva tejaḥ eva bṛhaḥ iti
translated: but this bodiless immortal breath is Brahman itself, is light itself’ (Bṛhadā.

original: 'sacakṣuracakṣuriva sakarṇo 'karṇa iva savāgavāgiva samanā amanā iva saprāṇo 'prāṇa iva' iti ca /
analyzed: sa cakṣuḥ a cakṣuḥ iva sa karṇo karṇaḥ iva sa vāc avāc iva sa manāḥ amanāḥ iva sa prāṇo prāṇaḥ iva iti ca
translated: ‘He has eyes, yet is as if he had none; he has ears, yet is as if he had none; he has speech, yet is as if he had none; he has mind, yet is as if he had none; he has breath, yet is as if he had none’ (Bṛhadā.

analyzed: smṛtiḥ api ca sthita prajñasya akā bhāṣā bhagī
translated: And the Smṛti also, in the passage, ‘What is the speech of one whose wisdom is firm?’ (Bhagavad-gītā, ii.

analyzed: ityādyā sthitaprajña lakṣaṇāni ācakṣāṇā viduṣaḥ sarva pravṛtti asaṃbandham darśayati
translated: 54), and so on, describes the characteristics of one whose wisdom is firm, and shows that the man who knows Brahman is not connected with any activity.

analyzed: tasmāt na avagata brahma ātma bhāvasya yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvam
translated: Therefore, one who has known Brahman to be the Self does not continue to be a transmigrating being as before.

original: yasya tu yathāpūrvaṃ saṃsāritvaṃ nāsāvavagatabrahmātmabhāva ityanavadyam /
analyzed: yasya tu yathāpūrvam saṃsāri tvam na asau avagata brahma ātma bhāvaḥ iti anavadyam
translated: But he who continues to be a transmigrating being as before has not known Brahman to be the Self. This is faultless.

analyzed: yat punar uktam śravaṇāt parācīnayoḥ manana nididhyāsanayoḥ darśanāt vadhi śeṣa tvam brahmaṇaḥ na svarūpa paryavasāyi tvam iti na
translated: As for the argument that Brahman is subordinate to the injunction to know, because of the fact that the texts about Brahman are seen to be subsequent to the injunctions to hear and to reflect, and therefore Brahman is not the ultimate purport of the Upaniṣads, that is not so.

analyzed: avagati artha tvāt manana nididhyāsanayoḥ
translated: Because the purpose of reflection and contemplation is to know.

original: yadi hyavagataṃ brahmānyatra viniyujyeta bhavettadā vidhiśeṣitvam /
analyzed: yadi hi avagatam brahma anyatra viniyujyeta bhavet tadā vidhi śeṣi tvam
translated: For if what is already known were to be employed elsewhere, then it could be a remainder of an injunction.

analyzed: na tu tat asti
translated: But that is not the case.

analyzed: manana nididhyāsanayoḥ api śravaṇa vat avagati artha tvāt
translated: Because reflection and contemplation, like hearing, are for the purpose of understanding.

original: tasmānna pratapattividhiviṣayatayā śāstrapramāṇakatvaṃ brahmaṇaḥ saṃbhavatītyataḥ svatantrameva brahma śāstrapramāṇakaṃ vedāntavākyasamanvayāditi 🔽siddham /
analyzed: tasmāt na śāstra pramāṇaka tvam brahmaṇaḥ saṃbhavati iti atas svatantram eva brahma śāstra pramāṇakam vedānta vākya samanvayāt iti  siddham
translated: Therefore, since Brahman cannot be the subject of the scriptural injunctions by being enjoined, it is established that Brahman is the subject of the scriptures independently, by the harmony of the Vedanta texts.

original: evañca sati 'athāto brahmajijñāsā' iti tadviṣayaḥ pṛthakśāstramārambha upapadyate /
analyzed: evam ca sati atha atas brahma jijñāsā iti tad viṣayaḥ pṛthak śāstram ārambhaḥ upapadyate
translated: And this being so, the undertaking of a separate treatise on that subject, beginning with Now, therefore, the inquiry into Brahman, is proper.

analyzed: pratipatti vidhi para tve hi atha atas dharma jijñāsā iti eva ārabdha tvāt na pṛthak śāstram ārabhyeta
translated: For if it were concerned with injunctions of practice, since it would have already been begun with Now, therefore, the inquiry into dharma, a separate treatise would not be begun.

original: ārabhyamāṇaṃ caivamārabhyeta 'athātaḥ pariśiṣṭadharmajijñāseti' ' athātaḥ kratvarthapuruṣārthayorjijñāsā' jai / / / itivat /
analyzed: ārabhyamāṇam ca evam ārabhyeta atha atas pariśiṣṭa dharma jijñāsā iti atha atas kratu artha puruṣa arthayoḥ jijñāsā itivat
translated: And if begun, it would be begun thus: Now, therefore, the inquiry into the remaining dharma, like Now, therefore, the inquiry into the purpose of the sacrifice and the purpose of man (Jaimini Sutra 1.1.1).

original: brahmātmaikyāvagatistvapratijñāteti tadartho yuktaḥ śāstrārambhaḥ 'athāto brahmajijñāsā' iti /
analyzed: brahma ātma aikya avagatiḥ tu apratijñātā iti tad arthaḥ yuktaḥ śāstra ārambhaḥ atha atas brahma jijñāsā iti
translated: But the understanding of the non-duality of Brahman and the self is not a matter of promise, so the undertaking of the treatise for that purpose is proper, beginning with Now, therefore, the inquiry into Brahman.

original: tasmādahaṃ brahmāsmītyetadavasānā eva sarve viṣayaḥ sarvāṇi cetarāṇi pramāṇāni /
analyzed: tasmāt aham brahma asmi iti etad avasānāḥ eva sarve viṣayaḥ sarvāṇi ca itarāṇi pramāṇāni
translated: Therefore all the topics and all the other means of knowledge end with the conclusion 'I am Brahman'.

analyzed: na hi aheya anupādeya advaita ātma avagatau nirviṣayāṇi apramātṛkāṇi ca pramāṇāni bhavitum arhanti iti
translated: For means of knowledge which have no object and no knower can exist when the non-dual Self, which is not to be rejected or accepted, is known.

analyzed: api ca āhuḥ gauṇa mithyā ātmanoḥ sattve putra deha ādi bādhanāt
translated: Moreover, they say: 'If the secondary false Self does not exist, because of the contradiction of son, body, etc.,

analyzed: sat brahma ātmā aham iti evam bodhe kāryam katham bhavet
translated: how can there be an effect of the knowledge I am the real Brahman Self in this way?

analyzed: anveṣṭavya ātma vijñānāt prāk pramātṛ tvam ātmanaḥ
translated: Before the knowledge of the Self to be sought, the Self is the knower.

analyzed: anviṣṭaḥ syāt pramātā eva pāpma doṣa ādi varjitaḥ
translated: When sought, it would be the knower itself, free from sin, faults, etc.

original: dehātmapratyayo yadvatpramāṇatvena kalpitaḥ /🔽laukikaṃ tadvadevedaṃ pramāṇaṃ tvā'tmaniścayāt'
analyzed: deha ātma pratyayaḥ yadvat pramāṇa tvena kalpitaḥ  laukikam tadvat evā idam pramāṇam tu ātma niścayāt
translated: Just as the notion of the body being the Self is imagined to be a means of knowledge,

analyzed: iti
translated: in the same way this is a worldly means of knowledge, because of the ascertainment of the Self.'

analyzed: iti catur sūtrī samāptā
translated: Thus ends the four-versed [treatise].

original: FN / pūrvapakṣiṇā kriyāśeṣatayā brahma pratipādyata ityuktaṃ tadvyāvṛttyarthamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvapakṣin kriyā śeṣa tā brahman pratipādyate iti uktam tad vyāvṛtti artha iti bhāva
translated: The opponent has said that Brahman is taught as a part of an action. The meaning is that this [verse] is for the purpose of excluding that.

original: pūrṇatayā juhūdvārā kratuśeṣatāvādātmano 'pi jñānadvārā karmaśeṣatvāttadarthā vedāntāstadvidhiśeṣā bhaviṣyantītyāśaṅkyāha tatkeneti /
analyzed: pūrṇa tayā juhū dvārā kratu śeṣa tā vāda ātmanaḥ api jñāna dvārā karma śeṣa tvāt tad arthāḥ vedāntāḥ tad vidhi śeṣāḥ bhaviṣyanti iti āśaṅkya āha tat kena iti
translated: Fearing that the Vedānta texts may be subsidiary to injunctions, on the ground that the self, being a part of the sacrifice through the juhū ladle, is also a part of the action through knowledge, he says: By what is that known?

original: pratipattikarma pradhānakarmaśeṣāṅgaṃ /🔽yatha pradhānacaruhomottaraṃ tenaiva dravyeṇa sviṣṭakṛdbalidānādi /
analyzed: pratipatti karma pradhāna karma śeṣa aṅgam  pradhāna caru homa uttaram tena eva dravyeṇa sviṣṭakṛt bali dāna ādi
translated: The act of understanding is a subsidiary part of the principal act.🔽Just as after the principal act of offering oblations of cooked rice, the offering of oblations to Sviṣṭakṛt and the giving of Bali are done with the same substance.

original: yathāvā śrāddhe piṇḍapradānapūjottaraṃ piṇḍānāṃ gaṅgādipravāhe prakṣepaḥ /
analyzed: yathā vā śrāddhe piṇḍa pradāna pūjā uttaram piṇḍānām gaṅgā ādi pravāhe prakṣepaḥ
translated: Or just as after the offering of balls of rice and worship at a śrāddha, the balls of rice are thrown into the current of the Ganges etc.

analyzed: saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Non-connection is non-entry.

analyzed: pratipatteḥ vidhiḥ niyogaḥ tasya viṣaya bhūtām pratipatti pratyavacchedaka tvema viṣayatayā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the object of the injunction, which is the act of understanding, is the object of the injunction in the sense of distinguishing the act of understanding.

analyzed: agni ādi devatā uddeśena puroḍāśa ādi dravya utsargaḥ yāgaḥ
translated: Sacrifice is the offering of substances like the sacrificial cake with the deity like Agni as the object.

analyzed: aśarīram videham
translated: Without a body, bodiless.

analyzed: priya apriye sukha duḥkhe  kṛta a kṛtāt iti
translated: Pleasure and pain are happiness and sorrow.🔽From the done and the undone.

analyzed: kṛtāt kāryāt
translated: From the done, the effect.

analyzed: akṛtāt kāraṇāt
translated: From the undone, the cause.

analyzed: tat brahma avet viditavat
translated: That Brahman knew, it knew.

original: valkalādivaccittarañjako rāgādikaṣāyo mṛditaḥ kṣālitaḥ vināśito yasya jñānavairāgyābhyāsakṣārajalena tasmai /
analyzed: valkala ādi vat citta rañjakaḥ rāga ādi kaṣāyaḥ mṛditaḥ kṣālitaḥ vināśitaḥ yasya jñāna vairāgya abhyāsa kṣāra jalena tasmai
translated: To him who has crushed, washed away, and destroyed the dye of passion etc., which colors the mind like bark etc., with the alkaline water of the practice of knowledge and detachment.

analyzed: adhyāsaḥ tasmin tad dhīḥ
translated: Adhyāsa is the superimposition of that on what is not that, according to the scriptures.

analyzed: ādeśaḥ upadeśaḥ  pralaya kāle vāyuḥ agni ādīn saṃvṛṇoti saṃharati iti saṃvargaḥ
translated: Ādeśa is instruction.🔽At the time of dissolution, Vāyu (air) covers (i.e., destroys) Agni (fire) and other elements, hence it is called Saṃvarga.

analyzed: svāpa kāle prāṇaḥ vāc ādīn saṃharati iti saṃhāra kriyā yogāt saṃvargaḥ
translated: At the time of sleep, Prāṇa (vital air) withdraws Vāg (speech) and other senses, hence it is called Saṃvarga due to the association with the act of withdrawal.

analyzed: tat viditāt jñāna viṣayāt anyat bhinnam
translated: That is different from the known, which is the object of knowledge.

analyzed: atha u api aviditāt ajñāna viṣayāt api adhi anyat
translated: Moreover, it is different from the unknown, which is the object of ignorance.

analyzed: yat vācā śabdena an abhyuditam a prakāśitam
translated: What is not manifested by speech, by sound.

analyzed: yena bhmaṇā sā vāc abhyadyate prakāśyate
translated: By which Brahman, that speech is manifested, is illuminated.

analyzed: nivṛtti viṣaya tvāt bhāpā
translated: Because it is the object of non-cessation.

original: svātmano dharmānāśrayatve 'pi nityo dharmo mokṣākhyo bhaviṣyatītyabhiprāyeṇa dharmaśabdaḥ /
analyzed: svātmanaḥ dharma anāśraya tve pi nityaḥ dharmaḥ mokṣa ākhyaḥ bhaviṣyati iti abhiprāyeṇa dharma śabdaḥ
translated: Even though the Self is not the substratum of attributes, the attribute called liberation will be eternal. With this intention, the word dharma is used.

analyzed: sva rūpa paraḥ vā
translated: Or it may refer to the nature of the Self.

analyzed: anyaḥ jīva ātmā
translated: The other is the individual soul.

analyzed: pippalam karma phalam
translated: The fruit of action is the pippala.

analyzed: abhicākaśīti prakāśate
translated: It shines, it is illuminated.
The controller of action is the giver of the fruits of action.

analyzed: śukram iti bāhya aśuddhi virahaḥ uktaḥ
translated: 'Pure' means free from external impurity.

analyzed: avraṇam asnāviram iti eva kāya niṣedhe siddhe punar tad niṣedhaḥ līlā dhṛta viṣaṇu ādi vigrahasya api anṛta tā pratipādana arthaḥ
translated: 'Free from disease' and 'free from fat' are mentioned again even though the prohibition of the body is already established by just that, in order to show that even the unreal incarnations like Visnu are prohibited.

original: tathāca 'māyā hyeṣā mayā sṛṣṭā yanmāṃ paśyasi nārada /
analyzed: tathā ca  māyā hi eṣā mayā sṛṣṭā yat mām paśyasi nārada
translated: And thus: This illusion, O Narada, has been created by me, by which you see me.

analyzed: sarva bhūta guṇaiḥ yuktam mā evam mām draṣṭum arhasi ti
translated: You should not see me as endowed with the qualities of all beings.

analyzed: śarīra upādāna bhūta avidyā rāhityāya śuddham iti
translated: 'Pure' means free from ignorance, which is the material cause of the body.

analyzed: tad nimitta rāhityāya a pāpa viddham iti
translated: 'Free from sin' means free from the cause of that.

original: atrānupraveśaḥ saṃbandhaḥ /🔽mayedaṃ kāryamityavagatimān hi niyojyo bhavati /
analyzed: atra anupraveśaḥ saṃbandhaḥ  mayā idam kāryam iti avagatimān hi niyojyaḥ bhavati
translated: Here, 'anu-prastha' means connection.🔽For one who understands 'this work is to be done by me' becomes one who is enjoined.

analyzed: kṛti sādhyaḥ ca vidhi viṣayaḥ bhavati
translated: And what is to be accomplished by action becomes the object of injunction.

analyzed: jñānasya ca kṛtya sādhya tvāt na ubhayam ātma jñānam bhavati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And since the knowledge of the self is not both of these, because knowledge is not to be accomplished by action, this is the idea.

analyzed: vidhi chāyāni prasiddha yāga ādi vidhi tulyāni
translated: 'Resembling injunctions' are similar to well-known injunctions regarding sacrifices etc.
The 'stream' is the flow of mental modifications within the individual self.

analyzed: kṛtam kṛtyam prāpaṇīyam prāptam iti eva tuṣyati pañca
translated: 'He is satisfied with the thought: The duty has been done, the duty to be attained has been attained. (Pancasikha)

analyzed: anusaṃjvaret śarīram paritapyamānam anutapyeta
translated: 'Anu-sanjvaret' means the body would be heated following the heat of another.
The word 'pratipatti' (comprehension) refers only to the cognition of valid and invalid knowledge.

analyzed: yat ca āpnoti yat ādatte yat ca atti viṣayān iha
translated: 'What one obtains, what one grasps, what one enjoys here as objects,

analyzed: yat ca asya saṃtataḥ bhāvaḥ tasmāt ātmā iti bhaṇyate iti
translated: and what is its continuous existence, for that reason it is called the self.'

analyzed: ahaṃpratyaya viṣayaḥ aupaniṣadaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: The object of the notion of 'I' is the Upanishadic person.

original: ahaṃpratyayaviṣayo yaḥ kartā kāryakaraṇasaṃghātopahito jīvātmā tadvyatirekeṇa /
analyzed: ahaṃpratyaya viṣayaḥ yaḥ kartā kārya karaṇa saṃghāta upahitaḥ jīvātmā tad vyatirekeṇa
translated: The individual self, which is the agent, is limited by the aggregate of body and organs, apart from that.

analyzed: iti evamādyā bhāpā
translated: 'Thus, etc.' is from the Bha.Pa.

analyzed: baṭoḥ vratam iti upakrāntam na īkṣeta udyantam ādityam ityādi prajāpativratam
translated: The vow of Prajapati, beginning with 'a student should not look at the rising sun', etc., is undertaken.

analyzed: vidhi anupraveśaḥ vidhi saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The connection with the injunction is the relation with the injunction.

analyzed: kūṭasthasya kṛtya yogāt na kartṛ tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the immutable one cannot be the agent because it is not related to action.

analyzed: śabdaḥ śābda vodhaḥ ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The word means verbal cognition.

analyzed: nirupacāreṇa guṇa jñānam vinā
translated: Without the knowledge of the attribute in an unqualified manner.

analyzed: śravaṇa manana kuśala tā mātreṇa paṇḍitānām anutpanna sākṣātkārāṇām iti yāvat
translated: Only by the skill in listening and reflecting, of the learned who have not yet attained realization, up to this point.

original: ahinirlvayanī sarpatvak valmīkādau pratyastā nikṣiptā mṛtā sarpeṇa tyaktābhimānā vartata evamityādyūhyam /
analyzed: ahi nirlvayanī sarpa tvac valmīka ādau pratyastā nikṣiptā mṛtā sarpeṇa tyakta abhimānā vartate evam ityādi ūhyam
translated: The slough of a snake, cast off by the snake on an anthill, etc., remains as if dead, abandoned by the snake. The meaning should be inferred in this way.

analyzed: brahma sākṣātkāraḥ vagatiḥ tad artha tvāt
translated: The realization of Brahman is the direct knowledge of Brahman, because that is its purpose.

analyzed: vidhi śeṣa tvena brahma arpaṇe pi
translated: Even in the offering of Brahman as an auxiliary to injunctions.

original: athāta iti tṛtīye śrutyādibhiḥ śeṣaśeṣitve siddhe satyanantaraṃ śeṣiṇaiva śeṣasya prayuktisaṃbhavātkonāma kratave kovā puruṣārtāyeti jijñāsā
analyzed: atha atas iti tṛtīye śruti ādibhiḥ śeṣa śeṣi tve siddhe sati anantaram śeṣiṇā eva śeṣasya prayukti saṃbhavāt kaḥ nāma kratave kaḥ vā puruṣa ārtāya iti jijñāsā
translated: Now, in the third chapter, when it is established by scripture etc. that Brahman is the primary and the other topics are secondary, then, since it is possible for the primary itself to employ the secondary, the inquiry begins in the fourth chapter as to which is for the sake of knowledge and which for the sake of human goals.

analyzed: pravṛttā caturtha ādau
translated: And it has begun in the fourth chapter and onwards.

analyzed: tasmāt jñānasya prameya pramātṛ bādhaka tva abhāvāt
translated: Therefore, since knowledge does not negate the object of knowledge or the knower,

analyzed: gaumā iti
translated: As in the case of cow.

analyzed: putra dāra ādiṣu ātma abhimānaḥ gauṇaḥ tatra bheda anubhavāt
translated: The notion of self in relation to wife, children, etc. is secondary, because there is the experience of difference there.

analyzed: tu abheda anubhavāt na gauṇaḥ kintu mithyā
translated: But in relation to the body, senses, etc., it is not secondary because of the experience of non-difference, but rather false.

analyzed: tad ubhaya ātmano satve putra deha ādi bādhanāt gauṇa ātmano satve putra kalatra ādi bādhanam
translated: When both of those selves do not exist, there is the negation of wife, children, etc. When the secondary self does not exist, there is the negation of wife, children, etc.

analyzed: mithyā ātmanaḥ sattve deha indriya ādi bādhanam ca
translated: And when the false self does not exist, there is the negation of body, senses, etc.

original: tathāca lokayātrakāryaṃ sadbrahmāhamiti bodhakāryaṃ advaitasākṣātkāraśca kathaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: tathā ca lokayātra kāryam sat brahma aham iti bodha kāryam advaita sākṣātkāraḥ ca katham bhavet
translated: And how can the functioning of worldly life, the functioning of the realization of the truth that I am Brahman, and the direct realization of non-duality be possible?

analyzed: anveṣṭavya ātma vijñānāt yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā
translated: From the knowledge of the self to be sought, That self which is free from evil, etc.

analyzed: saḥ nu eṣṭavyaḥ iti tad vijñānāt pūrvam ātmanaḥ mātṛ tvam pramā prameya pramāṇa vibhāgaḥ ca
translated: He is to be sought for, i.e., before the knowledge of him, the Self is the mother, and the division of the knower, the object of knowledge, and the means of knowledge.

analyzed: tena tad abhāve kāryam na utpadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in its absence, the effect is not produced.

analyzed: ātma niścayāt ā brahma svarūpa sākṣātkārāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that from the ascertainment of the Self, up to the direct realization of the nature of Brahman.

analyzed: īkṣati adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on He sees (Īśā 11).

original: evaṃ tāvadvedāntavākyānāṃ brahmātmāvagatiprayojanānāṃ brahmātmani tātparyeṇa samanvitānāmantareṇāpi kāryānupraveśaṃ /🔽brahmaṇi paryavasānamuktam /
analyzed: evam tāvat vedānta vākyānām brahma ātma avagati prayojanānām brahma ātmani tātparyeṇa samanvitānām antareṇa api kārya anupraveśam  brahmaṇi paryavasānam uktam
translated: Thus far, it has been said that the Vedānta passages, which have the purpose of bringing about the knowledge of Brahman as the Self, and which are complete in themselves, come to rest in Brahman, even without entering into the effect.

analyzed: brahma ca sarvajñam sarva śakti jagat utpatti sthiti nāśa kāraṇam iti uktam
translated: And Brahman is said to be omniscient, omnipotent, and the cause of the origin, sustentation, and dissolution of the world.

original: sāṃkhyādayastu pariniṣṭhitaṃ vastu pramāṇāntaragamyameveti manyamānāḥ pradhānādīni kāraṇāntarāṇyanumimānāstatparatayaiva vedāntavākyāni yojayanti
analyzed: sāṃkhya ādayaḥ tu pariniṣṭhitam vastu pramāṇa antara gamyam eva iti manyamānāḥ pradhāna ādīni kāraṇa antarāṇi anumimānāḥ tad para tayā eva vedānta vākyāni yojayanti
translated: But the Sāṃkhyas and others, considering the ultimate reality to be knowable only by other means of knowledge, inferring other causes such as primordial matter, interpret the Vedānta passages in such a way as to accord with their own views.

original: sarveṣveva vedāntavākyeṣu sṛṣṭiviṣayeṣvanumānenaiva kāryeṇa kāraṇaṃ lilakṣayiṣitam /
analyzed: sarveṣu eva vedānta vākyeṣu sṛṣṭi viṣayeṣu anumānena eva kāryeṇa kāraṇam
translated: In all the Vedānta passages dealing with creation, the cause is inferred only by the effect.

analyzed: pradhāna puruṣa saṃyogāḥ nitya anumeyāḥ iti sāṃkhyāḥ manyante
translated: The Sāṃkhyas think that the conjunction of the primordial matter and the souls is to be inferred as eternal.

original: kāṇādāstvetebhya eva vākyebhya īśvaraṃ nimittakāraṇamanumimate aṇūṃśca samavāyikāraṇam /
analyzed: kāṇādāḥ tu etebhyaḥ eva vākyebhyaḥ īśvaram nimitta kāraṇam anumimate aṇūn ca samavāyi kāraṇam
translated: But the Kāṇādas, on the other hand, infer from these very passages that God is the instrumental cause and the atoms are the material cause.

analyzed: evam anye pi tārkikāḥ vākya ābhāsa yukti ābhāsa avaṣṭambhāḥ pūrvapakṣa vādinaḥ iha uttiṣṭante
translated: In this way, other logicians also, relying on false arguments and false passages, stand as opponents here.

original: tatra padavākyapramāṇajñenācāryeṇa vedāntavākyānāṃ brahmāvagatiparatvadarśanāya vākyābhāsayuktābhāsavipratipattayaḥ pūrvapakṣīkṛtya nirākriyante
analyzed: tatra pada vākya pramāṇa jñena ācāryeṇa vedānta vākyānām brahma avagati para tva darśanāya vākya ābhāsa yukta ābhāsa vipratipattayaḥ pūrvapakṣīkṛtya nirākriyante
translated: There, the teacher, who knows the words and sentences as valid means of knowledge, having made the disagreements with false arguments and false passages regarding the Vedānta passages as the prima facie view, refutes them in order to show that they are for the purpose of realizing Brahman.

original: tatra sāṃkhyāḥ pradhānaṃ triguṇamacetanaṃ jagataḥ kāraṇamiti manyamānā āhuḥ yāni
analyzed: tatra sāṃkhyāḥ pradhānam triguṇam acetanam jagataḥ kāraṇam iti manyamānāḥ āhuḥ yāni
translated: There, the Sāṃkhyas, considering the primordial matter to be the cause of the world, having three qualities and being insentient, say: Those

analyzed: vedānta vākyāni sarvajñasya sarva śakteḥ brahmaṇaḥ jagat kāraṇa tvam darśayanti iti avocaḥ tāni
translated: passages of the Vedānta that you have said show the all-knowing, all-powerful Brahman to be the cause of the world,

analyzed: pradhāna kāraṇa pakṣe pi yojayitum śakyante
translated: can be applied even to the side of the primordial matter being the cause.

analyzed: sarva śakti tvam tāvat pradhānasya api sva vikāra viṣayam upapadyate
translated: The all-powerful nature is possible for the primordial matter also, with regard to its own evolutes.

analyzed: evam sarvajña tvam api upapadyate
translated: In the same way, the all-knowing nature is also possible.

analyzed: katham
translated: How?

analyzed: yat tu jñānam manyase sa sattva dharmaḥ
translated: But the knowledge which you consider to be the attribute of the soul,

analyzed: sattvāt saṃjāyate jñānam iti smṛteḥ
translated: is produced from the soul, according to the Smṛti (verse), ‘Knowledge is produced from the soul’ (Gītā, 14.3).

original: tena ca sattvadharmeṇa jñānena kāryakāraṇavantaḥ puruṣāḥ sarvajñā yoginaḥ prasiddhāḥ /
analyzed: tena ca sattva dharmeṇa jñānena kārya kāraṇavantaḥ puruṣāḥ sarvajñāḥ yoginaḥ prasiddhāḥ
translated: And by that knowledge which is the attribute of the soul, the souls which are endowed with cause and effect are known to be omniscient by the yogins.

analyzed: sattvasya hi niratiśaya utkarṣe sarvajña tvam prasiddham
translated: For omniscience is well known to be the result of the soul’s having the highest excellence of the quality of goodness.

original: na kevalasyākāryakāraṇasya puruṣopalabdhimātrasya sarvajñatvaṃ kiñcijjñatvaṃ vā kalpayituṃ śakyam /
analyzed: na kevalasya akārya kāraṇasya puruṣa upalabdhi mātrasya sarvajñatvam kiñcijjñatvam vā kalpayitum śakyam
translated: But it is not possible to suppose that the soul, which is not endowed with cause and effect, and which is merely perceived, is omniscient or knows something.

original: triguṇatvāttu pradhānasya sarvajñānakāraṇabhūtaṃ sattvaṃ pradhānāvasthāyāmapi vidyata iti pradhānasyācetanasyaiva sataḥ sarvajñatvamupacaryate
analyzed: triguṇa tvāt tu pradhānasya sarvajñāna kāraṇa bhūtam sattvam pradhāna avasthāyām api vidyate iti pradhānasya acetanasya eva sataḥ sarvajña tvam upacaryate
translated: But since the pradhāna is composed of the three qualities, the quality of goodness, which is the cause of all knowledge, exists even in the state of the pradhāna. Therefore, omniscience is attributed to the pradhāna, which is insentient and existent.

original: vedāntavākyeṣvavaśyaṃ ca tvayāpi sarvajñaṃ brahmābhyupagacchatā sarvajñānāktimattvenaiva sarvajñatvamupagantavyam /
analyzed: vedānta vākyeṣu avaśyam ca tvayā api sarvajñam brahma abhyupagacchatā sarva jñāna aktimat tvena eva sarvajña tvam upagantavyam
translated: And by you also, who must accept the omniscience of Brahman in the Vedānta texts, omniscience must be accepted only as consisting in the possession of all knowledge.

original: nahi sarvaviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ kurvadeva brahma vartate /
analyzed: nahi sarva viṣayam jñānam kurvat eva brahma vartate
translated: For Brahman does not exist as long as it is engaged in producing knowledge of all objects.

original: tathāhi jñānasya nityatve jñānakriyāṃ prati svātantryaṃ brahmaṇo hīyeta /
analyzed: tathā hi jñānasya nitya tve jñāna kriyām prati svātantryam brahmaṇaḥ hīyeta
translated: For, if knowledge is eternal, Brahman’s independence with regard to the act of knowing is lost.

analyzed: atha anityam tat iti jñāna kriyāyāḥ uparameta api brahma
translated: Or, if it is non-eternal, then Brahman also ceases to exist when the act of knowing ceases.

analyzed: tadā sarvajñāna aktimat tvena eva sarvajña tvam āpatati
translated: Then, omniscience would follow only from the possession of all knowledge.

analyzed: api ca prāk utpatteḥ sarva kārakā śūnyam brahma iṣyate tvayā
translated: Moreover, you accept that Brahman is devoid of all effects prior to creation.

original: naca jñānasādhanānāṃ śarīrendriyādīnāmabhāve jñānotpattiḥ kasyacidupapannā /🔽apica pradhānasyanekātmakasya pariṇāmāsaṃbhavātkāraṇatvopapattirmṛdādivat /
analyzed: na ca jñāna sādhanānām śarīra indriya ādīnām abhāve jñāna utpattiḥ kasyacid upapannā  api ca pradhānasya aneka ātmakasya pariṇāma asaṃbhavāt kāraṇatva upapattiḥ mṛd ādi vat
translated: And the origin of knowledge is not possible for anyone in the absence of the body, sense organs, etc., which are the means of knowledge.🔽Furthermore, since the transformation of the non-composite, unitary Brahman is impossible, the possibility of being a cause is established for the Pradhana, which has many parts, like clay, etc.

original: nāsaṃhatasyaikātmakasya brahmaṇa ityevaṃ prāptaṃ idaṃ sūtramārabhyate
analyzed: na asaṃhatasya eka ātmakasya brahmaṇaḥ iti evam prāptam idam sūtram ārabhyate
translated: This is the conclusion. This aphorism is begun:

analyzed: kārya sambandham vinā api anumeyāḥ iti
translated: Even without the relation of effect, they are to be inferred.

original: buddhau yaḥ pratibimbaḥ sa tādṛśabimbapūrvakaḥ pratibimbatvāt /
analyzed: buddhau yaḥ pratibimbaḥ sa tādṛśa bimba pūrvakaḥ pratibimba tvāt
translated: The reflection in the intellect has a corresponding original object, because it is a reflection,

analyzed: darpaṇe mukha ābhāsāt iti anumānam  vyākaraṇa mīmāṃsā nyāyāḥ pada vākya pramāṇāni
translated: like the reflection of the face in a mirror. This is the inference.🔽Vyakarana, Mimansa and Nyaya are the authorities on words, sentences and logic.

analyzed: vākya ābhāseṣu yukti ābhāseṣu ca vipratipattiḥ yeṣām te
translated: Those who disagree about false sentences and false arguments.

analyzed: jñāna kriyām prati jñā dhātvartham prati
translated: With regard to the activity of knowledge, with regard to the meaning of the root jñā (to know).

analyzed: svātantryam kartṛ tvam
translated: Independence is the state of being an agent.

analyzed: ādi padena jñeya jñātṛ ādi saṃgrahaḥ
translated: By the word ādi (etc.) is meant the inclusion of the knower, the known, etc.
The causality of Pradhāna (Primordial Matter) and others is refuted by logical arguments in the Tarka Pada (Chapter on Logic).

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ kāraṇa tvam smṛti pāde samarthyate
translated: The causality of Brahman is established in the Smṛti Pada (Chapter on Smṛti).

analyzed: īkṣateḥ na a śabdam
translated: Not from the Sāṅkhya, because of the mention of the seer.

original: na sāṃkhyaparikalpitamacetanaṃ pradhānaṃ jagataḥ kāraṇaṃ śakyaṃ vedānteṣvāśrayitum /
analyzed: na sāṃkhya parikalpitam acetanam pradhānam jagataḥ kāraṇam śakyam vedānteṣu āśrayitum
translated: The unconscious Pradhāna postulated by the Sāṅkhyas cannot be accepted as the cause of the world in the Vedānta texts.

analyzed: aśabdam hi tat
translated: For that is not mentioned in the Veda.

analyzed: katham aśabda tvam
translated: How is it not mentioned?

analyzed: īkṣateḥ īkṣitṛ tva śravaṇāt kāraṇasya
translated: Because of the mention of the seer, the cause.

analyzed: katham
translated: How so?

analyzed: evam hi śrūyate sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīyam
translated: For this is heard: O Somya, this world existed in the beginning as Being, one only, without a second.

original: chāndo / / / ityupakramya 'tadaikṣata bahu syāṃ prajāyeyeti tattejo 'sṛjata' chāndo / / / iti /🔽tatredaṃśabdavācyaṃ nāmarūpavyākṛtaṃ jagatprāgutpatteḥ sadātmanāvadhārya tasyaiva prakṛtasya sacchabdavācyasyekṣaṇapūrvakaṃ tejaḥprabhṛteḥ
analyzed: chāndaḥ iti upakramya tat aikṣata bahu syām prajāyeya iti tat tejaḥ sṛjata chāndaḥ iti  tatra idam śabda vācyam nāma rūpa vyākṛtam jagat prāc utpatteḥ sat ātmanā avadhārya tasya eva prakṛtasya sat śabda vācyasya īkṣaṇa pūrvakam tejaḥ prabhṛteḥ
translated: Having begun thus, it is said: It thought: 'Let me be many. Let me procreate.' It emitted fire.

analyzed: sraṣṭṛ tvam darśayati
translated: There, this world, manifested by name and form, which is denoted by the word this, is determined to be of the nature of Being before creation. And it shows the state of being the creator of fire and others preceded by the seeing of that very subject denoted by the word Being, which is the original topic.

analyzed: tathā anyatra ātmā vai idam ekaḥ eva agre āsīt
translated: So also in another place: ‘In the beginning this was Self, one only, without a second.

original: nānyatkiñcana miṣat /🔽sa īkṣata lokānnu sṛjā iti /
analyzed: na anyat kiñcana miṣat  saḥ īkṣata lokān nu sṛjai iti
translated: There was nothing else whatsoever moving.🔽He looked upon the creation of the worlds.

analyzed: saḥ imān lokān asṛjata aita
translated: He created these worlds.’ (Chānd. Up. 6.2.1)

analyzed: iti īkṣā pūrvikām eva sṛṣṭim ācaṣṭe
translated: Thus it declares the creation to have been preceded by the act of looking.

analyzed: dvacid ca ṣoḍaṣa kalam puruṣam prastutya āha saḥ īkṣāñcakre
translated: And in another place, referring to the person of sixteen parts, it says: ‘He looked.

analyzed: sa prāṇam asṛjata praśnaḥ iti
translated: He created the vital air.’ (Praśna Up. 1.1)

analyzed: īkṣateḥ iti ca dhātvartha nirdeśaḥ bhipretaḥ
translated: And the word ‘īkṣateḥ’ (from the root ‘īkṣ’) is meant to indicate the meaning of the root,

analyzed: yajateḥ iti vat
translated: like the word ‘yajateḥ’ (from the root ‘yaj’).

analyzed: na dhātu nirdeśaḥ
translated: It is not an indication of the root itself.

analyzed: tena yaḥ sarva jñaḥ sarva vidyasya jñāna mayam tapaḥ
translated: Therefore, such passages as ‘He who is omniscient, in whom knowledge is the austerity consisting of knowledge,

original: tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ na jāyate' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: tasmāt etat brahma nāma rūpam annam na jāyate muṇḍa
translated: from whom this Brahman consisting of name, form, and food is not born’ (Muṇḍ. Up. 1.1.9)

analyzed: iti evamādīni api sarvajña īśvara kāraṇa parāṇi
translated: should also be quoted as referring to the all-knowing God as the cause.

original: yattūktaṃ sattvadharmeṇa jñānena sarvajñaṃ pradhānaṃ bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam sattva dharmeṇa jñānena sarvajñam pradhānam bhaviṣyati iti
translated: As for what was said that the primordial matter would be all-knowing by the knowledge which is the attribute of the sattva,

analyzed: tat na upapadyate
translated: that is not correct.

analyzed: nahi pradhāna avasthāyām guṇa sāmyāt sattva dharmaḥ jñānam saṃbhavati
translated: For when in the state of primordial matter, there is an equilibrium of the constituents, knowledge, which is the attribute of the sattva, is not possible.

analyzed: nanu uktam sarva jñāna śaktimat tvena sarvajñam bhaviṣyati iti
translated: But was it not said that it would be all-knowing by possessing the power of all knowledge?

analyzed: tat api na upapadyate
translated: That also is not correct.🔽If, on the ground of the activity of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.🔽And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.

original: yadi guṇasāmye sati sattvavyapāśrayāṃ jñānāktimāśritya sarvajñaṃ pradhānamucyeta kāmaṃ rajastamovyapāśrayāmapi jñānapratibandhakaśaktimāśritya 🔽kiñcijjñamucyeta /
analyzed: yadi guṇa sāmye sati sattva vyapāśrayām jñāna aktim āśritya sarvajñam pradhānam ucyeta kāmam rajaḥ tamaḥ vyapāśrayām api jñāna pratibandhaka śaktim āśritya  kiñcid jñam ucyeta
translated: And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.

original: apica nāsākṣikā sattvavṛttirjānātinābhidhīyete /🔽na cācetanasya pradhānasya sākṣitvamasti /
analyzed: apica na a sākṣikā sattva vṛttiḥ jānātinā abhidhīyete  na ca acetanasya pradhānasya sākṣi tvam asti
translated: And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.

analyzed: tasmāt anupapannam pradhānasya sarvajña tvam
translated: And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.🔽And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.

analyzed: yoginām tu cetana tvāt sattva utkarṣa nimittam sarvajña tvam upapannam iti anudāharaṇam
translated: And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.

analyzed: atha punar sākṣi nimittam īkṣitṛ tvam kalpyeta  yathā agni nimittam ayaḥ piṇḍa ādeḥ dagdhṛ tvam
translated: And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.🔽And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.🔽And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.🔽And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.🔽And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.

original: tathāsati yannimittamīkṣitṛtvaṃ pradhānasya tadeva sarvajñaṃ mukhyaṃ brahma jagataḥ kāraṇamiti yuktam /
analyzed: tathā asati yat nimittam īkṣitṛ tvam pradhānasya tat eva sarvajñam mukhyam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam iti yuktam
translated: And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful.🔽And on the ground of the quality of darkness, it may be said to be the cause of the world.

analyzed: yat punar uktam na mukhyam sarvajña tvam upapadyate
translated: And if, on the ground of the quality of goodness, the pradhāna is said to be omniscient, on the ground of the quality of activity, it may be said to be all-powerful

analyzed: nitya jñāna kriya tve jñāna kriyām prati svātantrya asaṃbhavāt iti
translated: Because if it is eternal knowledge and action, it is not possible for it to be independent with regard to the action of knowledge.

analyzed: atrā ucyate idam tāvat bhavān praṣṭavyaḥ
translated: To this we reply: This much should first be asked of you:

analyzed: katham nitya jñāna kriya tve sarvajña tva hāniḥ iti
translated: How is there the loss of omniscience if it is eternal knowledge and action?

original: yasya hi sarvaviṣayāvabhāsanakṣamaṃ jñānaṃ nityamasti so 'sarvajña iti vipratiṣiddham /
analyzed: yasya hi sarva viṣaya avabhāsana kṣamam jñānam nityam asti saḥ sarvajñaḥ iti vipratiṣiddham
translated: For it is contradictory to say that one who has eternal knowledge capable of illuminating all objects is not omniscient.

original: anityatve hi jñānasya kadācijjānāti kadācinnajānātītyasarvajñatvamapi syāt /
analyzed: anitya tve hi jñānasya kadācid jānāti kadācid na jānāti iti asarvajña tvam api syāt
translated: If knowledge were non-eternal, sometimes it would know, sometimes it would not know, and omniscience would also be impossible.

original: nāsau jñānanityatve doṣo 'sti jñānanityatve jñānaviṣayaḥ svātantryavyapadeśo nopapadyata iti cenna /
analyzed: na asau jñāna nitya tve doṣaḥ sti jñāna nitya tve jñāna viṣayaḥ svātantrya vyapadeśaḥ nā upapadyate iti ced na
translated: If this is said to be a fault in the eternality of knowledge, that the designation of independence with regard to the object of knowledge is not possible in the eternality of knowledge, it is not so.

analyzed: pratata auṣṇya prakāśe savitari dahati prakāśayati iti svātantrya vyapadeśa darśanāt
translated: Because even in the sun, which has continuous heat and light, the designation of independence is seen, as in it burns, it illuminates.

original: nanu saviturdāhyaprakāśasaṃyoge sati dahati prakāśayatīti vyapadeśaḥ syāt /
analyzed: nanu savituḥ dāhya prakāśa saṃyoge sati dahati prakāśayati iti vyapadeśaḥ syāt
translated: But it may be said that if there is a conjunction of the sun with what is to be burned and what is to be illuminated, the designation it burns, it illuminates would be appropriate.

original: natu brahmaṇaḥ prāgutpatterjñānakarmasaṃyogo 'stīti viṣamo dṛṣṭāntaḥ / na /
analyzed: na tu brahmaṇaḥ prāk utpatteḥ jñāna karma saṃyogaḥ sti iti viṣamaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ na
translated: But Brahman does not have a conjunction with knowledge and action prior to creation, so the example is not apt. No.

original: asatyapi karmaṇi savitā prakāśata iti kartṛtvavyapadeśadarśanāt /
analyzed: asati api karmaṇi savitā prakāśate iti kartṛ tva vyapadeśa darśanāt
translated: For we see that the sun is spoken of as an agent, although it does not act, in the passage, The sun shines, &c, Bṛ Up , , 0

original: evamasatyapi jñānakarmaṇi brahmaṇaḥ 'tadaikṣata' iti kartṛtvavyapadeśopapatterna vaiṣamyam /
analyzed: evam asati api jñāna karmaṇi brahmaṇaḥ tadā aikṣata iti kartṛ tva vyapadeśa upapatteḥ na vaiṣamyam
translated: In the same way Brahman may be spoken of as an agent in the passage, It thought, although it does not act in the way of knowledge; so that there is no inequality of the two cases

analyzed: karma apekṣāyām tu brahmaṇi īkṣitṛ tva śrutayaḥ sutarām upapannāḥ
translated: But if the existence of an act is admitted, the passages which declare that Brahman is the seer are still more easily accounted for

analyzed: kim punar tat karma  yat prāk utpatteḥ īśvara jñānasya viṣayaḥ bhavati iti
translated: What then is that act?🔽It is that of which Brahman has knowledge before the creation, and which therefore cannot be either name or form, unmanifested as it is

original: tattvānyatvābhyāmanirvacanīye nāmarūpe avyākṛte vyācikīrṣite iti brūmaḥ /
analyzed: tattva anya tvābhyām anirvacanīye nāma rūpe avyākṛte vyācikīrṣite iti brūmaḥ
translated: We declare that it is that which is to be manifested, which cannot be defined as either different from Brahman or nondifferent from it

analyzed: yad prasādāt hi yoginām api atīta anāgata viṣayam pratyakṣam jñānam icchanti yoga śāstra vidaḥ
translated: For those who are acquainted with the Yogaśāstra maintain that even the yogins have a knowledge of the past and the future only through the favour of the Lord, and that without his favour they are unable to know anything beyond the limits of the present moment

original: kimu vaktavyaṃ tasya nityasiddhasyeśvarasya sṛṣṭisthitisaṃhṛtiviṣayaṃ nityajñānaṃ bhavatīti /
analyzed: kimu vaktavyam tasya nitya siddhasya īśvarasya sṛṣṭi sthiti saṃhṛti viṣayam nitya jñānam bhavati iti
translated: How much less then can the eternal knowledge of the Lord, who is eternally existent, have for its object the creation, the subsistence, and the reabsorption of the world?

analyzed: yat api uktam prāk utpatteḥ brahmaṇaḥ śarīra ādi saṃbandham antareṇa īkṣitṛ tvam anupapannam iti
translated: The pūrvapakṣin maintains that the objection urged above against the doctrine of Brahman being the cause of the world, that it is impossible to assume that Brahman, before the creation, should be an agent without being connected with a body, &c, is valid

analyzed: na tat codyam avatarati
translated: This objection, we reply, does not hold good

analyzed: savitṛ prakāśa vat brahmaṇaḥ jñāna svarūpa nitya tve jñāna sādhana apekṣā anupapatteḥ
translated: If Brahman, like the sun, were of the nature of eternal knowledge, the necessity of the means of knowledge would be unintelligible.

original: apicāvidyādimataḥ saṃsāriṇaḥ śarīrādyapekṣā jñānotpattiḥ syānna jñānapratibandhakāraṇarahitasyeśvarasya /🔽mantrau cemāvīśvarasya śarīrādyanapekṣatāmanāvaraṇajñānatāṃ ca darśayataḥ 'na tasya kāryaṃ karaṇaṃ ca vidyate na tatsamaścābhyadhikaśca dṛśyate
analyzed: api ca avidyā ādimataḥ saṃsāriṇaḥ śarīra ādi apekṣā jñāna utpattiḥ syāt na jñāna pratibandha kāraṇa rahitasya īśvarasya  mantrau ca imau īśvarasya śarīra ādi anapekṣa tām anāvaraṇa jñāna tām ca darśayataḥ na tasya kāryam karaṇam ca vidyate na tad samaḥ ca abhyadhikaḥ ca dṛśyate
translated: Moreover, the knowledge of the transmigrating soul, which is subject to Nescience, &c, must depend on a body, &c, but not so the knowledge of the Lord, who is free from all causes of obstruction to knowledge.

original: parāsya śaktirvividhaiva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñānabalakriyā ca' śvetā / / iti /
analyzed: parā asya śaktiḥ vividhā eva śrūyate svābhāvikī jñāna bala kriyā ca śvetā iti
translated: And two Mantras declare that the Lord does not stand in need of a body, &c, and that his knowledge is unobstructed, There is no work, no instrument of work, for him; nothing equal or greater to him is seen Śve Up , And of him various powers are heard, natural, of knowledge, of strength, and of action Śve Up ,

analyzed: a pāṇi pādaḥ javanaḥ grahītā paśyati a cakṣuḥ sa śṛṇoti a karṇaḥ
translated: He who has neither hands nor feet can move and grasp; he who has neither eyes nor ears sees and hears;

original: sa vetti vedyaṃ na ca tasyāsti vettā tamāhuragryaṃ puruṣaṃ mahāntam' śvetā / / iti ca /
analyzed: sa vetti vedyam na ca tasya asti vettā tam āhuḥ agryam puruṣam mahāntam śvetāḥ iti ca
translated: he knows the knowable, and there is no knower of him; him they call the highest person, the great Śve Up ,

analyzed: nanu nā asti tāvat jñāna pratibandha kāraṇavān īśvarāt anyaḥ saṃsārī
translated: But, it may be objected, there is no transmigrating soul other than the Lord, who might be subject to the causes of the obstruction of knowledge

original: 'nānyo 'stī draṣṭā nānyo 'to 'stī vijñātā' bṛha / / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: na anyā u stī draṣṭā na anyā u to stī vijñātā bṛhaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: For scripture declares, There is no other seer but he; there is no other knower but he Bṛ Up , ,

original: tatra kimidamucyate saṃsāriṇaḥ śarīrādyapekṣā jñānotpattirneśvarasyeti /🔽atrocyate satyaṃ /
analyzed: tatra kim idam ucyate saṃsāriṇaḥ śarīra ādi apekṣā jñāna utpattiḥ na īśvarasya iti  atra ucyate satyam
translated: What is meant by this question, “Is the knowledge of the Lord dependent upon the body, etc., as it is in the case of the transmigrating soul?”

analyzed: na īśvarāt anyaḥ saṃsārī
translated: The answer to this is as follows: It is true that there is no transmigrating soul apart from God;

analyzed: tathā api deha ādi saṃghāta upādhi saṃbandhaḥ iti atas eva
translated: yet, on account of the connection of the Lord with the limiting adjunct in the shape of the aggregate of body, etc.,

analyzed: ghaṭa karaka giri guhā ādi upādhi saṃbandhaḥ iva vyomnaḥ
translated: just as the Ākāśa is connected with the limiting adjuncts in the shape of jars, pots, hills, caves, etc.;

original: tatkṛtaśca śabdapratyayavyavahāro lokasya dṛṣṭo ghaṭacchidraṃ karakādicchidramityādirākāśāvyatireke 'pi tatkṛtā cākāśe ghaṭākāśādibhedamithyābuddhirdṛṣṭā
analyzed: tad kṛtaḥ ca śabda pratyaya vyavahāraḥ lokasya dṛṣṭaḥ ghaṭa chidram karaka ādi chidram ityādiḥ ākāśa avyatireke tad kṛtā ca ākāśe ghaṭa ākāśa ādi bheda mithyā buddhiḥ dṛṣṭā
translated: and it is also seen that people make use of words and ideas in regard to Ākāśa, as if it were something different from the jars, etc., and they have the false notion of the difference of Ākāśa as ‘jar-ākāśa’, ‘pot-ākāśa’ and so forth, even though Ākāśa is not really different from these things;

analyzed: tathā iha api deha ādi saṃghāta upādhi saṃbandha aviveka kṛta īśvara saṃsāri bheda mithyā buddhiḥ
translated: in the same manner, in the case in question, the difference between the Lord and the transmigrating soul is due to the non-discrimination of the fact that the Lord is connected with the limiting adjunct in the shape of the aggregate of body, etc.;

original: dṛśyate cātmana eva sato dehādisaṃghāte 'nātmanyātmatvābhiniveśo mithyābuddhimātreṇa pūrveṇa /
analyzed: dṛśyate ca ātmanaḥ eva sataḥ deha ādi saṃghāte na ātmani ātma tva abhiniveśaḥ mithyā buddhi mātreṇa pūrveṇa
translated: and it is also seen that the man who is existent as the pure ‘Soul’, has the false notion of the ‘Soul’ in the aggregate of body, etc. which is not the ‘Soul’, due to the previous false notion.

analyzed: sati ca evam saṃsāri tve deha ādi apekṣam īkṣitṛ tvam upapannam saṃsāriṇaḥ
translated: And when there is this state of being a ‘transmigrating being’, it is only right that the act of ‘seeing’ should be dependent upon the body, etc., in the case of the transmigrating being.

analyzed: yat api uktam pradhānasya aneka ātmaka tvāt mṛd ādi vat kāraṇatva upapattiḥ na asaṃhatasya brahmaṇaḥ iti
translated: It has been argued (under Text 213) that “the Primordial Matter being a composite substance, it is capable of effective action, like the Jar, etc., and not Brahman, which is not a composite substance”.

analyzed: tad pradhānasya a śabda tvena eva pratyuktam
translated: This has been already answered by the fact that the pradhāna is not mentioned in the passage under discussion.

original: yathā tu tarkeṇāpi brahmaṇa eva kāraṇatvaṃ nirvoḍhuṃ śakyate na pradhānādīnāṃ tathā prapañcayiṣyati 'na vilakṣaṇatvādasya' bra / / /🔽ityevamādinā // //🔽atrāha yaduktaṃ nācetanaṃ pradhānaṃ jagatkāraṇamīkṣitṛtvāditi tadanyathāpyupapadyate /
analyzed: yathā tu tarkeṇa api brahmaṇaḥ eva kāraṇa tvam nirvoḍhum śakyate na pradhāna ādīnām tathā prapañcayiṣyati na vilakṣaṇa tvāt asya brahma  iti evamādinā  atra āha yat uktam na acetanam pradhānam jagat kāraṇam īkṣitṛ tvāt iti tat anyathā api upapadyate
translated: But we shall show later on that the existence of Brahman as the cause of the world can be established by reasoning, while the existence of the pradhāna and so on cannot be so established; cp the Sūtras 2, 1, 14, 2, 1, 31, 2, 1, 32

analyzed: acetane pi cetana vat upacāra darśanāt
translated: Here the pūrvapakṣin maintains that the objection founded on the fact of the world being seen does not apply to the doctrine of the pradhāna being the cause of the world; because the pradhāna may be spoken of as seeing, although it is not conscious, just as an unconscious thing may be spoken of as conscious

original: yathā pratyāsannapatanatāṃ nadyāḥ kūlasyālakṣya kūlaṃ pipātiṣatītyacetane 'pi kūle cetanavadupacāro dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: yathā pratyāsanna patana tām nadyāḥ kūlasya ālakṣya kūlam pipātiṣati iti acetane pi kūle cetana vat upacāraḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: For instance, when the bank of a river is about to fall down on one side only, people say that the bank runs, although the bank is an unconscious thing

original: tadvadacetano 'pi pradhāne pratyāsannasarge cetanavadupacāro bhaviṣyati 'tadaikṣata' iti /🔽yathā loke kaściccetanaḥ snātvā bhuktvā cāparāhne grāmaṃ rathena gamiṣyāmītīkṣitvānantaraṃ tathaiva niyamena pravartate /
analyzed: tadvat acetanaḥ pi pradhāne pratyāsanna sarge cetana vat upacāraḥ bhaviṣyati tadā aikṣata iti  yathā loke kaścid cetanaḥ snātvā bhuktvā ca aparāhne grāmam rathena gamiṣyāmi iti īkṣitvā anantaram tathā eva niyamena pravartate
translated: In the same way the pradhāna, although unconscious, may be spoken of as conscious, when it is about to produce the great principle and so on, and therefore may be said to see, as it were, in the passage, It thought

analyzed: tathā pradhānam api mahat ādi ākāreṇa niyamena pravartate
translated: For in ordinary life a conscious being, after having bathed and eaten, thinks in the afternoon, I will go to the village in my chariot, and then acts accordingly; and in the same way the pradhāna also acts in a regular manner, by passing over into the form of the great principle and so on

analyzed: tasmāt cetana vat upacaryate
translated: Therefore, it is figuratively spoken of as having consciousness.

analyzed: kasmāt punar kāraṇāt vihāya mukhyam īkṣitṛ tvam aupacārikam kalpyate  tat tejaḥ aikṣata
translated: But why is the primary meaning of the seer rejected and a figurative one assumed?🔽Because we find figurative expressions even in regard to non-intelligent things, such as 'That fire desired' (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.1),

analyzed: tāḥ āpaḥ aikṣanta chāndaḥ  iti ca acetanayoḥ api ap tejasoḥ cetana vat upacāra darśanāt
translated: and 'Those waters desired' (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.3.2).

analyzed: tasmāt kartṛkam api īkṣaṇam aupacārikam iti gamyate  upacāra prāye vacanāt iti
translated: Therefore, it is understood that the act of desiring is also figurative in the case of the non-intelligent fire and water.

analyzed: evam prāpte idam sūtram ārabhyate
translated: Thus, the Sūtra is begun:

analyzed: sāmānyatas sarve jānāti iti sarvajñaḥ
translated: 'Sarvajña' means knowing everything in general.

analyzed: tad tad viśeṣa dharma ghaṭa ādi puraskāreṇa sarve vetti iti sarva vid
translated: 'Sarvavit' means knowing everything in particular, such as pots etc.

analyzed: etat brahma jāyamānam hiraṇya garbha ākhyam kāryam
translated: This Brahman, when becoming, becomes the effect called Hiraṇyagarbha.

analyzed: sāṃkhyīyam sva mata samādhānam upanyasya dūṣayati yat tu uktam iti
translated: Having presented the Sāṃkhya's own solution, he criticizes it.

analyzed: acetanasya ajñātṛ tvam tad śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'that' is the non-knowing of the non-intelligent.

analyzed: sa īśvara sāṃkhya matam āha atha iti
translated: He states the Sāṃkhya view with an Īśvara: Now, if it is argued.

analyzed: pratatā iti asya saṃtatā iti arthaḥ  asati api avivakṣite api
translated: The meaning of the suffix is like the meaning of the root.

analyzed: prakṛti arthavat pratyaya arthasya api bādhā abhāvāt sutarām iti uktam
translated: Even when it is not true, even when it is not intended, it is said to be all the more so because there is no contradiction of the meaning of the suffix.

analyzed: kāryam śarīram
translated: The body is the effect.

analyzed: karaṇam indriya jātam
translated: The organs are the instruments.

original: abhiniveśo mithyābhimānaḥ /🔽gauṇaścennātmaśabdāt / / / /🔽yaduktaṃ pradhānamacetanaṃ sacchabdavācyaṃ tasminnaupacārika īkṣatiḥ /
analyzed: abhiniveśaḥ mithyā abhimānaḥ  gauṇaḥ ced na ātma śabdāt  / yat uktam pradhānam acetanam sat śabda vācyam tasmin aupacārikaḥ īkṣatiḥ
translated: Attachment is false pride.🔽If it be said that the word is used figuratively because it is the cause, no; on account of the word 'self.'

analyzed: ap tejasoḥ iva iti tat asat
translated: It has been said that the nonintelligent pradhāna is denoted by the word Sat, and that the word 'sees' is used with regard to it in a derived sense, just as it is with regard to water and fire; but that is inadmissible.

original: kasmāt / ātmaśabdāt /🔽'sadeva somyedamagra āsīt' ityupakramya 'tadaikṣata tattejo 'sṛjata' chāndo / / / /
analyzed: kasmāt ātma śabdāt  sat eva somya idam agre āsīt iti upakramya tat aikṣata tat tejaḥ sṛjata chāndo
translated: For what reason? On account of the word 'self.'

original: iti ca tejo 'bannānāṃ sṛṣṭimuktvā tadeva prakṛtaṃ sadīkṣitṛ /🔽tāni ca tejo 'bannāni /
analyzed: iti ca tejaḥ bannānām sṛṣṭim uktvā tat eva prakṛtam sa dīkṣitṛ  tāni ca tejaḥ bannāni
translated: After the text has begun with the words, In the beginning all this was Self, one only, has declared that the creation of fire, water, and earth took place in the following manner, In that Self there arose a desire to create; it sent forth fire, and that fire, having become air, became the three worlds, earth, air, and heaven Ch Up , ,

original: devatāśabdena parāmṛśyāha 'seyaṃ devataikṣata hantāhamimāstisro devatā anena jīvenātmanānupravaśya nāmarūpe vyākaravāṇi' chāndo / / / iti🔽tatra yadi pradhānamacetanaṃ guṇavṛttyekṣitṛ kalpyeta tadeva prakṛtatvātseyaṃ devateti parāmṛśyeta /
analyzed: devatā śabdena parāmṛśya āha sā iyam devatā aikṣata hanta aham imāḥ tisraḥ devatāḥ anena jīvena ātmanā anupravaśya nāma rūpe vyākaravāṇi chāndo iti  tatra yadi pradhānam acetanam guṇa vṛttyā īkṣitṛ kalpyeta tat eva prakṛta tvāt sā iyam devatā iti parāmṛśyeta
translated: and then again refers to that same Self which had the desire to create, and to fire, water, and earth, as the deities, and says, This deity thought, may transform myself by entering into these three deities with this living Self, and may evolve names and forms Ch Up , ,

analyzed: na tadā devatāḥ jīva ātma śabdena abhidadhyāt
translated: If the nonintelligent pradhāna were assumed to be the seer on account of the activity of its parts, it would be referred to as the deity, because it is the subject of the chapter; and the living Self would not be spoken of as the deity

original: jīvo hi nāma cetanaḥ śarīrādhyakṣaḥ prāṇānāṃ dhārayitā /
analyzed: jīvaḥ hi nāma cetanaḥ śarīra adhyakṣaḥ prāṇānām dhārayitā
translated: For the so-called individual soul is the conscious ruler of the body, the supporter of the life-breaths.

analyzed: tad prasiddheḥ nirvacanāt ca
translated: This is known from the scriptures and can be inferred from the etymology of the word.

analyzed: sa katham acetanasya pradhānasya ātmā bhavet
translated: How can it be the Self of the non-conscious pradhāna?

analyzed: ātmā hi nāma svarūpam
translated: For the Self is the very nature of a thing.

original: nācetanasya pradhānasya cetano jīvaḥ svarūpaṃ bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: na acetanasya pradhānasya cetanaḥ jīvaḥ svarūpam bhavitum arhati
translated: The conscious individual soul cannot be the nature of the non-conscious pradhāna.

original: atha tu cetanaṃ brahma mukhyamīkṣitṛ parigṛhyate tasya jīvaviṣaya ātmaśabdaprayoga upapadyate /
analyzed: atha tu cetanam brahma mukhyam īkṣitṛ parigṛhyate tasya jīva viṣayaḥ ātma śabda prayogaḥ upapadyate
translated: But if the principal seer, the conscious Brahman, is accepted, then the use of the word Self in reference to the individual soul is justified.

original: tathā 'sa ya eṣo 'ṇimaitadātmyamidaṃ sarvaṃ tatsatyaṃ sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo' chāndo / / /
analyzed: tathā sa yaḥ eṣaḥ ṇimā etat ātmyam idam sarvam tat satyam saḥ ātmā tat tvam asi śvetaketo chāndaḥ
translated: Thus in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad (7.25.2), That which is the smallest of the small, the innermost of the inner, that is all this, that is true, that is the Self, that are you, Śvetaketu.

original: ityatra 'sa ātmā' iti prakṛtaṃ sadaṇimānamātmānamātmaśabdenopadiśya 'tattvamasi śvetaketo' iti cetanasya śvetaketorātmatvenopadiśati /
analyzed: iti atra saḥ ātmā iti prakṛtam sat aṇimānam ātmānam ātma śabdena upadiśya tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti cetanasya śvetaketoḥ ātma tvena upadiśati
translated: Here, the existent, the smallest, the Self, which is referred to as that is the Self, is taught as the Self by the word Self, and the conscious Śvetaketu is taught as the Self by the words that are you, Śvetaketu.

analyzed: ap tejasoḥ tu viṣaya tvāt acetana tvam
translated: As for water and fire, they are non-conscious because they are objects.

analyzed: nāma rūpa vyākaraṇa ādau ca prayojya tvena eva nirdeśāt
translated: And in the creation of name and form, they are referred to only as the instruments.

analyzed: na ca ātma śabda vat kiñcid mukhya tve kāraṇam asti iti yuktam kūla vat gauṇa tvam īkṣitṛ tvasya
translated: And there is no reason for taking the word 'self' in its primary sense, as there is for taking the word 'bank' in its primary sense. Therefore it is proper to take the word 'self' in its secondary sense.

analyzed: tayoḥ api ca sat adhiṣṭhita tva apekṣam eva īkṣitṛ tvam
translated: And the state of being a seer belongs to both the self and the not-self only in relation to being supported by the existent.

analyzed: sataḥ tu ātma śabdāt na gauṇam īkṣitṛ tvam iti uktam
translated: But the state of being a seer cannot be secondary in the case of the existent self, because of the word 'self'. This has been explained.

analyzed: atha ucyeta acetane pi pradhāne bhavati ātma abdaḥ
translated: Now it may be said that the word 'self' is used even in relation to the non-sentient pradhāna.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ sarva artha kāri tvāt
translated: Because the self is the cause of all things.

original: yathā rājñaḥ sarvārthakāriṇi bhṛtye bhavatyātmaśabdo mamātmā bhadrasena iti /
analyzed: yathā rājñaḥ sarva artha kāriṇi bhṛtye bhavati ātma śabdaḥ mama ātmā bhadrasenaḥ iti
translated: Just as the word 'self' is used in relation to a servant who does all things for the king, as in 'Bhadrasena is my self'.

analyzed: pradhānam hi puruṣasya ātmanaḥ bhoga apavargau kurvat upakaroti
translated: For the pradhāna, acting as it does, is of service to the self, the puruṣa, in bringing about enjoyment and liberation.

analyzed: rājñaḥ iva bhṛtyaḥ saṃdhi vigraha ādiṣu vartamānaḥ
translated: Just as a servant engaged in making peace and war, etc. is of service to a king.

analyzed: athavā ekaḥ eva ātma śabdaḥ cetana acetana viṣayaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Or else, the word 'self' may refer to both the sentient and the non-sentient.

analyzed: bhūtātmā indriyātmā iti ca prayoga darśanāt
translated: Because we find usage like 'the self of beings', 'the self of the senses'.

analyzed: yathā ekaḥ eva jyotiḥ śabdaḥ kratu jvalana viṣayaḥ
translated: Just as the word 'light' refers to both the sacrifice and the burning [object].

analyzed: tatra kutas etad ātma śabdāt īkṣateḥ agauṇa tvam iti atas uttaram paṭhati
translated: Here, how is it known that the word 'self' in 'the self beholds' is not secondary? In response, he says:

original: FN / anena pūrvasṛṣṭyanubhūtena prāṇadhṛtihetunāmātmanā sadrūpeṇa yathoktā devatāḥ sargānantaraṃ praviśya nāma rūpaṃ ceti vispaṣṭamāsamantātkaravāṇīti
analyzed: anena pūrva sṛṣṭi anubhū prāṇa dhṛti hetunā ātman sat rūpeṇa yathā ukta devatāḥ sarga anantaram praviśya nāma rūpam ca iti vispaṣṭam ā samantāt karavāṇi iti
translated: By this Self, which is the cause of the sustenance of life experienced in the previous creation, in its real form, the deities mentioned, having entered after the creation, will clearly make all around the name and form.

analyzed: parā devatā īkṣitavatī iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the supreme deity has looked upon them.

analyzed: kūlasya guṇa vṛttyā pipatiṣā vat yuktam ap tejasoḥ gauṇam īkṣitṛ tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: The secondary seeing of water and fire is appropriate like a bank desiring to fall. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tad niṣṭhasya mokṣa upadeśāt
translated: Because liberation is taught for one who is established in that.

analyzed: na pradhānam acetanam ātma śabda ālambanam bhavitum arhati
translated: The non-intelligent pradhāna cannot be the basis of the word ātman.

original: 'sa ātmā' iti prakṛtaṃ sadaṇimānamādāya 'tattvamasi śvetaketo' iti cetanasya śvetaketormokṣayitavyasya
analyzed: saḥ ātmā iti prakṛtam sat aṇimānam ādāya tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti cetanasya śvetaketoḥ mokṣayitavyasya
translated: Taking up the existent, which is the subject, as the one without measure, and teaching the one who is to be liberated, the conscious Śvetaketu, as being based on that, with the words That thou art, O Śvetaketu,

original: tanniṣṭhamupadiśya 'ācāryavānpuruṣo veda' 'tasya tāvadeva ciraṃ yāvanna vimokṣye
analyzed: tad niṣṭham upadiśya ācāryavān puruṣaḥ veda tasya tāvat eva ciram yāvat na vimokṣye
translated: and teaching liberation with the words A person who has a teacher knows; for him it is a long time only until he is liberated from this bondage of truth by good conduct and knowledge.

analyzed: tha saṃpatsye chāndaḥ
translated: Then he will be united with Brahman, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.14.2

analyzed: iti mokṣa upadeśāt
translated: because of the teaching of liberation.

original: yadi hyacetanaṃ pradhānaṃ sacchabdavācyaṃ tadasīti grāhayenmumukṣuṃ cetanaṃ santamacetano 'sīti tadā viparītavādī śāstraṃ puruṣasyānarthāyetyapramāṇaṃ
analyzed: yadi hi acetanam pradhānam sat śabda vācyam tat asi iti grāhayet mumukṣum cetanam santam acetana u si iti tadā viparīta vādī śāstram puruṣasya anarthāya iti apramāṇam
translated: For if the nonintelligent pradhāna, which is denoted by the word Sat, were taught to the intelligent man who is desirous of release as being the Self, then the sacred text would be a teacher of what is contrary to the truth, and would thus be a source of evil to man, and therefore not a means of right knowledge

analyzed: syāt
translated: It would be so.

analyzed: na tu śāstram apramāṇam kalpayitum yuktam
translated: But it is not proper to assume that a sacred text which is free from all defects is not a means of right knowledge.

original: yadi cājñasya sato mumukṣoracetanamanātmānamātmetyupadiśetpramāṇabhūtaṃ śāstraṃ sa śraddhadhānatayāndhagolāṅgūlanyāyena tadātmadṛṣṭiṃ na parityajet /
analyzed: yadi ca ajñasya sataḥ mumukṣoḥ acetanam anātmānam ātmā iti upadiśet pramāṇa bhūtam śāstram sa tad ātma dṛṣṭim na parityajet
translated: And if the sacred text, which is a means of right knowledge, were to teach to a man who is desirous of release but is ignorant of the truth, that which is nonintelligent and not the Self is the Self, then the man, being full of faith, would not abandon that view of the Self, just as a blind man or a monkey would not abandon their hold of a snake;

analyzed: tad vyatiriktam ca ātmānam na pratipadyeta
translated: and he would not understand the Self to be different from that.

analyzed: tathā sati puruṣa arthāt vihanyeta anartham na ṛcchet
translated: If that were so, he would be deprived of the object of man’s life, and would fall into a pit of evil.

original: tasmādyathā svargādyarthino 'gnihotrādisādhanaṃ yathābhūtamupadiśati tathā mumukṣorapi 'sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo' iti yathābhūtamevātmānamupaduśatīti
analyzed: tasmāt yathā svarga ādi arthinaḥ gnihotra ādi sādhanam yathābhūtam upadiśati tathā mumukṣoḥ api saḥ ātmā tat tvam asi śvetaketo iti yathābhūtam eva ātmānam upaduśati iti
translated: Therefore, just as the sacred text teaches to a man who is desirous of heaven the means of attaining heaven, such as the agnihotra, etc., in a manner that is in accordance with the truth, so also it teaches to a man who is desirous of release the truth about the Self, in such passages as ‘That is the Self; thou art that, Śvetaketu’ (Ch.

analyzed: yuktam
translated: This is proper.

original: evañca sati taptaparaśugrahaṇamokṣadṛṣṭāntena satyābhisandhasya mokṣopadeśa upapadyate /
analyzed: evam ca sati tapta paraśu grahaṇa mokṣa dṛṣṭāntena satya abhisandhasya mokṣa upadeśaḥ upapadyate
translated: And if this is so, then the teaching of release to one who is intent on truth is proper by means of the illustration of the burning axe, and the release of the man who was desirous of release.
