original: anyathā hyamukhye sadātmatattvopadeśe 'ahamukthamasmīti vidyāt' ai / āra / / / /
analyzed: anyathā hi amukhye sat ātma tattva upadeśe aham uktham asmi iti vidyāt
translated: Otherwise, if the teaching of the truth of the Self were not primary, then the statement One should know 'I am the Udgītha' (Ch. 1.1.1) would be meaningless.

analyzed: itivat saṃpad mātram idam anitya phalam syāt
translated: Otherwise, if the teaching of the truth of the Self were not primary, this would be merely a fruitful result like the statement, One should know that I am the Udgītha (Ch. 1.1.1).

analyzed: tatra mokṣa upadeśaḥ na upapadyeta
translated: There, the teaching of liberation would not be appropriate.

analyzed: tasmāt na sat aṇimani ātma śabdasya gauṇa tvam
translated: Therefore, the word Self does not have a secondary meaning other than the existent.

original: bhṛtye tu svāmibhṛtyabhedasya pratyakṣatvādupapanno gauṇa ātmaśabdo mamātmā bhadrasena iti /
analyzed: bhṛtye tu svāmi bhṛtya bhedasya pratyakṣa tvāt upapannaḥ gauṇaḥ ātma śabdaḥ mama ātmā bhadrasenaḥ iti
translated: But in the case of a servant, the word Self is appropriately used in a secondary sense as Bhadra-sena is my Self, because the difference between master and servant is directly perceived.

original: apica Dvacidgauṇaḥ śabdo dṛṣṭa iti naitāvatā śabdapramāṇaker'tho gauṇī kalpanā nyāyyā /
analyzed: apica dvacid gauṇaḥ śabdaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti na etāvatā śabda pramāṇakā irthaḥ gauṇī kalpanā nyāyyā
translated: Moreover, just because a word is seen to be used secondarily in some cases, it is not proper to assume that the meaning of a word whose authority is based on the Veda is secondary.

analyzed: sarvatra anāśvāsa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because that would lead to a lack of confidence in everything.

original: yattūktaṃ cetanācetanayoḥ sādhāraṇa ātmābdaḥ kratujvalanayoriva jyotiḥśabda iti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam cetana acetanayoḥ sādhāraṇaḥ ātma abdaḥ kratu jvalanayoḥ iva jyotiḥ śabdaḥ iti
translated: As for the argument that the word Self is common to the conscious and the insentient, like the word light is to the sacrificial altar and the fire,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: aneka artha tvāt asya anyāyya tvāt
translated: Because it is not proper for a word to have multiple meanings.

original: tasmāccetanaviṣaya eva mukhya ātmaśabdaścetanatvopacārādbhūtādiṣu prayujyate bhūtātmendriyātmeti ca /
analyzed: tasmāt cetana viṣayaḥ eva mukhyaḥ ātma śabdaḥ cetana tva upacārāt bhūta ādiṣu prayujyate bhūtātmā indriyātmā iti ca
translated: Therefore, the word Self primarily refers to the conscious being, and is used figuratively in relation to the elements etc. as the Self of the elements and the Self of the senses, due to their having consciousness.

original: sādhāraṇatve 'pyātmaśabdasya na prakaraṇamupapadaṃ vā kiñcinniścāyakamantareṇānyataravṛttitā nirdhārayituṃ śakyate /
analyzed: sādhāraṇa tve pi ātma śabdasya na prakaraṇam upapadam vā kiñcid niścāyakam antareṇa anyatara vṛtti tā nirdhārayitum śakyate
translated: Although the word ‘ātman’ is common to both, yet, in the absence of any such determining factor as the context or the proximity of other words, it cannot be ascertained to which one of the two it belongs.

analyzed: na ca atra acetanasya niścāyakam kiñcid kāraṇam asti
translated: And there is no reason here to determine the word to mean the nonintelligent.

analyzed: prakṛtam tu sa dīkṣitṛ
translated: The person who is the subject of the chapter is the intelligent one,

original: saṃnihitaścetanaḥ śvetaketuḥ nahi cetanasya śvetaketoracetana ātmā saṃbhavatītyavocāma /
analyzed: saṃnihitaḥ cetanaḥ śvetaketuḥ nahi cetanasya śvetaketoḥ acetanaḥ ātmā saṃbhavati iti avocāma
translated: and Śvetaketu, who is mentioned in the proximity of the passage, is also an intelligent person; and we have already shown that the soul of the intelligent Śvetaketu cannot be the nonintelligent pradhāna.

analyzed: tasmāt cetana viṣayaḥ iha ātma śabdaḥ iti niścīyate
translated: Therefore it is ascertained that the word ‘ātman’ here refers to an intelligent being.

original: jyotiḥśabdo 'pi laukikena prayogeṇa jvalana eva rūḍhor'thavādakalpitena tu jvalanasādṛśyena kratau pravṛtta ityadṛṣṭāntaḥ /
analyzed: jyotiḥ śabdaḥ pi laukikena prayogeṇa jvalanaḥ eva rūḍha arthavāda kalpitena tu jvalana sādṛśyena kratau pravṛttaḥ iti adṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: As for the word ‘jyotiḥ’, it is well known to denote fire in ordinary parlance; but in the passage under discussion it is used figuratively, on account of the similarity of light, in the sense of the sacrifice. Hence it cannot serve as an instance.

original: athavā pūrvasūtra evātmaśabdaṃ nirastasamastagauṇatvasādhāraṇatvaśaṅkatayā vyākhyāya tataḥ svatantra eva pradhānakāraṇanirākaraṇaheturvyākhyeyaḥ
analyzed: athavā pūrva sūtre eva ātma śabdam nirasta samasta gauṇatva sādhāraṇa tva śaṅkatayā vyākhyāya tatas svatantraḥ eva pradhāna kāraṇa nirākaraṇa hetuḥ vyākhyeyaḥ  /
translated: Or, the word ‘ātman’ may be explained in the previous aphorism, by removing all doubts as to its meaning a nonintelligent principle or a principle common to all, and then the next aphorism may be explained as the reason for the rejection of the pradhāna as the cause of the world.

analyzed: tad niṣṭhasya mokṣa upadeśāt iti
translated: ‘Because final release is taught to be dependent on that.’

analyzed: tasmāt na acetanam pradhānam sat śabda vācyam  /
translated: Therefore the nonintelligent pradhāna cannot be denoted by the word ‘sat’.

analyzed: atra uttama puruṣaḥ tu ubhayatra prathama puruṣe chāndasa vat
translated: Here the optative mood is used in both places, as in the Vedic language.

original: tadā cetanaṃ santaṃ mumukṣumacetano 'sītibruvacchāstraṃ viparītavādibhūtvā puṃso 'narthāyetikṛtvā syādapramāṇamiti yojanā /
analyzed: tadā cetanam santam mumukṣum acetano si iti bruvat śāstram viparīta vādi bhūtvā puṃsaḥ narthāya iti kṛtvā syāt apramāṇam iti yojanā
translated: Then, the scripture, by saying that the conscious one who desires liberation is unconscious, becomes a speaker of contradictions and would be a non-authority for the purpose of the man's misfortune, thus is the construction.

analyzed: atra vihatiḥ mukti bhāj tva abhāvaḥ
translated: Here, the obstruction is the absence of being a candidate for liberation.

original: 'yathā satyābhisaṃdhastaptaṃ paraśuṃ sa na dahyate 'tha mucyate' iti /
analyzed: yathā satya abhisaṃdhaḥ taptam paraśum sa na dahyate mucyate iti
translated: As it is said, Just as one who has a true intention is not burned by a heated axe, then he is liberated.

analyzed: uktham prāṇaḥ
translated: The Uktha is the breath.

analyzed: mahā vākya uttham jñānam idam ucyate
translated: This knowledge arising from the great statement is said to be that.

analyzed: kutas ca na pradhānam sat śabda vācyam
translated: And why is the pradhāna not denoted by the word Sat?

original: heyatvāvacanācca / / / /🔽yadyānātmaiva pradhānaṃ sacchabdavācyaṃ 'sa ātmā tattvamasi' itīhopadiṣṭaṃ syātsa
analyzed: heya tva avacanāt ca  yadi an ātmā eva pradhānam sat śabda vācyam saḥ ātmā tattvam asi iti iha upadiṣṭam syāt sa
translated: And because of the non-mention of its being an object of desire.🔽If the non-Self alone, the pradhāna, were denoted by the word Sat and were taught here in 'That is the Self, that is Thou', then

original: tadupadeśaśravaṇādanātmajñatayā tanniṣṭho mā bhūditi mukhyamātmānamupadidikṣustasya heyatvaṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: tad upadeśa śravaṇāt anātma jña tayā tad niṣṭhaḥ mā bhūt iti mukhyam ātmānam upadidikṣuḥ tasya heya tvam brūyāt
translated: the teacher, desiring to teach the primary Self, would speak of its being an object of desire, in order that one might not be devoted to it by knowing it as non-Self, by hearing the teaching of that.

original: yathārundhatīṃ didarśayiṣustatsamīpasthāṃ sthūlāṃ tārāmamukhyāṃ prathamamarundhatiti grāhayitvā tāṃ pratyākhyāya paścādarundhatīmeva grāhayati
analyzed: yathā arundhatīm didarśayiṣuḥ tad samīpa sthām sthūlām tārām amukhyām prathamam arundhatī iti grāhayitvā tām pratyākhyāya paścāt arundhatīm eva grāhayati
translated: Just as one who wishes to point out Arundhati, first, having made him understand the principal star near it, which is gross, as Arundhati, and having rejected that, afterwards makes him understand Arundhati itself.

analyzed: tadvat na ayam ātmā iti brūyāt
translated: In the same way, one should say, 'This Self is not so.'

analyzed: na ca evam avocat
translated: But he did not say so.

analyzed: sanmātra ātma avagati niṣṭhā eva hi ṣaṣṭha prapāṭhaka parisamāptiḥ dṛśyate
translated: For the conclusion of the sixth section is seen to be the realization of the Self as mere existence.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ  pratijñā virodhāt
translated: The word 'ca' (and)🔽is used to show the contradiction with the thesis.
The word 'ca' (and) is used to show the contradiction with the thesis.

analyzed: sati api heya tva vacane pratijñā virodhaḥ prasajyeta
translated: Even if the word 'should be abandoned' is used, there would be a contradiction with the thesis.

analyzed: kāraṇa vijñānāt hi sarvam vijñātam iti pratijñātam
translated: For it has been asserted that everything is known through the knowledge of the cause.

original: 'uta tamādeśamaprākṣyo yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñātaṃ vijñātamiti
analyzed: uta tam ādeśam aprākṣyaḥ yena a śrutam śrutam bhavati a matam matam a vijñātam vijñātam iti
translated: 'Or, if you ask about that instruction by which the unheard becomes heard, the unknown known, and the unseen seen,

original: kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ
analyzed: katham nu bhagavaḥ saḥ ādeśaḥ bhavati iti yathā somya ekena mṛd piṇḍena sarvam mṛd mayam
translated: how then, O revered one, is that instruction?' 'Just as, my dear, by one clod of clay everything made of clay is known,

original: vijñātaṃ syādvācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyam' /
analyzed: vijñātam syāt vācā ārambhaṇam vikāraḥ nāmadheyam mṛttikā iti eva satyam
translated: the modification is a mere verbal expression, the name is a mere designation, only clay is the truth.'

analyzed: evam somya saḥ ādeśaḥ bhavati chāndaḥ
translated: ‘Thus, my dear, is that instruction’ (Chānd. Up. 6.8.3).

analyzed: iti vākya upakrame śravaṇāt
translated: Because this is stated in the beginning of the passage.

original: naca sacchabdavācye pradhāne bhogyavargakāraṇe heyatvenāheyatvena vā vijñāte bhoktṛvargo vijñāto bhavati /
analyzed: na ca sat śabda vācye pradhāne bhogya varga kāraṇe heya tvena aheya tvena vā vijñāte bhoktṛ vargaḥ vijñātaḥ bhavati
translated: And when the pradhāna, which is denoted by the word ‘Sat’, and is the cause of the aggregate of objects of enjoyment, is known either as something to be relinquished or as something not to be relinquished, the aggregate of enjoyers is not known.

analyzed: a pradhāna vikāra tvāt bhoktṛ vargasya
translated: Because the aggregate of enjoyers is not a modification of the pradhāna.

analyzed: tasmāt na pradhānam sat śabda vācyam
translated: Therefore, the pradhāna is not denoted by the word ‘Sat’.

analyzed: kutas ca na pradhānam sat śabda vācyam
translated: And for what other reason is the pradhāna not denoted by the word ‘Sat’?

analyzed: he śvetaketo
translated: O Śvetaketu!

original: uta api ādisyata ityādeśastaṃ śāstrācāryoktigamyaṃ vastvaprākṣyaḥ pṛṣṭavānasyācāryam /
analyzed: uta api iti ādeśaḥ tam śāstra ācārya ukti gamyam vastu aprākṣyaḥ pṛṣṭavān asi ācāryam
translated: The instruction is that which is to be learnt. You have asked the teacher about that reality which is to be known through the words of the scriptures and the teacher.

original: vācārabhyamāṇamuccāryamāṇaṃ nāmadheyameva vikāro na tu ghaṭaśarāvādināmātirikto mṛdi vikāro vastuto 'sti paramārthato mṛttikaiva tu satyaṃ
analyzed: vācā ārabhyamāṇam uccāryamāṇam nāmadheyam eva vikāraḥ na tu ghaṭa śarāva ādi nāma atiriktaḥ mṛdi vikāraḥ sti paramārthataḥ mṛttikā eva tu satyam
translated: The name that is being uttered is indeed a modification, but apart from the names of the pot, dish, etc., there is no modification in clay in reality. In the highest sense, clay alone is the truth.

analyzed: sva apyayāt
translated: Because of its being absorbed into the Self.

original: tadeva sacchabdavācyaṃ kāraṇaṃ prakṛtya śrūyate 'yatraitatpuruṣaḥ svapiti nāma satā
analyzed: tat eva sat śabda vācyam kāraṇam prakṛtya śrūyate yatra etat puruṣaḥ svapiti nāma satā
translated: With reference to that very cause denoted by the word ‘Sat’, it is heard: ‘When this person sleeps, it is with that Self that he worships, for the name is “he sleeps”’ (Chānd. Up. 6.8.3).

original: somya tadā saṃpanno bhavati svamapīto bhavati tasmādenaṃ svapitītyācakṣate svaṃ hyapīto
analyzed: somya tadā saṃpannaḥ bhavati svam api itas bhavati tasmāt enam svapiti iti ācakṣate svam hi api itas
translated: Then, my dear, he becomes complete, he becomes gone to his own. Therefore they say of him, 'He sleeps,' for he has gone to his own.

analyzed: bhavati chāndaḥ iti
translated: This is the Vedic text.

original: eṣā śrutiḥ svapitītyetatpuruṣasya lokaprasiddhaṃ nāma nirvakti /
analyzed: eṣā śrutiḥ svapiti iti etat puruṣasya loka prasiddham nāma nirvakti
translated: This Vedic text explains the well-known name 'sleeping' of the person.

analyzed: sva śabdena iha ātmā ucyate
translated: The word 'own' here denotes the Self.

analyzed: yaḥ prakṛtaḥ sat śabda vācyaḥ tam apītaḥ bhavati apigataḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: He becomes gone to that which is the subject, denoted by the word 'that' (in the text). The meaning is: he becomes gone to.

analyzed: api pūrvasya eteḥ larya artha tvam prasiddham
translated: The prefix 'a' (in 'api') has the sense of 'l' (in 'ete').

analyzed: prabhava apyayau iti utpatti pralayayoḥ prayoga darśanāt
translated: This is well known. The usage 'prabhava-apya' (origination-dissolution) is seen in reference to origination and dissolution.

analyzed: manaḥ pracāra upādhi viśeṣa saṃbandhāt indriyārthān gṛhyan tad viśeṣa āpannaḥ jīvaḥ jāgarti
translated: The individual soul, which is associated with the specific limiting conditions of the functioning of the mind, perceives the objects of the senses and becomes endowed with those specific qualities while awake.

analyzed: tad vāsanā viśiṣṭaḥ svapnān paśyanmanaḥ śabda vācyaḥ bhavati
translated: Endowed with the impressions of that, he sees dreams and becomes denoted by the word 'mind.'

original: sa upādhidvayoparame suṣuptāvasthāmupādhikṛtaviśeṣābhāvātsvātmani pralīna iveti 'svaṃ hyapīto bhavati' ityucyate /
analyzed: saḥ upādhi dvaya uparame suṣupta avasthām upādhi kṛta viśeṣa abhāvāt sva ātmani pralīnaḥ iva iti svam hi api itas bhavati iti ucyate
translated: When those two limiting conditions cease, in the state of deep sleep, due to the absence of the specific qualities created by the limiting conditions, he is said to be 'gone to his own,' as if merged in his own Self.

original: yathā hṛdayaśabdanirvacanaṃ śrutvā darśitam 'sa vā eṣa ātmā hṛdi tasyaitadeva niruktaṃ hṛdyayamiti tasmādhṛdayamiti' chāndo / / / iti /
analyzed: yathā hṛdaya śabda nirvacanam śrutvā darśitam sa vai eṣaḥ ātmā hṛdi tasya etat eva niruktam hṛdi ayam iti tasmāt hṛdayam iti chāndaḥ iti
translated: As, for instance, the explanation of the word hṛdaya, heart, shows that the Self is the object of the word hṛdaya, For that Self is the heart; the explanation of the word hṛdaya is this, that it is so called because all the gods have their abode in it; therefore it is called hṛdaya Ch Up , , i;

original: yathāvāśanāyodanyāśabdapravṛttimūlaṃ darśayati śrutiḥ 'āpa eva tadaśitaṃ nayante' 'teja eva tatpītaṃ nayante' chā / / / / iti ca /
analyzed: yathāvā aśanāya udanyā śabda pravṛtti mūlam darśayati śrutiḥ āpaḥ eva tat aśitam nayante tejaḥ eva tat pītam nayante chā
translated: or as the text shows the ground of the use of the word food in the sense of something different from food, Water carries it when eaten, fire carries it when drunk Bṛ Up , , 0;

original: evaṃ svamātmānaṃ sacchabdavācyamapīto bhavatītīmamarthaṃ svapitināmanirvacanena darśayati /
analyzed: evam svam ātmānam sat śabda vācyam apītaḥ bhavati iti imam artham svapiti nāma nirvacanena darśayati
translated: in the same way the text shows by the explanation of the word sleep that the Self which is denoted by the word Sat becomes absorbed in itself.

original: naca cetana ātmācetanaṃ pradhānaṃ svarūpatvena pratipadyeta /
analyzed: na ca cetanaḥ ātmā acetanam pradhānam sva rūpa tvena pratipadyeta
translated: And the intelligent Self cannot assume as its own nature the nonintelligent pradhāna.

analyzed: yadi punar pradhānam eva ātmīyātvāt svā śabdena eva ucyeta
translated: If, on the other hand, the pradhāna only is called its own Self because it belongs to it, and is therefore denoted by the word svam, its own;

original: evamapi cetano 'cetanamapyetīti viruddhamāpadyeta /🔽śrutyantaraṃ ca 'prājñenātmanā saṃpariṣvakto na bāhyaṃ kiñcana veda nāntaram' /
analyzed: evam api cetano cetanam apyeti iti viruddham āpadyeta  śruti antaram ca prājñena ātmanā saṃpariṣvaktaḥ na bāhyam kiñcana veda na antaram
translated: then it would follow that the intelligent Self becomes absorbed in the nonintelligent pradhāna, which is absurd.

analyzed: bṛhaḥ iti suṣupta avasthāyām cetane darśayati
translated: Another scriptural passage also declares that in the state of deep sleep the Self becomes absorbed in itself, although it is intelligent, Being embraced by the intelligent Self, he knows nothing within nor without Bṛ Up , , 0.

original: ato yasminnapyayaḥ sarveṣāṃ cetanānāṃ taccetanaṃ sacchabdavācyaṃ jagataḥ kāraṇaṃ na pradhānam // //
analyzed: atas yasmin apyayaḥ sarveṣām cetanānām tat cetanam sat śabda vācyam jagataḥ kāraṇam na pradhānam
translated: Therefore, that into which all conscious beings merge is the cause of the world, not the pradhāna.

original: FN / yatra suptau puṃsaḥ svapitītyetannāma bhavati tadā puruṣaḥ satā saṃpannastenaikībhūta iti yojanā /
analyzed: yatra suptau puṃsaḥ svapiti iti etat nāma bhavati tadā puruṣaḥ satā saṃpannaḥ tena ekībhūtaḥ iti yojanā
translated: The meaning of the passage is: when a person is asleep and has the name of 'sleeping', then the person is united with the existent, having become one with it.

analyzed: kutas ca na pradhānam jagataḥ kāraṇam
translated: And why is not the pradhāna the cause of the world?

analyzed: gati sāmānyāt
translated: Because of the uniformity of the account.

original: yadi tārkikasamaya iva vedānteṣvapi bhinnā kāraṇāvagatirabhaviṣyatkvaciccetanaṃ brahma jagataḥ kāraṇaṃ Dvacidanyadeveti /
analyzed: yadi tārkika samaye iva vedānteṣu api bhinnā kāraṇa avagatiḥ abhaviṣyat kvacid cetanam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam
translated: If, as in the doctrines of the logicians, there were a different account of the cause in different Vedānta texts, in some places Brahman, the conscious, being the cause of the world, and in some other places something else,

analyzed: tatas kadācid pradhāna kāraṇa vāda anurodhena api īkṣati ādi śravaṇam akalpayiṣyat
translated: then we might have assumed that the passages about the 'Iśvara' and so on are meant to conform to the doctrine of the pradhāna being the cause.

analyzed: na tu etat asti
translated: But this is not the case.

original: samānaiva hi sarveṣu vedānteṣu cetanakāraṇāvagatiḥ /🔽'yathāgnerjvalataḥ sarvā diśo visphuliṅgā vipratiṣṭherannevamevaitasmādātmanaḥ sarve prāṇā yathāyatanaṃ vipratiṣṭhante prāṇebhyo devā devebhyo
analyzed: samānā eva hi sarveṣu vedānteṣu cetana kāraṇa avagatiḥ  yathā agneḥ jvalataḥ sarvāḥ diśaḥ visphuliṅgāḥ vipratiṣṭheran evam eva etasmāt ātmanaḥ sarve prāṇāḥ yathāyatanam vipratiṣṭhante prāṇebhyaḥ devāḥ devebhyaḥ
translated: For the account of the cause is the same in all the Vedānta texts, namely, that it is conscious.

analyzed: lokāḥ kau iti
translated: 'Just as sparks fly off a burning mass of iron in all directions, so do all the vital breaths go forth from this Self to their respective seats. From the vital breaths the gods, from the gods the worlds' (Kaṭha. 1. 2. 21).

analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ iti
translated: From that Self, indeed, space was produced (Tai. 2.1).🔽

analyzed: ātmataḥ eva idam sarvam chāndaḥ iti
translated: All this is verily from the Self (Ch. 7.25.2).

analyzed: ātmanaḥ eṣa prāṇaḥ jāyate pra
translated: From the Self, indeed, this life is born (Pra. 6.5).

original: iti cātmanaḥ kāraṇatvaṃ darśayanti sarve vedāntāḥ /
analyzed: iti ca ātmanaḥ kāraṇa tvam darśayanti sarve vedāntāḥ
translated: Thus all the Vedanta texts show that the Self is the cause.

analyzed: ātma śabdaḥ ca cetana vacanaḥ iti avocāma
translated: And we have said that the word Self denotes the conscious being.

analyzed: mahat ca prāmāṇya kāraṇam etat yat vedānta vākyānām cetana kāraṇa tve samāna gati tvam
translated: And this is a great reason for the authoritativeness of the Vedanta statements, that they have the same purport in regard to the conscious being as the cause.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādīnām iva rūpa ādiṣu
translated: Like the eye, etc. in regard to form, etc.

analyzed: atas gati sāmānyāt sarvajñam brahma jagataḥ kāraṇam  /
translated: Therefore, by the sameness of purport, the omniscient Brahman is the cause of the world.

analyzed: gatiḥ avagatiḥ

translated: For in the passage, ‘From that Self sprang ether,’ the word ‘Self’ is in the masculine gender, and Brahman is the subject.

analyzed: na ca iha sa viśeṣam brahma pratipipādayiṣitam

analyzed: vāc manasa gocara atikrama śruteḥ

original: pucchaśabdādavayavatveneti prāpta ucyate 'ānandamayo 'bhyāsāt' ānandamaya ātmetyatra 'brahma pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā' iti svapradhānameva brahmopadiśyate /

analyzed: puccham iti avayava śabdāt na svapradhāna tvam brahmaṇaḥ iti yat uktam

analyzed: tasya parihāraḥ vaktavyaḥ

analyzed: atra ucyate na ayam doṣaḥ

analyzed: prācuryāt api avayava śabda upapatteḥ

analyzed: prācuryam prāya āpattiḥ
translated: Abundance is preponderance.

analyzed: avayava prāye vacanam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the statement is mostly about parts.

original: annamayādīnāṃ hi śiraādiṣu pucchāntevavayaveḥṣūkte tvānandamayasyāpi śiraādīnyavayavāntarāṇyuktvāvayavaprāyāpattyā 'brahma pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā'
analyzed: anna maya ādīnām hi śiraḥ ādiṣu tu ānanda mayasya api śiraḥ ādīni avayava antarāṇi uktvā avayava prāya āpattyā brahma puccham pratiṣṭhā
translated: For the head etc. of the Self consisting of food etc. are mentioned as parts ending with the tail. Having mentioned the other parts such as the head of the Self consisting of bliss, by the preponderance of parts, Brahman is the tail, the support.

analyzed: na avayava vivakṣayā
translated: Not with the intention of mentioning a part.

analyzed: yatkāraṇam abhyāsāt iti svapradhāna tvam brahmaṇaḥ samarthitam  tad hetu vyapadeśāt ca
translated: The reason for this is stated in the Sūtra, ‘On account of the predominance of Brahman’ (Brahma-parimāṇatvāt).🔽And on account of the declaration of Brahman as the cause of that.

original: sarvasya vikārajātasya sānandamayasya kāraṇatvena brahma vyapadiśyate idaṃ sarvamasṛjata /
analyzed: sarvasya vikāra jātasya sa ānanda mayasya kāraṇa tvena brahma vyapadiśyate idam sarvam asṛjata

analyzed: yat idam kiñca te iti

translated: And it is not possible for Brahman, which is the cause, to be a part of the Ākāśa in the heart, which is its effect, in the primary sense of the term.

original: aparāṇyapi sūtrāṇi yathāsaṃbhavaṃ pucchavākyanirdiṣṭasyaiva brahmaṇa upapādakāni draṣṭavyāni // //
analyzed: aparāṇi api sūtrāṇi yathāsaṃbhavam puccha vākya nirdiṣṭasya eva brahmaṇaḥ upapādakāni draṣṭavyāni

translated: Not the Self, because it is superimposed along with the related sense-organs, and because it is not the effect of the five gross elements.

original: anirukte nikṛṣyocyanta iti niruktāni bhūtasūkṣmāṇi taiścābhedavarjite /🔽niḥśeṣalayasthānaṃ nilayanaṃ māyā tacchūnye /

original: udaramiti ut api aramalpam antaraṃ bhedam /

translated: For there is the following Smṛti passage, This illusion, O Nārada, has been created by me, by which thou seest me as possessed of all the qualities of created beings; do not, therefore, think of me as such Bṛ Up , , 0 Moreover, wherever the highest Lord is taught as being devoid of all distinctions, the sacred texts declare him to be of the nature of mere existence, as in the passage, He is without sound, without touch, without form, without decay Śve Up , 0 But, on the other hand, he is, on account of his being the cause of all, to be meditated upon as distinguished by certain qualities which are modifications of himself, as in the passage, He who is the work of all, the desire of all, the scent of all, the taste of all Ch Up , , 0 And so also the passages about the golden person, &c, will be explained Moreover, the pūrvapakṣin maintains, the passage about the abode shows that the highest Lord is not meant, because the abode is mentioned, and because the qualities of the embodied soul are mentioned, such as going, &c To this we reply that the teaching about a special abode of the highest Lord, although he rests on his own glory, has for its purpose the meditation on him, because Brahman, although allpervading like ether, may be spoken of as the inner Self of all, on account of the possibility of the distinction of adhyātma, adhibhūta, adhidaiva Moreover, the statement about the limits of his power has for its purpose the meditation on him, on account of the distinction of adhyātma, adhibhūta, adhidaiva

analyzed: tatra api tad liṅgāt prāṇa śabdam brahma eva

translated: That objection is not valid, we reply🔽For as it is clear from the complementary passage that the word prāṇa denotes Brahman, the mere fact of the prāṇa being mentioned together with the sun is of no avail

original: atra kecidudāharanti 'prāṇasya prāṇam' /🔽'prāṇabandhanaṃ hi somya manaḥ' iti ca /🔽tadayuktam /

original: śabdabhedātprakaraṇācca saṃśayānupapatteḥ /🔽yathā pituḥ piteti prayoge 'nyaḥ pitā ṣaṣṭīnirdiṣṭo 'nyaḥ prathamānirdiṣṭaḥ pituḥ piteti gamyate /

original: tadvat 'prāṇasya prāṇam' iti śabdabhedātprasiddhātprāṇādanyaḥ prāṇasya prāṇa iti niścīyate /🔽nahi sa eva tasyeti bhedanirdeśārhe bhavati /🔽yasya ca prakaraṇe yo nirdiśyate nāmāntareṇāpi sa eva tatra prakaraṇī nirdiṣṭa iti gamyate /

translated: For instance, when we say the father of the father, it is understood that the father mentioned by the genitive case is one, and the father mentioned by the nominative case is another; in the same way, on account of the difference of words, it is understood that the prāṇa of prāṇa is different from the wellknown prāṇa For the same cannot be the object of the genitive and the nominative case

translated: The whole world is one foot of it, three feet of it are the immortal in heaven Ch Up , ,

original: tatra yaccatuṣpādo brahmaṇastripādamṛtaṃ dyusaṃbandhirūpaṃ nirdiṣṭaṃ tadeveha dyusaṃbandhānnirdiṣṭamiti pratyabhijñāyate /
analyzed: tatra yat catuṣpādaḥ brahmaṇaḥ tripād amṛtam dyu saṃbandhi rūpam nirdiṣṭam tat eva iha dyu saṃbandhāt nirdiṣṭam iti pratyabhijñāyate
translated: Now, the Brahman consisting of four feet, of which three feet are the immortal connected with heaven, have been indicated in the preceding passage, and the same Brahman is indicated in the passage under discussion as connected with heaven; this is what we conclude from the recognition of the same thing in both passages

original: tatparityajya prākṛtaṃ jyotiḥ kalpayataḥ prakṛtahānāprakṛtaprakriye prasajyeyātām /
analyzed: tat parityajya prākṛtam jyotiḥ kalpayataḥ prakṛta hāna aprakṛta prakriye prasajyeyātām
translated: If, on the other hand, we should abandon the Brahman of the preceding passage and assume that the word light denotes the ordinary light, we should thereby abandon the subjectmatter of the preceding passage and introduce a new subjectmatter

analyzed: na kevalam pūrva vākyāt jyotiḥ vākye eva brahma anuvṛttiḥ
translated: Moreover, the Brahman is not only continued from the preceding passage into the passage about light,

analyzed: parasyām api śāṇḍilya vidyayām anuvartiṣyate brahma
translated: but it will be continued into the Śāṇḍilyavidyā also, which is a subsequent passage

analyzed: tasmāt iha jyotiḥ iti brahma pratipattavyam
translated: Hence we must conclude that the word light denotes Brahman

original: yattūktam 'jyotiradīpyate' iti caitau śabdau kārye jyotiṣi prasiddhāviti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam jyotiḥ adīpyate iti ca etau śabdau kārye jyotiṣi prasiddhau iti
translated: But it has been said that the words light and shines are well known to denote the created light!

analyzed: na ayam doṣaḥ
translated: This objection is without force,

analyzed: prakaraṇāt brahma avagame sati anayoḥ śabdayoḥ aviśeṣaka tvāt
translated: because, if Brahman is known from the general subjectmatter of the chapter, the two words do not denote anything else

original: dīpyamānakāryajyotirupalakṣite brahmaṇyapi prayogasaṃbhavāt /🔽'yena sūryastapati tejaseddhaḥ' tai /brā / / / /
analyzed: dīpyamāna kārya jyotiḥ upalakṣite brahmaṇi api prayoga saṃbhavāt  yena sūryaḥ tapati tejasā iddhaḥ taibrā
translated: Because the application is possible even to Brahman, which is characterized by the light of the function of the self-luminous effect.

analyzed: iti ca mantra varṇāt
translated: And from the text of the mantra, 'By which the sun shines, being impelled by that energy' (Tai. Br. 3.12.9.1).

analyzed: yat vā na ayam jyotiḥ śabdaḥ cakṣuḥ vṛtteḥ eva anugrāhake tejasi vartate
translated: Or this word 'light' does not refer only to the light that aids the function of the eye.

analyzed: anyatra api prayoga darśanāt
translated: Because it is seen to be used elsewhere.

analyzed: vācā eva ayam jyotiṣā āste bṛ
translated: 'By speech alone this light abides' (Tai. Br. 2.8.1.1).

analyzed: manaḥ jyotiḥ juṣatām taibrā
translated: 'May the light of the mind rejoice' (Tai. Br. 1.5.1.1).

analyzed: iti ca tasmāt yat yat kasyacid avabhāsakam tat tat jyotiḥ śabdena abhidhīyate
translated: Thus, whatever is the illuminator of something, that is denoted by the word 'light'.

original: tathā sati brahmaṇo 'pi caitanyarūpasya samastajagadavabhāsahetutvādupapanno jyotiḥśabdaḥ /
analyzed: tathā sati brahmaṇaḥ pi caitanya rūpasya samasta jagat avabhāsa hetu tvāt upapannaḥ jyotiḥ śabdaḥ
translated: When that is so, then the word 'light' is appropriate for Brahman also, which is of the nature of consciousness, because it is the cause of the illumination of the entire world.

original: 'tameva bhāntamanubhāti sarvaṃ tasya bhāsā sarvamidaṃ vibhāti' kau / / /
analyzed: tam eva sarvam tasya bhāsā sarvam idam vibhāti kau
translated: 'All this shines after Him who shines. By His light all this shines' (Ka. 6.2).

analyzed: tat devāḥ jyotiṣām jyotiḥ āyuḥ ha īpāsate mṛtam bṛ
translated: 'The gods worship that light of lights, the immortal life' (Tai. Br. 3.12.9.1).

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ ca
translated: And from such Vedic texts.

original: yadapyuktaṃ dyumaryādatvaṃ sarvagatasya brahmaṇo nopapadyata iti /
analyzed: yat api uktam dyu maryāda tvam sarva gatasya brahmaṇaḥ na upapadyate iti
translated: As for what was said - that the all-pervading Brahman cannot be limited by the sky -

analyzed: atrā ucyate sarva gatasya api brahmaṇaḥ upāsana arthaḥ pradeśa viśeṣa parigrahaḥ na virudhyate

original: nanuktaṃ niṣpradeśasya brahmaṇaḥ pradeśaviśeṣakalpanā nopapadyata iti /
analyzed: nanu uktam niṣpradeśasya brahmaṇaḥ pradeśa viśeṣa kalpanā na upapadyate iti
translated: But it has been said that the postulation of a particular place for Brahman, which is without parts, is not logically possible.

analyzed: na ayam doṣaḥ

analyzed: niṣpradeśasya api brahmaṇaḥ upādhi viśeṣa saṃbandhāt pradeśa viśeṣa kalpanā upapatteḥ  tathā hi ādityaḥ
translated: For even though Brahman is without parts, the postulation of particular places is logically possible because of its connection with particular limiting adjuncts.

analyzed: cakṣuṣi
translated: For thus it is heard: 'In the eye,'

analyzed: hṛdaye
translated: 'In the heart,'

analyzed: iti pradeśa viśeṣa saṃbandhāni brahmaṇaḥ upāsanāni śrūyante

analyzed: etena viśvatas pṛṣṭheṣu iti ādhāra bahutvam upapāditam
translated: By this also is explained the plurality of supports in 'on all sides of the back.'

analyzed: yat api etat uktam
translated: And as for what was said,

original: auṣṇyaghoṣānumite kaukṣeye kārye jyotiṣyadhyasyamānatvātparamapi divaḥ kāryaṃ jyotireveti /
analyzed: auṣṇya ghoṣa anumite kaukṣeye kārye jyotiṣi adhyasyamāna tvāt param api divaḥ kāryam jyotiḥ eva iti

analyzed: tat api ayuktam
translated: That also is not proper.

analyzed: parasya api nāma ādi pratīka tva tkaukṣeya jyotiṣpratīka tva upapatteḥ
translated: For just as Brahman is the symbol of name, etc., so it is logically possible that it is the symbol of the light in the cavity of the heart.

original: 'dṛṣṭaṃ ca śrutaṃ cetyupāsīta' iti tu pratīkadvārakaṃ dṛṣṭatvaṃ śrutatvaṃ ca bhaviṣyati /

analyzed: yat api alpa phala śravaṇāt na brahma iti  tat api anupapannam
translated: And the assertion that Brahman is not meant because the result mentioned is small, is also untenable.

analyzed: nahi iyate phalāya brahma āśrayaṇīyam
translated: For Brahman is not to be resorted to for the sake of a small result.

analyzed: iyate na iti niyama hetuḥ asti
translated: There is no reason for limiting it to this much.

analyzed: yatra hi nirasta sarva viśeṣa saṃbandham param brahma ātma tvena upadiśyate
translated: For where Brahman is taught as the Self, all connection with particular attributes being set aside,

analyzed: tatra eka rūpam eva phalam mokṣaḥ iti avagamyate
translated: there the one result is understood to be final release.

original: yatra tu guṇaviśeṣasaṃbandhaṃ pratīkaviśeṣasaṃbandhaṃ vā brahmopadiśyate /

translated: But where Brahman is taught as connected with particular attributes or as connected with particular symbols,

original: tatra saṃsāragocarāṇyevoccāvacāni phalāni dṛśyante 'annādo vasudāno vidante vasu ya evaṃ veda' bṛ / / /
analyzed: tatra saṃsāra gocarāṇi eva uccāvacāni phalāni dṛśyante anna ādaḥ vasu dānaḥ vidante vasu yaḥ evam veda

analyzed: ityādyāsu śrutiṣu
translated: and similar passages.

original: yadyapi na svavākye kiñcijjyotiṣo brahmaliṅgamasti tathāpi pūrvasminvākye dṛśyamānaṃ grahītavyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yadi api na sva vākye kiñcid jyotiṣaḥ brahma liṅgam asti tathā api pūrvasmin vākye dṛśyamānam grahītavyam bhavati
translated: Although in the passage itself there is no indication of Brahman in the word light, still the indication which is seen in the preceding passage must be accepted.🔽This has been declared by the author of the Sūtras, Ch Up , , 0, The light is Brahman on account of the mention of the feet.

original: taduktaṃ sūtrakāreṇa 'jyotiścaraṇābhidhānāt' iti kathaṃ punarvākyāntaragatena brahmasaṃnidhānena jyotiḥśrutiḥ svaviṣayācchakyā pracyāvayitum
analyzed: tat uktam sūtrakāreṇa jyotiścaraṇa abhidhānāt iti katham punar vākya antara gatena brahma saṃnidhānena jyotiḥ śrutiḥ sva viṣayāt śakyā pracyāvayitum
translated: But how can the word light be torn away from its own object and made to denote Brahman, on the ground of the proximity of Brahman in another passage?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This does not affect our position.

original: 'yadataḥ paro jyotiḥ' iti prathamatarapaṭhitena yacchabdena sarvanāmnā dyusaṃbnandhātpratyabhijñāyamāne
analyzed: yat atas paras jyotiḥ iti prathamatara paṭhitena yad śabdena sarvanāmnā dyu saṃbnandhāt pratyabhijñāyamāne
translated: The word yat, which is read first as yat param jyotih, by the pronoun tat, which is connected with the word dyauh, and which is recognized by the recognition of Brahman indicated in the previous sentence, is referred to by its own power.

original: pūrvavākyanirdiṣṭe brahmaṇi svasāmārthyena parāmṛṣṭe satyarthājjyotiḥśabdasyāpi brahmaviṣayatvopapatteḥ /
analyzed: pūrva vākya nirdiṣṭe brahmaṇi sva sāmārthyena parāmṛṣṭe sati arthāt jyotiḥ śabdasya api brahma viṣaya tva upapatteḥ

analyzed: tasmāt iha jyotiḥ iti brahma pratipattavyam
translated: Therefore, here Brahman should be understood as the Light.

analyzed: gāyatrī upādhi brahma upāsti anantaram upāsti antara ukti arthaḥ tha śabdaḥ

analyzed: atas dyu lokāt paras parastāt yat jyotiḥ dīpyate tat idam iti jāṭhare jyotiṣi adhyasyate

analyzed: viśvasmāt prāṇi vargāt sarvasmāt bhūḥ ādi lokāt ca pṛṣṭeṣu upari iti arthaḥ

analyzed: nahi iti rūpa ādimataḥ sa avayavasya eva dīpti yogāt iti arthaḥ

analyzed: yat tejaḥ bannābhyām asaṃpṛktam tat atri vat kṛtam ucyate
translated: The light that is not mixed with fire and food is said to be made like Atri.
The other purpose is the destruction of darkness and so on.

original: tāsāṃ tejobannānāmekaikaṃ dvidhā vibhajya punaścekaikaṃ bhāgaṃ dvedhā kṛtvā svabhāgāditarabhāgayornikṣipya trivṛtkaraṇaṃ saṃpadyate /
analyzed: tāsām tejaḥ bannānām ekaikam dvidhā vibhajya punar ca ekaikam bhāgam dvedhā kṛtvā sva bhāgāt itara bhāgayoḥ nikṣipya trivṛtkaraṇam saṃpadyate
translated: Having divided each of those three, fire, water and food, into two parts, and having placed each part in two other parts, the threefold division is accomplished.

analyzed: bhāginī yuktā
translated: Endowed with parts, connected.

original: ekatvasāmyādbhūrityasminnakṣare prajāpateḥ śirodṛṣṭiruktā tathātrāpi sārūpyaṃ vācyaṃ anyathādhyāsāsiddheḥ /
analyzed: eka tva sāmyāt bhūḥ iti asmin akṣare prajāpateḥ śiraḥ dṛṣṭiḥ uktā tathā atra api sārūpyam vācyam anyathā adhyāsa asiddheḥ
translated: Due to similarity with oneness, the eye of Prajapati is said to be seen in this syllable 'bhūḥ'. Similarly, here also, the similarity should be stated. Otherwise, superimposition is not established.

analyzed: eṣā dṛṣṭiḥ yat etat uṣṇimānam sparśena vijānāti
translated: This seeing is that which one perceives by touch in this body.

analyzed: eṣā śrutiḥ yat karṇau apidhāya ninadam iva śṛṇoti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: This hearing is that which one hears as if roaring by closing the ears. The rest is to be supplied.

analyzed: cakṣuṣyaḥ darśanīyaḥ
translated: Desirable to the eye, pleasing to the sight.

analyzed: śrutaḥ viśrutaḥ
translated: Famed, well-known.

analyzed: prākṛtam prakṛteḥ jātam
translated: Natural, born from nature.

original: kāryamiti yāvat /🔽brahmaṇo vyavacchidya tejaḥsamarpakatvaṃ viśeṣakatvaṃ tadabhāvo 'viśeṣakatvaṃ /
analyzed: kāryam iti yāvat  brahmaṇaḥ vyavacchidya tejaḥ samarpaka tvam viśeṣaka tvam tad abhāvaḥ viśeṣaka tvam
translated: That is, effect.🔽It is a distinguishing mark that points to fire, excluding Brahman. Non-distinguishing is the absence of that, i.e., the absence of distinguishing.

analyzed: aviśeṣaka tvāt brahma vyāvartaka tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because it does not exclude Brahman.

analyzed: pramiti artha tvena upāsti artha tvena vā maryādāvat tvam
translated: The limitedness is either for the purpose of cognition or for the purpose of worship.

analyzed: divaḥ param api iti anvayaḥ
translated: The continuation is: even beyond heaven.

original: kaukṣeyakaṃ hi jyotirjīvabhāvenānupraviṣṭasya paramātmano vikāraḥ jīvābhāve dehasya śaithilyāt jīvataścauṣṇyājjāyate /
analyzed: kaukṣeyakam hi jyotiḥ jīva bhāvena anupraviṣṭasya paramātmanaḥ vikāraḥ jīva abhāve dehasya śaithilyāt jīvataḥ ca auṣṇyāt jāyate
translated: The light in the eye is a modification of the supreme Self, which has entered into the state of the individual soul; it arises from the looseness of the body in the absence of the individual soul, and from the heat in the living state.

analyzed: tasmāt pratīka upāsanam upapannam
translated: Therefore, the meditation on the symbol is reasonable.

analyzed: jīva rūpeṇa annam atti iti annādaḥ
translated: He is the eater of food in the form of the individual soul.

analyzed: annasya a samantāt dātā vā
translated: Or he is the giver of food on all sides.

original: vasu hiraṇyaṃ karmaphalaṃ dadātīti vasudāna iti guṇaviśeṣasaṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: vasu hiraṇyam karma phalam dadāti iti vasudānaḥ iti guṇa viśeṣa saṃbandhaḥ
translated: He gives wealth, gold, the fruit of action, so he is the giver of wealth. This is the connection with specific qualities.

original: sarvanāmnā svasāmarthyena svasya sarvanāmnaḥ sāmartyaṃ saṃnihitavācitvaṃ tadbalena parāmṛṣṭe satīti yojanā /
analyzed: sarvanāmnā sva sāmarthyena svasya sarvanāmnaḥ sāmartyam saṃnihita vāci tvam tad balena parāmṛṣṭe sati iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: when the universal name is referred to by the power of its own inherent meaning, which is the power to denote what is present.

original: chando 'bhidhānān neti cen na tathā ceto'rpaṇanigadāt tathā hi darśanam / / / /
analyzed: chandaḥ abhidhānāt na iti ced na tathā cetaḥ ūrpaṇa nigadāt tathā hi darśanam
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of the mention of the meter, it is not so, because of the statement of the mind being directed thus, as is seen thus.

original: atha yaduktaṃ pūrvasminnapi vākye na brahmabhihitamiti /
analyzed: atha yat uktam pūrvasmin api vākye na brahma abhihitam iti
translated: Now, what was said earlier, that Brahman is not mentioned in the previous sentence,

original: 'gāyatrī vā idaṃ sarvaṃ bhūtaṃ yadidaṃ kiñca' chāṃ / / /
analyzed: gāyatrī vai idam sarvam bhūtam yat idam kiñca chāṃ
translated: This entire world, whatever there is, is indeed the Gayatri meter.

analyzed: iti gāyatrī ākhyasya chandasaḥ bhihita tvāt iti
translated: Because the meter called Gayatri is mentioned.

analyzed: tat parihartavyam
translated: That should be refuted.

analyzed: katham punar chandaḥ abhidhānāt na brahma abhihitam iti śakyate vaktum
translated: But how can it be said that Brahman is not mentioned because of the mention of the meter?

analyzed: yāvatā tāvān asya mahimā iti etasyām ṛci catuṣpād brahma darśitam

analyzed: na etat asti
translated: This is not so.

original: 'gāyatrī vā idaṃ sarvam' iti gāyatrīmupakramya tāmeva bhūtapṛthivīśarīrahṛdayavākyapramāṇabhedairvyakhyāya
analyzed: gāyatrī vai idam sarvam iti gāyatrīm upakramya tām eva bhūta pṛthivī śarīra hṛdaya vākya pramāṇa bhedaiḥ vyakhyāya
translated: Having begun with the Gāyatrī, This all is Gāyatrī, and having explained that Gāyatrī itself by the divisions of elements, earth, body, heart, speech, and means of knowledge,

original: 'saiṣā catuṣpādā ṣaḍvidhā gāyatrī tadetadṛcābhyanuktaṃ tāvānasya mahimā' iti tasyāmeva
analyzed: sā eṣā catuṣpādā ṣaḍvidhā gāyatrī tat etat ṛcā abhyanuktam tāvān asya mahimā iti tasyām eva
translated: and having said, This Gāyatrī is of four feet and six kinds, and this greatness of his is declared in this verse,

original: vyākhyātarūpāyāṃ gāyatryāmudāhṛto mantraḥ kathamakasmādbrahma catuṣpādabhidadhyāt /🔽yo 'pi tatra 'yadvai tadbrahma' chā / / / /🔽iti brahmaśabdaḥ so 'pi chandasaḥ prakṛtatvācchandoviṣaya eva 'ya etāmevaṃ brahmopaniṣadaṃ veda' chāṃ / /
analyzed: vyākhyāta rūpāyām gāyatryām udāhṛtaḥ mantraḥ katham akasmāt brahma catuṣpād abhidadhyāt  tatra yat vai tat brahma chā  iti brahma śabdaḥ saḥ u pi chandasaḥ prakṛta tvāt chandaḥ viṣayaḥ eva yaḥ etām evam brahma upaniṣadam veda chām
translated: how could the mantra quoted in that very Gāyatrī, whose form has been explained, suddenly refer to Brahman as having four feet?🔽And the word Brahman there, in the passage, What is that Brahman,🔽is also about the metre only, because the metre is the subject, in the passage, He who thus knows this Gāyatrī which is Brahman.

analyzed: iti atra hi veda upaniṣadam iti vyācakṣate
translated: For here they explain the word Brahman as referring to the Veda and the Upaniṣad.

analyzed: tasmāt chandaḥ abhidhānāt na brahmaṇaḥ prakṛta tvam iti ced
translated: Therefore, because it is mentioned as a metre, Brahman is not the subject.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: 'tathā cetorpaṇanigahāt' tathā gāyatryākhyacchandodvāreṇa tadanugate brahmaṇi cetasor'paṇaṃ cittasamādhānamanena brahmaṇavākyena nigadyate
analyzed: tathā cetaḥ ūrpaṇa nigahāt tathā gāyatrī ākhya chandaḥ dvāreṇa tad anugate brahmaṇi cetasā ūrpaṇam citta samādhānam anena nigadyate  /
translated: And so the fixing of the mind on Brahman, which is accompanied by the metre called Gāyatrī, is declared by this sentence about Brahman,

analyzed: gāyatrī vai idam sarvam iti
translated: 'Gāyatrī, verily, is all this' (Taitt. Up. 1.1.1).

analyzed: na hi akṣara saṃniveśa mātrāyāḥ gāyatryāḥ sarva ātmaka tvam saṃbhavati
translated: For it is not possible that Gāyatrī, which is merely a combination of syllables, is the Self of all.

analyzed: tasmāt yāt gāyatrī ākhya vikāre nugatam jagat kāraṇam brahma tat iha sarvam iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, here it is said that all this is Brahman, which is the cause of the world and is present in the modification called Gāyatrī,

analyzed: yathā sarvam khalu idam brahma chā iti
translated: just as in 'All this, verily, is Brahman' (Chānd. Up. 3.14.1).

original: kāryaṃ ca kāraṇādavyatiriktamiti vakṣyāmaḥ 'tadananyatvamārambhaṇaśabdādibhyaḥ' bra / / / ityatra /
analyzed: kāryam ca kāraṇāt avyatiriktam iti vakṣyāmaḥ tad ananyatvam ārambhaṇa śabda ādibhyaḥ iti atra
translated: And we shall explain that the effect is not separate from the cause, in the passage 'Because of the words beginning with arambhaṇa, etc.' (Brahmas. 1.1.11).

original: tathānyatrāpi vikāradvāreṇa brahmaṇa upāsanaṃ dṛśyate 'etaṃ hyeva bahvṛcā mahatyukthe mīmāṃsanta etamagnāvadhvaryava etaṃ mahāvrate chandogāḥ' 🔽ai /ā / / / iti /
analyzed: tathā anyatra api vikāra dvāreṇa brahmaṇaḥ upāsanam dṛśyate etam hi eva bahvṛcāḥ mahati ukthe mīmāṃsante etam agnau adhvaryavaḥ etam mahāvrate chandogāḥ  / aiā iti
translated: Similarly, elsewhere also the meditation on Brahman through its modifications is seen: 'For they investigate this very [Brahman] in the great hymn of the Bahvṛcas, in the fire in the Adhvaryus, in the great vow in the Chandogas' (Chānd. Up. 1.1.1).

analyzed: tasmāt asti chandaḥ abhidhāne pi pūrvasmin vākye catuṣpād brahma nirdiṣṭam
translated: Therefore, even in the designation of the metres, Brahman with four feet is indicated in the previous sentence.

analyzed: tat eva jyotiḥ vākye pi parāmṛśyate upāsana antara vidhānāya
translated: In the Jyotiṣṭoma passage also, that same Brahman is referred to for the purpose of enjoining another meditation.

original: apara āha sākṣādeva gāyatrīśabdena brahma pratipādyate /
analyzed: aparaḥ āha sākṣāt eva gāyatrī śabdena brahma pratipādyate
translated: Another says: The word gāyatrī directly denotes Brahman.

analyzed: saṃkhyā sāmānyāt
translated: Because of the similarity of number.

original: yathā gāyatrī catuṣpadā ṣaḍakṣaraiḥ pādaistathā brahma catuṣpāt /
analyzed: yathā gāyatrī catuṣpadā ṣaṣ akṣaraiḥ pādaiḥ tathā brahma catuṣpād
translated: Just as the gāyatrī has four feet with six syllables each, so Brahman has four feet.

analyzed: tathā anyatra api chandaḥ abhidhāyī śabdaḥ ūrtha antare saṃkhyā sāmānyāt prayujyamānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: And elsewhere also a word denoting a meter is seen to be used in another sense because of the similarity of number.

original: tadyathā 'te vā ete pañcānye pañcānye daśa santastatkṛtam' ityupakramyāha 'saiṣā virāḍannādi' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: tat yathā te vai ete pañca anye pañca anye daśa santaḥ tat kṛtam iti upakramya āha sā eṣā virāj annādi chā iti
translated: For example, beginning with Those are five, and another five, being ten, that is the creation, it is said This is the virāṭ, beginning with food.

analyzed: asmin pakṣe brahma eva abhihitam iti na chandaḥ abhidhānam
translated: In this view, only Brahman is mentioned, so it is not a reference to a meter.

analyzed: sarvathā api asti pūrvasmin vākye prakṛtam brahma
translated: In any case, in the previous sentence, Brahman is the subject.

original: FN / ya etāṃ prakṛtāṃ brahmopaniṣadaṃ vedarahasyaṃ madhuvidyārūpaṃ veda tasyodayāstamayarahitabrahmaprāptirbhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ etad prakṛ brahman upaniṣad veda rahasya madhu vidyā rūpa veda tad udaya astamaya rahita brahman prāptiḥ bhavati iti artha
translated: The meaning is: he who knows this secret Upanishad of Brahman, which is in the form of the honey knowledge, attains Brahman, which is free from rising and setting.

analyzed: etam ṛgvedinaḥ mahati ukthe śastre upāsate
translated: The Ṛgvedins meditate on this in the great Uktha hymn.

original: adhvaryavo yajurvedinaḥ kratau chandogāḥ sāmavedino mahāvrate kratau /
analyzed: adhvaryavaḥ yajurvedinaḥ kratau chandogāḥ sāmavedinaḥ mahāvrate kratau
translated: The Adhvaryus, who know the Yajur Veda, in the Kratu; the Chandogas, who know the Sama Veda, in the Mahavrata.

analyzed: saṃvarga vidyāyām adhidaivam agni sūrya candra ambhāṃsi vāyau līyate
translated: In the knowledge of the universal dissolution, the gods Agni, Surya, Chandra, and Ambhas dissolve into Vayu.

analyzed: adhyatmam vāc cakṣuḥ śrotra manasi prāṇam apiyanti
translated: In the individual, speech, eye, ear, mind, and breath dissolve into the life-breath.

analyzed: te vai ete pañca anye ādhidaivikāḥ
translated: These five are the external gods.

original: pañcānye ādhyātmikāste militvā daśa santaḥ kṛtamityucyate /
analyzed: pañca anye ādhyātmikāḥ te militvā daśa santaḥ kṛtam iti ucyate
translated: The five internal ones, together making ten, are called the Krita.

analyzed: kṛtam dyūtam
translated: The Krita is the play.

analyzed: bhūta ādi pāda vyapadeśa upapatteḥ ca evam
translated: And because the designation of the feet beginning with Bhūta is possible in this way.

analyzed: itas ca evam abhyupagantavyam iti
translated: And for this reason also it must be accepted in this way.

analyzed: pūrvasmin vākye prakṛtam brahma iti
translated: In the previous sentence, Brahman is the subject.

analyzed: yatas bhūta ādīn pādān vyapadiśati
translated: Because it designates the feet beginning with Bhūta.

original: bhūtapṛthivīśarīrahṛdayāni hi nirdiśyāha 'saiṣā catuṣpadā ṣaḍvidhā gāyatrī' iti /
analyzed: bhūta pṛthivī śarīra hṛdayāni hi nirdiśya āha sā eṣā catuṣpadā ṣaḍvidhā gāyatrī iti
translated: For after pointing out Bhūta, earth, body, and heart, it says, This Gāyatrī is four-footed and sixfold.

original: nahi brahmānāśrayaṇe kevalasya chandaso bhūtādayaḥ pādā upapadyante /
analyzed: nahi brahma an āśrayaṇe kevalasya chandasaḥ bhūta ādayaḥ pādāḥ upapadyante
translated: For without Brahman as the basis, the feet beginning with Bhūta are not possible for mere meter.

analyzed: api ca brahma an āśrayaṇe na iyam ṛc saṃbodhyeta tāvān asya iti
translated: Moreover, if Brahman is not accepted, this Ṛk would not be understood: So great is it.

analyzed: anayā hi ṛcā sva rasena brahma eva abhidhīyate
translated: For by this Ṛk, Brahman itself is denoted by its own meaning.

analyzed: pādaḥ u sya sarvā bhūtāni tri pādasya amṛtam divi chā
translated: 'The foot of him is all beings, the immortal three-footed one in heaven' (RV. 10.90.3).

analyzed: iti sarva ātma tva upapatteḥ
translated: Thus, because of the possibility of being the Self of all.

analyzed: puruṣasūkte pi iyam ṛc brahma para tayā eva samāmnāyate
translated: In the Purusha Sukta, this verse is recited with reference to Brahman.

original: smṛtiśca brahmaṇa evaṃrūpatāṃ darśayati 'viṣṭabhyāhamidaṃ kṛtsnamekāṃśena sthito jagat' bhaga / / iti /
analyzed: smṛtiḥ ca brahmaṇaḥ evaṃrūpa tām darśayati viṣṭabhya aham idam kṛtsnam eka aṃśena sthitaḥ jagat bhaga iti
translated: And the Smriti shows Brahman to have such a form: 'By one part of me I hold up this entire world' (Bhagavad Gita 10.42).

analyzed: yat vai tat brahma chā
translated: 'That which is Brahman' (Ch. Up. 7.25.2).

original: iti ca nirdeśa evaṃ sati mukhyārtha upapadyate /
analyzed: iti ca nirdeśaḥ evam sati mukhya arthe upapadyate
translated: Thus, in this case, the primary meaning is appropriate.

analyzed: pañca brahma puruṣāḥ chā
translated: 'The five Brahmapurusha' (Ch. Up. 3.12.7).

original: iti ca hṛdayasuṣiṣu brahmapuruṣaśrutirbrahmasaṃbandhitāyāṃ vivakṣitāyāṃ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: iti ca hṛdaya suṣiṣu brahma puruṣa śrutiḥ brahma saṃbandhi tāyām vivakṣitāyām saṃbhavati
translated: Thus, the mention of Brahmapurusha in the heart-cavities is possible when the connection with Brahman is intended.

analyzed: tasmāt asti pūrvasmin vākye brahma prakṛtam
translated: Therefore, in the previous statement, Brahman is the subject.

original: tadeva brahma jyotirvākye dyusaṃbandhātpratyabhijñāyamānaṃ parāmṛśyata iti sthitam // //
analyzed: tat eva brahma jyotiḥ vākye dyu saṃbandhāt pratyabhijñāyamānam parāmṛśyate iti sthitam  /
translated: It is established that the same Brahman, recognized through its connection with heaven, is referred to in the statement about the light.

original: FN / bhūtapṛthivīśarīrahṛdayavākprāṇa iti ṣaṭprakārā gāyatryākhyasya brahmaṇaḥ śrūyante /
analyzed: bhūta pṛthivī śarīra hṛdaya vāc prāṇaḥ iti ṣaṣ prakārāḥ gāyatrī ākhyasya brahmaṇaḥ śrūyante
translated: The six types of Brahman called Gayatri are heard as earth, body, heart, speech, and life-breath.

analyzed: suṣayaḥ chidrāṇi
translated: The cavities are the holes.

original: upadeśabhedān neti cen nobhayasminn apy avirodhāt / / / /
analyzed: upadeśa bhedāt na iti ced na ubhayasmin api avirodhāt
translated: If it be said that (the passage) is not (a reference to the same Brahman) on account of the difference in the teaching, (we say) not so, because there is no contradiction in both (ways of teaching).

original: yadapyetaduktaṃ pūrvatra 'tripādasyāmṛtaṃ divi' iti saptamyā dyaurādhāratvenopadiṣṭā iti /
analyzed: yat api etat uktam pūrvatra tripādasya amṛtam divi iti saptamyā dyauḥ ādhāra tvena upadiṣṭā iti
translated: And as for what was said before, that the heaven is taught as the substratum by the locative case in the passage, 'Three feet of it are immortal in heaven,'

original: punaḥ 'atha yadataḥ paro divaḥ' iti pañcamyā maryādātvena /
analyzed: punar atha yat atas paras divaḥ iti pañcamyā maryādā tvena
translated: and again, by the ablative case in the passage, 'And what is beyond the heaven,'

analyzed: tasmāt upadeśa bhedāt na tasya iha pratyabhijñānam asti
translated: therefore, on account of the difference in the teaching, there is no recognition of it here (in the latter passage).

analyzed: tat parihartavyam
translated: That (objection) must be refuted.

analyzed: atra ucyate na ayam doṣaḥ  ubhayasmin api avirodhāt
translated: The reply to that is this: This is not a fault.🔽Because there is no contradiction in both (ways of teaching).

original: ubhayasminnapi saptamyante pañcamyante copadeśe na pratyabhijñānaṃ virudhyate /
analyzed: ubhayasmin api saptamī ante pañcamī ante ca upadeśe na pratyabhijñānam virudhyate
translated: The recognition is not contradicted in both ways of teaching, by the locative case and by the ablative case.

original: yathā loke vṛkṣāgrasaṃbaddho 'pi śyena ubhayathopadiśyamāno dṛśyate /
analyzed: yathā loke vṛkṣa agra saṃbaddhaḥ pi śyenaḥ ubhayathā upadiśyamānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: As in the world, a hawk connected with the top of a tree is seen taught in both ways,

original: vṛkṣāgre śyeno vṛkṣāgrātparataḥ śyena iti ca /
analyzed: vṛkṣa agre śyenaḥ vṛkṣa agrāt paratas śyenaḥ iti ca
translated: 'The hawk is on the top of the tree,' and 'The hawk is beyond the top of the tree.'

analyzed: evam divi eva sat brahma divaḥ param iti upadiśyate
translated: In the same way, Brahman, though really existing in heaven, is taught as beyond the heaven.

original: apara āha yathā loke vṛkṣāgreṇāsaṃbaddho 'pi śyena ubhayathopadiśyamāno dṛśyate /
analyzed: aparaḥ āha yathā loke vṛkṣa agreṇa asaṃbaddhaḥ pi śyenaḥ ubhayathā upadiśyamānaḥ dṛśyate
translated: Another says: As in the world, a hawk not connected with the top of a tree is seen taught in both ways,

original: vṛkṣāgre śyeno vṛkṣāgrātpurataḥ śyena iti ca /
analyzed: vṛkṣa agre śyenaḥ vṛkṣa agrāt puratas śyenaḥ iti ca
translated: 'The hawk is on the top of the tree,' and 'The hawk is in front of the top of the tree.'

original: evaṃ ca divaḥ paramapi sadbrahma divītyupadiśyate /
analyzed: evam ca divaḥ param api sat brahma divi iti upadiśyate
translated: And thus the highest Brahman, which is beyond heaven, is taught to be in heaven.

analyzed: tasmāt asti pūrva nirdiṣṭasya brahmaṇaḥ iha pratyabhijñānam
translated: Therefore, there is recognition here of the Brahman previously indicated.

analyzed: atas param eva brahma jyotiḥ śabdam iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is established that the word 'light' refers to the highest Brahman itself.

analyzed: pratardana adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on Pratardana. Sutra.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ tathā anugamāt
translated: The vital breath, because of the subsequent connection.

original: asti kauṣītakibrāhmaṇopaniṣadīndrapratardanākhyāyikā 'pratardano ha vai daivodāsirindrasya priyaṃ dhāmopajagāma yuddhena ca pauruṣeṇa ca'
analyzed: asti kauṣītakibrāhmaṇa upaniṣadi indrapratardana ākhyāyikā pratardanaḥ ha vai daivodāsiḥ indrasya priyam dhāma upajagāma yuddhena ca pauruṣeṇa ca
translated: There is a story of Indra and Pratardana in the Upanishad of the Koushitika Brahmana: Pratardana, the son of Divodasa, approached the beloved abode of Indra through battle and manly effort.

original: tasyāṃ śrūyate 'sa hovāca praṇo 'smi prajñātmā taṃ māmāyuramṛtamityupāḥsva' iti /
analyzed: tasyām śrūyate sa ha uvāca praṇo smi prajñā ātmā tam mām āyuḥ amṛtam iti upāḥsva iti
translated: In that story it is heard: He said, 'I am the vital breath, the conscious self. Worship me as life, immortality.'

original: tathottaratrāpi 'atha khalu prāṇa eva prajñātmedaṃ śarīraṃ parigṛhyotthāpayati' ko / / / / iti /
analyzed: tathā uttaratra api atha khalu prāṇaḥ eva prajñā ātmā idam śarīram parigṛhya utthāpayati iti
translated: Similarly, later on: Then indeed the vital breath itself, having encompassed this body, raises it up. Who...

original: tathā 'na vācaṃ vijijñāsīta vaktāraṃ vidyāt' ityādi /
analyzed: tathā na vācam vijijñāsīta vaktāram vidyāt ityādi
translated: Similarly, One should not seek to know speech, one should know the speaker. And so on.

original: ante ca 'sa eṣa prāṇa eva prajñātmānando 'jaro 'mṛtaḥ' ko / / ityādi /
analyzed: ante ca saḥ eṣa prāṇaḥ eva prajñā ātmā ānandaḥ jaraḥ mṛtaḥ ityādi
translated: And at the end: That is this very vital breath, the conscious self, bliss, the unborn, the immortal. Who... And so on.

original: tatra saṃśayaḥ kimiha prāṇaśabdena vāyumātramabhidhīyata upa devatātmeti /
analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ kim iha prāṇa śabdena vāyu mātram abhidhīyate upa devatā ātmā iti
translated: Here there is doubt: does the word 'prāṇa' here denote just the wind or the deity?

analyzed: param brahma iti
translated: Or the individual soul or the supreme Brahman?

original: nanu 'ata eva prāṇaḥ' ityatra varṇitaṃ prāṇaśabdasya brahmaparatvam /
analyzed: nanu atas eva prāṇaḥ iti atra varṇitam prāṇa śabdasya brahma para tvam
translated: But has it not been explained in 'Therefore, prāṇa' that the word 'prāṇa' refers to Brahman?

analyzed: iha api ca brahma liṅgam asti ānandaḥ jaraḥ mṛtaḥ ityādi
translated: And here too there is a mark of Brahman, such as 'Bliss, immortal, and deathless'?

analyzed: katham iha punar saṃśayaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: How then is doubt possible here?

analyzed: aneka liṅga darśanāt iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say it is due to the perception of multiple marks.

analyzed: na kevalam iha brahma liṅgam eva upalabhyate
translated: Not only is a mark of Brahman perceived here,

analyzed: santi hi itara liṅgāni api  mām eva vijānīhi kau
translated: there are also other marks.

analyzed: iti indrasya vacanam devatā ātma liṅgam
translated: 'Know me alone' - this statement of Indra is a mark of the deity-self.

analyzed: idam śarīram parigṛhya utthāpayati iti prāṇa liṅgam
translated: 'Having taken up this body, it raises up' - this is a mark of prāṇa.

original: 'na vācaṃ vijijñāsīta vaktāraṃ vidyāt' ityādi jīvaliṅgam /
analyzed: na vācam vijijñāsīta vaktāram vidyāt ityādi jīva liṅgam
translated: 'One should not seek to know speech, but should know the speaker' - this and so on are marks of the individual soul.

analyzed: atas upapannaḥ saṃśayaḥ
translated: Therefore, doubt is proper.

original: tatra prasiddhervāyuḥ prāṇa iti prāpta ucyateprāṇaśabdaṃ brahma vijñeyam /
analyzed: tatra prasiddheḥ vāyuḥ prāṇaḥ iti prāptaḥ ucyate prāṇa śabdam brahma vijñeyam
translated: There, it is accepted that wind is prāṇa because of its common usage. It is said: Brahman should be known as denoted by the word 'prāṇa'.

analyzed: kutas tathā anugamāt
translated: Why? Because of the conformity with that.

original: tathāhi paurvāparyeṇa paryalocyamāne vākye padārthānāṃ samanvayo brahmapratipādanapara upalabhyate /
analyzed: tathā hi paurvāparyeṇa vākye padārthānām samanvayaḥ brahma pratipādana paraḥ upalabhyate
translated: For, when the sentence is examined in its parts, the connection of the meanings of the words is found to be directed to the teaching of Brahman.

analyzed: upakrame tāvat
translated: In the beginning, first of all,

original: 'varaṃ vṛṇīṣva' itīndreṇoktaḥ pratardanaḥ paramaṃ puruṣārthaṃ varamupacikṣepa 'tvameva me vṛṇīśva yaṃ tvaṃ manuṣyāya hitatamaṃ manyase' iti
analyzed: varam vṛṇīṣva iti indreṇa uktaḥ pratardanaḥ paramam puruṣa artham varam upacikṣepa tvam eva me yam tvam manuṣyāya hitatamam manyase iti
translated: Pratardana, addressed by Indra with the words, 'Choose a boon,' chose the highest human end as the boon, saying, 'You yourself choose for me what you think to be the best for a human being.'

original: tasmai hitatamatvenopadiśyamānaḥ prāṇaḥ kathaṃ paramātmā na syāt /
analyzed: tasmai hitatama tvena upadiśyamānaḥ prāṇaḥ katham paramātmā na syāt
translated: How can the breath, which is taught as the best for him, not be the highest Self?

original: nahyanyatra paramātmajñānāddhitatamaprāptirasti /🔽'tameva viditvātimṛtyumeti nānyaḥ panthā vidyate 'yanāya' śvetā / /
analyzed: na hi anyatra paramātma jñānāt hitatama prāptiḥ asti  tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate yanāya śvetā
translated: For, apart from the knowledge of the highest Self, there is no attainment of the best.

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: For, from such Vedic texts as, 'Having known Him alone, one passes beyond death; there is no other path to go' (Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 3.8),

original: tathā 'sa yo māṃ veda na ha vai tasya kenacana karmaṇā loko mīyate na steyena na bhrūṇahatyayā' kau / /
analyzed: tathā sa yaḥ mām veda na ha vai tasya kenacana karmaṇā lokaḥ mīyate na steyena na bhrūṇahatyayā kau
translated: and also from such passages as, 'For him who knows Me thus, no world is diminished by any action, neither by theft nor by foeticide' (Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.2.15),

analyzed: ityādi ca brahma parigrahe ghaṭate
translated: this is possible only if Brahman is accepted.

original: brahmavijñānena hi sarvakarmakṣayaḥ prasiddhaḥ 'kṣīyante cāsya karmāṇi tasmindṛṣṭe parāvare' mu / / /
analyzed: brahma vijñānena hi sarva karma kṣayaḥ prasiddhaḥ kṣīyante ca asya karmāṇi tasmin dṛṣṭe parāvare
translated: For, it is well known that by the knowledge of Brahman all actions are destroyed: 'And his actions are destroyed when He, the highest and the lowest, is seen' (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.2.9).

analyzed: ityādyāsu śrutiṣu
translated: Thus in these and other passages.

analyzed: prajñā ātma tvam ca brahma pakṣe eva upapadyate
translated: And the nature of being the Self of wisdom is possible only in the case of Brahman.

analyzed: na hi acetanasya vāyoḥ prajñā ātma tvam saṃbhavati
translated: For the nature of being the Self of wisdom is not possible for the non-intelligent wind.

original: tathopasaṃhāre 'pi 'ānando 'jaro 'mṛtaḥ' ityānandatvādīni na brahmaṇo 'nyatra samyak saṃbhavati /
analyzed: tathā upasaṃhāre pi ānandaḥ jaraḥ mṛtaḥ iti ānanda tva ādīni na brahmaṇaḥ nyatra samyak saṃbhavati
translated: Similarly, at the conclusion also, the nature of being bliss and so on is not possible in anything other than Brahman.

original: 'sa na sādhunā karmaṇā bhūyānbhavati no evāsādhunā karmaṇā kanīyāneṣa hyeva sādhu karma kārayati taṃ yamebhyo lokasya unninīṣate /
analyzed: sa na sādhunā karmaṇā bhūyān bhavati na u eva asādhunā karmaṇā kanīyān eṣa hi eva sādhu karma kārayati tam yam ebhyaḥ lokasya unninīṣate
translated: He does not become greater by good action, nor smaller by bad action; for he causes one to do good and bad actions, whom he leads from these worlds upwards.

original: eṣa u bhavāsādhu karma kārayati taṃ yamebhyo lokebhyo 'dho ninīṣate' iti /
analyzed: eṣaḥ u bhava asādhu karma kārayati tam yam ebhyaḥ lokebhyaḥ dhas ninīṣate iti
translated: And he causes one to do bad actions, whom he leads from these worlds downwards.

analyzed: eṣa loka adhipatiḥ eṣa loka īśaḥ kau iti ca
translated: He is the Lord of the worlds, he is the Ruler of the worlds.

analyzed: sarvam etat parasmanin brahmaṇi āśrīyamāṇe nu gantum śakyate na mukhye prāṇe
translated: All this can be understood if Brahman is accepted as the ultimate, but not if the primary life-breath is accepted.

analyzed: tasmāt prāṇaḥ brahma
translated: Therefore, the life-breath is Brahman.
