original: kutaḥ / tasya hi kāryakaraṇādhipateḥ prasiddho manaādibhiḥ saṃbandho na parasya brahmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: kutas tasya hi kārya karaṇa adhipateḥ prasiddhaḥ manaḥ ādibhiḥ saṃbandhaḥ na parasya brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Why? Because the embodied Self, being the lord of the body and organs, is well known to be connected with mind etc., not the supreme Brahman.

analyzed: a prāṇaḥ hi a manāḥ śubhraḥ mu
translated: For it is said in the Upanishad: 'It is without breath, without mind, pure' (Tai. 2.7).

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: And so on, according to the scriptures.

original: nanu 'sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma' iti svaśabdenaiva brahmopāttaṃ /
analyzed: nanu sarvam khalu idam brahma iti sva śabdena eva brahma upāttam
translated: But is it not Brahman itself that is referred to by its own word in the statement 'All this is Brahman'?

analyzed: katham iha śārīraḥ ātmā upāsyaḥ āśaṅkyate
translated: How then can the embodied Self be suspected as the object of worship here?

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

original: nedaṃ vākyaṃ brahmopāsanāvidhiparaṃ kiṃ tarhi śamavidhiparam /🔽yatkāraṇaṃ 'sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma tajjalāniti śānta upāsīta' ityāha /
analyzed: na idam vākyam brahma upāsanā vidhi param kim tarhi śama vidhi param  yatkāraṇam sarvam khalu idam brahma tat jalān iti śāntaḥ upāsīta iti āha
translated: This statement is not about enjoining the worship of Brahman, but rather about enjoining tranquility.🔽For this reason it says: 'One should worship as tranquil, All this is Brahman, that is born of water (Tai. 2.7).

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati yasmāt sarvam idam vikāra jātam brahmā eva
translated: This is what is meant: Since this entire creation is Brahman itself,

analyzed: tad ja tvāt tad la tvāt tad ana tvāt ca
translated: because it is born of that, because it is of that, and because it is that.

analyzed: na ca sarvasya eka ātma tve rāga ādayaḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: And when everything is of one Self, attachment and so on cannot exist.

analyzed: tasmāt śāntaḥ upāsīta iti
translated: Therefore one should worship as tranquil.

original: naca śamavidhiparatve satyanena vākyena brahmopāsanaṃ niyantuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca śama vidhi para tve sati anena vākyena brahma upāsanam niyantum śakyate
translated: And if it has for purport the enjoining of tranquillity, it cannot be enjoined by this sentence that Brahman is to be meditated upon.

original: upāsanaṃ tu 'sa kratuṃ kurvīta' ityanena vidhīyate /
analyzed: upāsanam tu sa kratum kurvīta iti anena vidhīyate
translated: But the meditation is enjoined by the sentence, Let him make the will.

analyzed: kratuḥ saṃkalpaḥ dhyānam iti arthaḥ
translated: Will means resolve, meditation.

original: tasya ca viṣayatvaṃna śrūyate 'manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīraḥ' iti jīvaliṅgam /
analyzed: tasya ca viṣaya tvam na śrūyate manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ iti jīva liṅgam
translated: And it is not heard that this has Brahman for its object. The text, He is mind-made, body is breath, contains an indication of the individual soul.

analyzed: atas brūmaḥ jīva viṣayam etat upāsanam iti
translated: Therefore we say that this meditation has the individual soul for its object.

analyzed: sarva karmā sarva kāmaḥ ityādi api śrūyamāṇam paryāyeṇa jīva viṣayam upapadyate
translated: And the text, He is all work, he is all desire, etc., which is heard, may be applied to the individual soul by turns.

original: 'eṣa ma ātmāntarhṛdaye 'ṇīyānvrīhervā yavādvā' iti ca hṛdayāyatanatvamaṇīyastvaṃ cārāgramātrasya jīvasyāvakalpate nāparicchinnasya brahmaṇaḥ
analyzed: eṣa me ātmā antar hṛdaye ṇīyān vrīheḥ vā yavāt vā iti ca hṛdaya āyatana tvam aṇīyaḥ tvam ca ārāgra mātrasya jīvasya avakalpate na aparicchinnasya brahmaṇaḥ
translated: And the text, He is my Self within the heart, smaller than a corn of rice, smaller than a corn of barley, is possible only of the individual soul, which has its abode in the heart, and is of the size of the point of a goad, and not of Brahman, which is without parts.

analyzed: nanu jyāyān pṛthivyāḥ ityādi api na paricchinne iti
translated: But the text, Greater than the earth, etc., is not possible of that which is limited.

original: atra brūmaḥ na tāvadaṇīyastvaṃ jyāyastvaṃ cobhayamekasminsamāśrayituṃ śakyaṃ / virodhāt /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ na tāvat aṇīyaḥ tvam jyāyaḥ tvam ca ubhayam ekasmin samāśrayitum śakyam virodhāt
translated: To this we reply that smallness and greatness cannot both be ascribed to the same thing, because of contradiction.

original: anyatarāśrayaṇe ca prathamaśrutatvādaṇīyastvaṃ yuktamāśrayituṃ /🔽jyāyastvaṃ tu brahmabhāvāpekṣayā bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: anyatara āśrayaṇe ca prathama śruta tvāt aṇīyaḥ tvam yuktam āśrayitum  jyāyaḥ tvam tu brahma bhāva apekṣayā bhaviṣyati iti
translated: And if one of the two is to be accepted, it is proper to accept the lesser one on the ground of its being mentioned first.🔽But the greater one will be accepted in view of the state of Brahman.

original: niścite ca jīvaviṣayatve yadante brahmasaṃkīrtanaṃ 'etadbrahma' chā / / /
analyzed: niścite ca jīva viṣaya tve yat ante brahma saṃkīrtanam etat brahma chā
translated: And when the reference to the individual soul is certain, the mention of Brahman at the end, 'This is Brahman' (Ch. U. 8.7.1),

analyzed: iti tat api prakṛta parāmarśa artha tvāt jīva viṣayam eva
translated: is also about the individual soul, because it serves to refer to what is already the subject.

analyzed: tasmāt manaḥ maya tva ādibhiḥ dharmaiḥ upāsyam
translated: Therefore, it is to be meditated upon as having the attributes of being made of mind, etc.

analyzed: kutas sarvatra prasiddha upadeśāt
translated: Why? Because of the teaching of what is well known everywhere.

original: yatsarveṣu vedānteṣu prasiddhaṃ brahmaśabdasyālambanaṃ jagatkāraṇaṃsa iha ca 'sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma' iti vākyopakrame śrute /
analyzed: yat sarveṣu vedānteṣu prasiddham brahma śabdasya ālambanam jagat kāraṇam saḥ iha ca sarvam khalu idam brahma iti vākya upakrame śrute
translated: That which is the basis of the word Brahman, well known in all the Vedanta texts as the cause of the world, and which is mentioned here in the beginning of the passage, 'All this is Brahman' (Ch. U. 7.25.2),

analyzed: tat eva manaḥ maya tva ādi dharmaiḥ viśiṣṭam upadiśyate iti yuktam
translated: it is proper that it alone, distinguished by the attributes of being made of mind, etc., is being taught.

analyzed: evam ca prakṛta hāna aprakṛta prakriye na bhaviṣyataḥ
translated: And in this way, there will be no abandoning of the subject matter and introduction of a new one.

original: nanu vākyopakrame śamavidhivivakṣayā brahma nirdiṣṭaṃ na svavivakṣayetyuktam /
analyzed: nanu vākya upakrame śama vidhi vivakṣayā brahma nirdiṣṭam na sva vivakṣayā iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that Brahman is indicated in the beginning of the passage with the intention of enjoining tranquility, not with its own intention.

original: atrocyate yadyapi śamavidhivivakṣayā brahma nirdiṣṭaṃ tathāpi manomayatvādiṣūpadiśyamāneṣu tadeva brahma saṃnihitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: atrā ucyate yadi api śama vidhi vivakṣayā brahma nirdiṣṭam tathā api manaḥ maya tva ādiṣu upadiśyamāneṣu tat eva brahma saṃnihitam bhavati
translated: To this it is said: Although Brahman is indicated with the intention of enjoining tranquility, even so, when things like being made of mind are being taught, that very Brahman becomes present.

original: jīstu na saṃnihito naca svaśabdenopātta iti vaiṣamyam // //
analyzed: jīḥ tu na saṃnihitaḥ na ca sva śabdena upāttaḥ iti vaiṣamyam
translated: But the individual soul is not present and is not mentioned by its own word. Thus there is inequality.

analyzed: jāyate iti tajjam
translated: That which is born in that is tajjam.

analyzed: tasmin iti tallam
translated: That which is in that is tallam.

original: tasminnaniti ceṣṭata iti tadanaṃ tajjaṃ catallaṃ ca tadanaṃ ceti tajjalān /🔽śākapārthivādinyāyena madhyamasya tacchabdasya lopaḥ /
analyzed: tasmin aniti ceṣṭate iti tat anam tad jam catallam ca tat anam ca iti tad jalān  śāka pārthiva ādi nyāyena madhyamasya tad śabdasya lopaḥ
translated: That which moves in that is tanam. That which is born in that is tajjam, and that which is in that is tallam, and that which moves in that is tanam. Thus it is tajjalam.🔽By the rule of shaka-parthiva, the middle tat word is elided.

analyzed: tat jalānam iti vaktavye chāndasaḥ vayava lopaḥ
translated: When it should be said tajjalam, due to the sandhi rule, there is elision of the part.

analyzed: vibhakti vyatyayena manaḥ mayam prāṇa śarīram bhā rūpam dhyāyet iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that one should meditate on the mind-made body, which has life as its essence, and which has the form of light, by reversing the case endings.

analyzed: yatas evam āha tasmāt śama vidhi param iti arthaḥ
translated: Since it is said in this way, the meaning is that it is for the purpose of enjoining tranquility.

analyzed: totra prota ayaḥ śalākā agra parimāṇasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is the size of the tip of an iron needle strung on a loom.

original: prāṇaḥ śarīramasyeti samāsagatasarvanāmnā saṃnihitārthena prakṛtaṃ brahma hitvā jīvamaprakṛtamicchataḥ prakṛtahāniraprakṛtaprakriyācetyarthaḥ
analyzed: prāṇaḥ śarīram asya iti samāsa gata sarvanāmnā saṃnihita arthena prakṛtam brahma hitvā jīvam aprakṛtam icchataḥ prakṛta hāniḥ aprakṛta prakriyā ca iti arthaḥ
translated: The compound word 'prāṇaśarīra' (having the body of prāṇa) is to be analysed as 'prāṇaḥ śarīram asya', and by taking the word 'asya' (his) as referring to the nearest object, which is Brahman, and by taking the word 'jīva' (individual soul) as the subject, there is the abandoning of the subject and the introduction of a new subject.

analyzed: vaiṣamyam jīva brahmaṇoḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The inequality between the individual soul and Brahman is the remainder.

analyzed: vivakṣita guṇa upapatteḥ ca
translated: And because the qualities intended are possible in Brahman.

analyzed: vaktum iṣṭāḥ vivakṣitāḥ
translated: The qualities intended are those that are desired to be spoken of.

original: yadyapyapauruṣeye vede vakturabhāvānneccārthaḥ saṃbhavati tathāpyupādānena phalenopacaryate /
analyzed: yadi api apauruṣeye vede vaktuḥ abhāvāt na id ca arthaḥ saṃbhavati tathā api upādānena phalena upacaryate
translated: Although the meaning of desire is not possible in the Veda, which is not of human origin, because there is no speaker, still it is figuratively applied by the result of the injunction.

analyzed: loke hi yad śabda abhihitam upādeyam bhavati tat vivakṣitam iti ucyate
translated: For in the world, that which is stated by the word 'yat' (if) as to be accepted is said to be intended.

analyzed: yat anupādeyam tat avivakṣitam iti
translated: That which is not to be accepted is not intended.

analyzed: tat amavede pi upādeya tvena abhihitam vivakṣitam bhavati
translated: In the Veda also, that which is stated as to be accepted becomes intended.

analyzed: itarat avivakṣitam
translated: The other is not intended.

analyzed: upādāna anupādāne tu veda vākya tātparyābhyām avagamyate
translated: But the acceptance or non-acceptance is understood from the purport and the meaning of the Vedic sentence.

original: tadiha ye vivakṣitā guṇā upāsanāyāmupādeyatvenopadiṣṭāḥ satyasaṃkalpaprabhṛtayaste parasminbrahmaṇyupapadyante /
analyzed: tat iha ye vivakṣitāḥ guṇāḥ upāsanāyām upādeya tvena upadiṣṭāḥ satya saṃkalpa prabhṛtayaḥ te parasmin brahmaṇi upapadyante
translated: Here, the qualities that are intended, which are taught as to be accepted in meditation, such as having true resolve, etc., are possible in the supreme Brahman.

analyzed: satya saṃkalpa tvam hi sṛṣṭi sthiti saṃhāreṣu apratibaddha śakti tvāt paramātmanaḥ eva avakalpate
translated: For the quality of having true desires and purposes is possible only for the highest Self, whose power is not obstructed in creation, preservation, and destruction.

analyzed: paramātma guṇa tvena ca yaḥ ātmā apahṛta pāpmā chā
translated: And the quality of being the Self is mentioned in the passage, 'He who is the Self, free from sin' (Ch. U. 8.7.1), as a quality of the highest Self.

analyzed: iti atra satya kāmaḥ satya saṃkalpaḥ iti śrutam
translated: And the quality of having true desires and purposes is mentioned in the passage, 'He who has true desires and true purposes' (Ch. U. 8.7.1).

analyzed: ākāśa ātmā ityādinā ākāśa vat ātmā asya iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of 'having the Self like space' is that it has a Self like space.

analyzed: sarvagata tva ādibhiḥ dharṇaiḥ saṃbhavati ākāśena sāmyam brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Brahman has similarity with space, which is possible through such qualities as being all-pervading.

analyzed: jyāyān pṛthivyāḥ ityādinā ca etat eva darśayati
translated: And this is shown by the passage beginning with 'greater than earth' (Ch. U. 8.7.1).

analyzed: yadā api ākāśaḥ ātmā yasya iti
translated: Even when the explanation is given as 'he who has space as his Self',

original: tadapi saṃbhavati sarvajagatkāraṇasya sarvātmano brahma ākāśātmatvam /
analyzed: tat api saṃbhavati sarva jagat kāraṇasya sarvātmanaḥ brahma ākāśa ātma tvam
translated: that is also possible, since Brahman, the cause of the entire world and the Self of all, has space as its Self.

analyzed: atas eva sarva karmā ityādi
translated: For this very reason, it is said that it is 'the doer of all' (Ch. U. 8.7.1).

analyzed: evam iha upāsya tayā vivakṣitāḥ guṇāḥ brahmaṇi upapadyante
translated: Thus, the qualities intended to be meditated upon here are possible in Brahman.

original: yattūktaṃ 'manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīraḥ' iti jīvaliṅgaṃ na tadbrahmaṇyupapadyata iti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ iti jīva liṅgam na tat brahmaṇi upapadyate iti
translated: As for what was said - that the indication of the individual soul in the passage 'consisting of mind, having breath for its body' (Ch. U. 8.7.1) is not possible in Brahman -

analyzed: tat api brahmaṇi upapadyate iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say that even that is possible in Brahman.

original: sarvātmatvāddhi brahmaṇo jīvasaṃbandhīni manomayatvādīni brahmasaṃbandhīni bhavanti /
analyzed: sarva ātma tvāt hi brahmaṇaḥ jīva saṃbandhīni manaḥ maya tva ādīni brahma saṃbandhīni bhavanti
translated: For, Brahman being the Self of all, the attributes of being full of mind, etc., which belong to the individual soul, belong to Brahman also.

original: tathāca brahmaviṣaye śrutismṛtī bhavataḥ 'tvaṃ strī tvaṃ kumāra uta vā kumārī /
analyzed: tathā ca brahma viṣaye śruti smṛtī bhavataḥ tvam strī tvam kumāraḥ uta vā kumārī
translated: And in this sense there are the Vedic texts and Smṛti texts about Brahman: 'You are a woman, you are a boy or a girl,

original: tvaṃ jīrṇo daṇḍena vañcasi tvaṃ jāto bhavasi viśvatomukhaḥ' śve / /
analyzed: tvam jīrṇaḥ daṇḍena vañcasi tvam jātaḥ bhavasi viśvatomukhaḥ śve
translated: you are an old man, you go about with a staff; you are born, you have a face on every side' (Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 3.1).

analyzed: iti sarvatas pāṇi pādam tat sarvatas akṣi śiraḥ mukham
translated: And: 'It has hands and feet on all sides, eyes, heads and faces on all sides,

original: sarvataḥśrutimalloke sarvamāvṛtya tiṣṭhati gī / / iti ca /
analyzed: sarvatas śrutimat loke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati iti ca
translated: ears on all sides; it stands pervading all the world' (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 1.1.9).

original: 'aprāṇo hyamanāḥ śubhraḥ' iti śrutiḥ śuddhabrahmaviṣayā /🔽iyaṃ tu 'manomayaḥ prāṇaśarīraḥ' iti saguṇabrahmaviṣayeti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: a prāṇaḥ hi a manāḥ śubhraḥ iti śrutiḥ śuddha brahma viṣayā  iyam tu manaḥ mayaḥ prāṇa śarīraḥ iti saguṇa brahma viṣayā iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: The Vedic text 'It is without breath, without mind, pure' refers to pure Brahman.🔽But this text 'It is full of mind, its body is breath' refers to Brahman with qualities. This is the difference.

analyzed: atas vivakṣita guṇa upapatteḥ param eva brahma iha upāsya tvena upadiṣṭam iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, because the attributes intended are possible, it is understood that the highest Brahman itself is taught here as the object of meditation.

analyzed: upādāna anupādāne parigraha parityāgau
translated: The acceptance and rejection of the Vedānta texts are the taking up and abandoning of them.

analyzed: tāttaryam nāma phalavat artha pratīti anukūla tvam śabda dharmaḥ
translated: Signification is a property of words that is conducive to the understanding of a meaningful object that has a result.

analyzed: upakrama ādinā jñānāt tayoḥ avagamaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that their understanding is from the knowledge of the beginning etc.

original: jīrṇaḥ sthaviro bhūtvā yodaṇḍena vañcati gacchati /
analyzed: jīrṇaḥ sthaviraḥ bhūtvā yaḥ daṇḍena vañcati gacchati
translated: He who, having become old and decrepit, goes by the rod, deceives.

original: tathā yo jātaḥ bālaḥ so 'pi tvameva /
analyzed: tathā yaḥ jātaḥ bālaḥ saḥ tvam eva
translated: And likewise, you alone are he who is born as a child.

analyzed: anupapatteḥ tu na śārīraḥ
translated: But on account of the impossibility (of attributing to the individual soul the qualities mentioned in the text), the individual soul cannot be the object of the passage.

analyzed: pūrveṇa sutreṇa brahmaṇi vivakṣitānām guṇānām upapattiḥ uktā
translated: By the preceding Sūtra it has been shown that the qualities which the text ascribes to Brahman are appropriate to it.

analyzed: anena tu śārīre teṣām anupapattiḥ ucyate
translated: The present Sūtra declares that they are not appropriate to the individual soul.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ vadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word but is meant to intimate the refutation of the pūrvapakṣa.

analyzed: brahmā eva uktena nyāyena manaḥ maya tva ādi guṇam
translated: Brahman only, for the reasons stated, possesses the qualities of consisting of mind and so on,

analyzed: na tu śārīraḥ jīvaḥ manaḥ maya tva ādi guṇaḥ  yatkāraṇam satya saṃkalpaḥ  ākāśa ātmā  avākī  anādaraḥ
translated: not the individual soul, the embodied Self, which cannot be supposed to possess those qualities.

original: jyāyānpṛthivyā' iti caivañjātīyakā guṇā na śārīra āñjasyenopapadyante /
analyzed: jyāyān pṛthivyāḥ iti ca evañjātīyakāḥ guṇāḥ na śārīre āñjasyena upapadyante
translated: For the following reasons also Brahman only can be the object of the passage, not the individual soul; because the qualities mentioned in the passage are not appropriate to the individual soul.

analyzed: śārīre iti śarīre bhave iti arthaḥ
translated: The individual soul means that which exists in the body.

analyzed: nanu īśvaraḥ pi śarīre bhavati
translated: But the Lord also exists in the body.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True;

original: śarīre bhavati natu śarīra eva bhavati /🔽'jyāyānpṛthivyā jyāyānantarikṣāt' /
analyzed: śarīre bhavati na tu śarīre eva bhavati  jyāyān pṛthivyāḥ jyāyān antarikṣāt
translated: but he exists in the body, not in the body only.🔽For the passage declares him to be allpervading, He is greater than the earth, greater than the sky,

analyzed: ākāśa vat sarva gataḥ ca nityaḥ iti ca vyāpita tva śravaṇāt
translated: and again, He is omnipresent like Ākāśa, eternal Bṛ Up , , 0.

analyzed: jīvaḥ tu śarīre eva bhavati
translated: The individual soul, on the other hand, exists in the body only.

original: tasya bhogādhiṣṭhānāccharīrādanyatra vṛttyabhāvāt // // 🔽FN / vāgeva vākaḥ so 'syāstīti vākī na vākī avākī vāgādisarvendriyarahitaḥ /
analyzed: tasya bhoga adhiṣṭhānāt śarīrāt anyatra vṛtti abhāvāt  vāc eva vākaḥ saḥ sya asti iti vākī na vākī avākī vāc ādi sarva indriya rahitaḥ
translated: Because, apart from the body, which is the substratum of experience, there is no operation of the Self.🔽Or, it is ‘vāki’ (without speech), because it has no speech, or any other sense organs.

analyzed: āpta kāma tvāt na sti iti anādaraḥ
translated: It is ‘anādara’ (without regard), because it has no regard for anything, being the fulfiller of all desires.

analyzed: karma kartṛ vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because there is designation of action and agent.

analyzed: itas ca na śārīraḥ manaḥ maya tva ādi guṇaḥ
translated: For another reason also the embodied Self is not the one possessing the qualities of consisting of mind, etc.

analyzed: yasmāt karma kartṛ vyapadeśaḥ bhavati etam itas pretya abhisaṃbhavitāsmi chā iti
translated: Because there is designation of action and agent, in the passage, ‘After departing from hence I shall become united with Him’ (Chānd. 8.1.6).

original: etamiti prakṛtaṃ manomayatvādiguṇamupāsyamātmānaṃ karmatvena prāpyatvena vyapadiśati /
analyzed: etam iti prakṛtam manaḥ maya tva ādi guṇam upāsyam ātmānam karma tvena prāpya tvena vyapadiśati
translated: Here, the embodied Self is designated as the object to be attained, as the action, in the words ‘I shall become united with Him’, referring to the Self which is the object of meditation and which possesses the qualities of consisting of mind, etc.

analyzed: abhisaṃbhavitāsmi iti śārīram upāsakam kartṛ tvena prāpaka tvena

translated: This is heard.

original: tatra saṃśayaḥ kimayamadreśyatvādiguṇako bhūtayoniḥ pradhānaṃ syāduta śārīra āhosvitparameśvara iti /🔽tatra pradhānamacetanaṃ bhūtayoniriti yuktaṃ /
analyzed: tatra saṃśayaḥ kim ayam adreśya tva ādi guṇakaḥ bhūtayoniḥ pradhānam syāt uta śārīraḥ āhosvit parameśvaraḥ iti  tatra pradhānam acetanam bhūta yoniḥ iti yuktam
translated: Here a doubt arises whether the source of the elements, which possesses the qualities of being invisible, &c, is the pradhāna, or the embodied soul, or the highest Lord?

original: acetanānāmeva taddṛṣṭāntatvenopādānāt /🔽'yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhyate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhaḥ saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: acetanānām eva tad dṛṣṭānta tvena upādānāt  yathā ūrṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhyate ca yathā pṛthivyām oṣadhaḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: The pradhāna, which is nonintelligent, may be the source of the elements, because only nonintelligent things are mentioned as its examples🔽, as, for instance, in the passage, As the spider sends forth and draws in its threads, as from a tree leaves and sprouts and fruits arise,

original: yathā sataḥ puruṣotkeśalomāni tathākṣarātsaṃbhavatīha viśvam' muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: yathā sataḥ puruṣa utkeśa lomāni tathā akṣarāt saṃbhavati iha viśvam muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: as from a living person hair and nails grow, thus from the Imperishable the whole world comes forth Śve Up ,

analyzed: nanu ūrṇanābhiḥ puruṣaḥ ca cetanau iha dṛṣṭānta tvena upāttau
translated: But, an objection is raised, the spider and the man are in the passage quoted mentioned as intelligent beings!

analyzed: na iti brūmaḥ
translated: We reply that that is not the case

original: nahi kevalasya cetanasya tatra sūtrayonitvaṃ keśalomayonitvaṃ cāsti /🔽cetanādhiṣṭhitaṃ hyacetanamūrṇanābhiśarīraṃ sūtrasya yoniḥ /
analyzed: nahi kevalasya cetanasya tatra sūtra yoni tvam keśa loma yoni tvam ca asti  cetanā dhiṣṭhitam hi acetanam ūrṇanābhi śarīram sūtrasya yoniḥ
translated: For the mere intelligent Self has neither the nature of a spider nor that of a man

analyzed: puruṣa śarīram ca keśa lomnām iti prasiddham
translated: The body of the spider, which is nonintelligent, but presided over by an intelligent principle, is the source of the thread; the body of the man is the source of the hair and nails This is well known

analyzed: api ca pūrvatra adṛṣṭa tva ādi abhilāṣa saṃbhave pi draṣṭṛ tva ādi abhilāṣa asaṃbhavāt na pradhānam abhyupagatam
translated: Moreover, although in the passage quoted above the pradhāna may be supposed to be the object of the desire of seeing, &c, on account of its being not seen before, &c, still it cannot be admitted that it is the object of the desire of seeing, on account of its being the seer, &c; for that reason also that it is not the object of the desire of seeing, on account of its being the seer, &c, is stated in the next Sūtra

analyzed: iha tu adṛśya tva ādayaḥ dharmāḥ pradhāne saṃbhavanti
translated: But here, the attributes of being invisible, etc., are possible in the principal (matter).

original: nacātra virudhyamāno dharmaḥ kaścidabhilapyate /🔽nanu 'yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavit' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: na ca atra virudhyamānaḥ dharmaḥ kaścid abhilapyate  nanu yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavid muṇḍa
translated: And no attribute that is contradictory is mentioned here.

analyzed: iti ayam vākya śeṣaḥ cetane pradhāne na saṃbhavanti
translated: But is this passage, He who is omniscient, who knows all, not possible in the non-intelligent pradhāna?

original: kathaṃ pradhānaṃ bhūtayoniḥ pratijñāyata iti /🔽atrocyate 'yayā tadakṣaramadhigamyate' 'yattadadreśyam' ityakṣaraśabdenādṛśyatvādiguṇakaṃ bhūtayoniṃ śrāvayitvā punarante śrāvayiṣyati 'akṣarātparataḥ
analyzed: katham pradhānam bhūta yoniḥ pratijñāyate iti  atrā ucyate yayā tat akṣaram adhigamyate yat tat adreśyam iti akṣara śabdena adṛśya tva ādi guṇakam bhūtayonim śrāvayitvā punar ante śrāvayiṣyati akṣarāt paratas
translated: How can the pradhāna be declared to be the source of beings?

analyzed: paraḥ muṇḍa iti
translated: To this it is said: Having declared the source of beings, which has the attributes of being invisible, etc., by the word akṣara (imperishable) in the passages By which that imperishable is attained and That which is invisible, it will again declare at the end, Beyond that imperishable, there is another.

original: tatra yaḥ paro 'kṣarācchrutaḥ sa sarvajñaḥ sarvavitsaṃbhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tatra yaḥ kṣarāt śrutaḥ sa sarvajñaḥ sarva vid saṃbhaviṣyati
translated: Among them, he who is heard to be beyond the imperishable will be omniscient and all-knowing.

analyzed: pradhānam eva tu akṣara śabda nirdiṣṭam bhūtayoniḥ
translated: But the pradhāna itself, indicated by the word akṣara (imperishable), is the source of beings.

original: yadā tu yoniśabdo nimittavācī tadā śārīro 'pi bhūtayoniḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadā tu yoni śabdaḥ nimitta vācī tadā bhūtayoniḥ syāt
translated: But when the word yoni (source) means cause, then the embodied Self also would be the source of beings.

analyzed: dharma adharmābhyām bhūta jātasya upārjanāt iti
translated: Because the various kinds of beings are produced by virtue and vice.

original: evaṃ prāpte 'bhidhīyate yoyamadṛśyatvādiguṇako bhūtayoniḥ sa parameśvara eva syānnānya iti /
analyzed: evam prāpte abhidhīyate yaḥ yam adṛśya tva ādi guṇakaḥ bhūtayoniḥ sa parameśvaraḥ eva syāt na anyaḥ iti
translated: To this we make the following reply: The source of the elements, which possesses the qualities of being invisible, &c., must be the highest Lord, not anything else.

analyzed: katham etat avagamyate
translated: How do you know that?

analyzed: dharma ukteḥ
translated: Because it is spoken of as a quality of the Lord

original: parameśvarasya hi dharma ihocyamāno dṛśyate 'yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavit' iti /🔽nahi pradhānasyācetanasya śārīrasya vopādhiparicchinnadṛṣṭeḥ sarvajñatvaṃ sarvavittvaṃ vā saṃbhavati /
analyzed: parameśvarasya hi dharmaḥ iha ucyamānaḥ dṛśyate yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarva vid iti  nahi pradhānasya acetanasya śārīrasya vā upādhi paricchinna dṛṣṭeḥ sarvajña tvam sarva vid tvam vā saṃbhavati
translated: For the text speaks of a quality of the highest Lord, He who is the knower of the field, who is the allknowing, the allseeing Bṛ Up , , 0🔽For the pradhāna, which is nonintelligent, as well as the embodied soul, whose vision is limited by the adjuncts, cannot be allknowing and allseeing

original: nanvakṣaraśabdanirdiṣṭādbhūtayoneḥ parasyaiva tatsarvajñatvaṃ ca na bhūtayoniviṣayamityuktam /
analyzed: nanu akṣara śabda nirdiṣṭāt bhūtayoneḥ parasya eva tat sarvajñatvam ca na bhūtayoni viṣayam iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the allknowingness belongs to the highest Self, which is indicated by the word undecaying, not to the source of the elements!

analyzed: atra ucyate na evam saṃbhavati
translated: To this we reply that that cannot be so,

original: yatkāraṇaṃ 'akṣarātsaṃbhavatīha viśvam' iti prakṛtaṃ bhūtayonimiha jāyamānaprakṛtitvena🔽nirdiśyānantaramapi jāyamānaprakṛtitvenaiva sarvajñaṃ nirdiśati 'yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavidyasya jñānamayaṃ tapaḥ /
analyzed: yatkāraṇam akṣarāt saṃbhavati iha viśvam iti prakṛtam bhūta yonim iha jāyamāna prakṛti tvena  nirdiśya anantaram api jāyamāna prakṛti tvena eva sarvajñam nirdiśati yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarva vid yasya jñāna mayam tapaḥ
translated: because the source of the elements, which is referred to in the passage, From the Imperishable everything here originates, is here spoken of as the material cause of what is born,

original: tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ ca jāyate' iti /
analyzed: tasmāt etat brahma nāma rūpam annam ca jāyate iti
translated: and immediately after that the allknowing one also is spoken of as the material cause of what is born, He who is the allknowing, the allseeing, whose light the Self is, whose splendour the Self is, whose lustre the Self is, whose knowledge the Self is, whose truth the Self is, whose infinity the Self is, whose eternity the Self is, whose omnipresence the Self is, whose allseeingness the Self is, whose allhearingness the Self is, whose allknowingness the Self is, whose allness the Self is, whose allbreaths the Self is, whose allbodies the Self is, whose allfaces the Self is, whose allgods the Self is, whose allcastes the Self is, whose allelements the Self is, whose allworlds the Self is, whose allbeings the Self is, whose allsacrifices the Self is, whose allchants the Self is, whose allvediclores the Self is, whose allpersons the Self is, whose allwords the Self is, whose allnames the Self is, whose allthoughts the Self is, whose allbeings the Self is, whose alldesires the Self is, whose allfears the Self is, whose alljoys the Self is, whose allsorrows the Self is, whose allduties the Self is, whose allnights the Self is, whose alldays the Self is, whose allhalves the Self is, whose allquarters the Self is, whose

original: tasmānnirdeśasāmyena pratyabhijñāyamānatvātprakṛtasyaivākṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ sarvajñatvaṃ sarvavittvaṃ ca dharma ucyata iti gamyate /
analyzed: tasmāt nirdeśa sāmyena pratyabhijñāyamāna tvāt prakṛtasya eva akṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ sarvajña tvam sarva vid tvam ca dharmaḥ ucyate iti gamyate
translated: Therefore, since the same is taught here as was taught there, it is understood that the same syllable, the source of all beings, is spoken of here as omniscient and all-knowing.

analyzed: akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti atra api na prakṛtāt bhūtayoneḥ akṣarāt paraḥ kaścid abhidhūyate
translated: In the passage, Beyond the imperishable, the supreme, no one beyond the imperishable, the source of all beings, is spoken of.

analyzed: katham etat avagamyate
translated: How is this understood?

original: 'yenākṣaraṃ puruṣaṃ veda satyaṃ provāca tāṃ tattvato brahmavidyām' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: yena akṣaram puruṣam veda satyam provāca tām tattvataḥ brahma vidyām muṇḍa
translated: He who knows the imperishable person, he has truly declared the knowledge of Brahman.

original: iti prakṛtya tasyaivākṣarasya bhūtayoneradṛśyatvādiguṇakasya vaktavyatvena pratijñātatvāt /
analyzed: iti prakṛtya tasya eva akṣarasya bhūtayoneḥ adṛśya tva ādi guṇakasya vaktavya tvena pratijñāta tvāt
translated: Having introduced this, it is promised that the same imperishable, the source of all beings, having the qualities of being invisible, etc., is to be spoken of.

original: kathaṃ tarhi 'akṣarātparataḥ paraḥ' iti vyapadiśyata iti /
analyzed: katham tarhi akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti vyapadiśyate iti
translated: Then how is it referred to as beyond the imperishable?

analyzed: uttara sūtre tat vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: We will explain that in the next aphorism.

original: apicātra dve vidye veditavye ukte 'parā caivāparā ca' iti /
analyzed: apica atra dve vidye veditavye ukte parā ca eva aparā ca iti
translated: Moreover, here two kinds of knowledge are said to be known, the lower and the higher.

original: tatrāparāmṛgvedādilakṣaṇāṃ vidyāmuktvā bravīti 'atha parā yayā tadakṣaramadhigamyate ityādi /
analyzed: tatra aparām ṛgveda ādi lakṣaṇām vidyām uktvā bravīti atha parā yayā tat akṣaram adhigamyate ityādi
translated: Having spoken of the lower knowledge characterized by the Ṛg Veda, etc., it is said, Now the higher, by which that imperishable is attained.

analyzed: tatra parasyāḥ vidyāyāḥ viṣaya tvena akṣaram śrutam
translated: There, the imperishable is heard as the object of the higher knowledge.

original: yadi punaḥ parameśvarādanyadadṛśyatvādiguṇakamakṣaraṃ parikalpyeta neyaṃ parā vidyā syāt /🔽parāparavibhāgo hyayaṃ vidyayorabhyudayaniḥśreyasaphalatayā parikalpyate /🔽naca pradhānavidyā niḥśreyasaphalā kenacidabhyupagamyate /🔽tisraśca vidyāḥ pratijñāyeran /🔽tvatpakṣe 'kṣarādbhūtayoneḥ parasya paramātmanaḥ pratipādyamānatvāt /🔽dve eva tu vidye veditavye iha nirdiṣṭe /🔽'kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati' muṇḍa / / /🔽iti caikavijñānena sarvavijñānāpekṣaṇaṃ sarvātmake brahmaṇi vivakṣyamāṇe 'vakalpyate /
analyzed: yadi punar parameśvarāt anyat adṛśya tva ādi guṇakam akṣaram parikalpyeta na iyam parā vidyā syāt  para apara vibhāgaḥ hi ayam vidyayoḥ abhyudaya niḥśreyasa phala tayā parikalpyate  na ca pradhāna vidyā niḥśreyasa phalā kenacid abhyupagamyate  tisraḥ ca vidyāḥ pratijñāyeran  tvad pakṣe kṣarāt bhūtayoneḥ parasya paramātmanaḥ pratipādyamāna tvāt  dve eva tu vidye veditavye iha nirdiṣṭe  kasmin nu bhagavaḥ vijñāte sarvam idam vijñātam bhavati muṇḍa  iti ca eka vijñānena sarva vijñāna apekṣaṇam sarva ātmake brahmaṇi vivakṣyamāṇe
translated: If, on the other hand, the imperishable Brahman, endowed with the qualities of being invisible, &c., were assumed to be something different from the highest Lord, the knowledge of that Brahman would not be the highest knowledge🔽For the distinction of the two kinds of knowledge is made on the ground of their results, the one leading to prosperity, the other to absolute beatitude🔽And nobody maintains that the knowledge of the pradhāna has for its result absolute beatitude🔽Moreover, if you maintain that the pradhāna is the imperishable Brahman, you will have to admit three kinds of knowledge,🔽since the highest Self, which is higher than the imperishable source of the elements, is taught in the Upaniṣads🔽But only two kinds of knowledge are mentioned in the passage, That which thou seest as neither this nor that, &c, and as the result of the knowledge of the highest Brahman the text declares that the highest state is reached, He becomes Brahman Bṛ Up , , 0🔽Moreover, the passage, Sir, when one thing is known, is everything known? Mu Up , , 1, which declares that by the knowledge of one thing everything is known, is possible only if Brahman which is all is intended to be taught

original: nācetanamātraikāyatane pradhāne /🔽bhogyavyatirikte vā bhoktari /🔽apica 'sa brahmavidyāṃ sarvavidyāpratiṣṭhāmatharvāya jyeṣṭhaputrāya prāha' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: na acetana mātra eka āyatane pradhāne 🔽bhogya vyatirikte vā bhoktari 🔽api ca sa brahma vidyām sarva vidyā pratiṣṭhām atharvāya jyeṣṭha putrāya prāha muṇḍa
translated: If, on the other hand, the imperishable were assumed to be something different from the highest Lord, possessing the attributes of being invisible, &c, it would not be the highest knowledge, and the distinction of the two kinds of knowledge would be lost, since that distinction is based on the fact that the one knowledge has for its result the highest human end, the other the mere attainment of heaven and so on But the knowledge of the pradhāna is not admitted by any one to have for its result the highest human end And a third kind of knowledge would have to be assumed, since according to your doctrine the highest Self is taught as something different from the imperishable source of the elements But only two kinds of knowledge are mentioned in the passage, That which thou seest as common to all, know that to be the lower; but that which thou seest as different, know that to be the higher Gī , , And the passage, When the one is known, everything else is known Mu Up , , , , intimates that the knowledge of everything else depends on the knowledge of the one, a fact which is possible only if Brahman is meant, which is the Self of everything, not if the pradhāna is meant, which is the abode of mere nonintelligent matter, or if the enjoyer is meant, who is different from the objects of enjoyment Moreover, the passage, He taught the highest knowledge, the foundation of all knowledge, to Atharvan, his eldest son Mu Up , , , intimates that the knowledge of the pradhāna is not the highest knowledge, since it is said to be taught by Brahman to his son

original: iti brahmavidyāṃ prādhānyenopakramya parāparavibhāgena parāṃ vidyāmakṣarādhigamanīṃ darśayaṃstayā brahmavidyātvaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: iti brahma vidyām prādhānyena upakramya para apara vibhāgena parām vidyām akṣara adhigamanīm darśayan tayā brahma vidyā tvam darśayati
translated: Having thus begun the knowledge of Brahman in the primary sense, by distinguishing the highest and the lowest, he shows the highest knowledge which leads to the understanding of the Imperishable, and thereby shows that it is the knowledge of Brahman.

original: sā ca brahmavidyāsamākhyā tadadhigamyasyākṣarasyābrahmatve bādhitā syāt /
analyzed: sā ca brahma vidyā samākhyā tad adhigamyasya akṣarasya abrahmatve bādhitā syāt
translated: And that designation of the knowledge of Brahman would be contradicted if the Imperishable, which is to be understood through that, were not Brahman.

analyzed: aparā ṛgveda ādi lakṣaṇā karma vidyā brahma vidyā upakrame upanyasyate brahma vidyā praśaṃsāyai
translated: The knowledge of action characterized by the other Vedas, etc., is introduced at the beginning of the knowledge of Brahman in order to praise the knowledge of Brahman.

original: 'plavā hyete adṛḍhā yajñarūpā aṣṭādaśoktamavaraṃ yeṣu karma /
analyzed: plavāḥ hi ete adṛḍhāḥ yajña rūpāḥ aṣṭādaśa uktam avaram yeṣu karma
translated: For these sacrificial forms are indeed unstable, the inferior rites of which eighteen are spoken of,

original: etacchreyo yo 'bhinandanti mūḍhā jarāmṛtyuṃ te punarevāpiyanti' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: etat śreyaḥ yaḥ bhinandanti mūḍhāḥ jarā mṛtyum te punar eva apiyanti muṇḍa
translated: those deluded ones who delight in this as the highest good, they again fall into old age and death (Mu. 1.2.7).

analyzed: iti evamādi nindā vacanāt
translated: Thus, because of the words of censure beginning with this,

original: ninditvā cāparāṃ vidyāṃ tato viraktasya paravidyādhikāraṃ darśayati 'parīkṣya lokānkarmacitānbrāhmaṇo nirvedamāyānnāstyakṛtaḥ kṛtena /
analyzed: ninditvā ca aparām vidyām tatas viraktasya para vidyā adhikāram darśayati parīkṣya lokān karma citān brāhmaṇaḥ nirvedam āyāt na asti akṛtaḥ kṛtena
translated: and having censured the other knowledge, it shows that one who is detached from that is qualified for the highest knowledge: Having examined the worlds created by action, the brahmin becomes indifferent, thinking 'there is no escape from the consequences of one's own action.'

original: tadvijñānārthaṃ sa gurumevābhigacchetsamitpāṇiḥ śretriyaṃ brahmaniṣṭham' muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: tad vijñāna artham sa gurum eva abhigacchet samidh pāṇiḥ śretriyam brahma niṣṭham muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: For the sake of understanding that, he should approach the teacher himself, with fuel in his hand, a brahmin devoted to Brahman (Mu. 1.2.12).

analyzed: yat tu uktam acetanānām pṛthivī ādīnām dṛṣṭānta tvena upādānāt dārṣṭāntikena api acetanena bhūtayoninā bhavitavyam iti
translated: As for what was said - that since insentient things like earth are used as examples, the inferred object, the source of beings, must also be insentient -

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is incorrect.

analyzed: nahi dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭāntikayoḥ atyanta sāmyena bhavitavyam iti
translated: There is no rule that the inferred object must be absolutely identical to the example.

original: apica sthūlāḥ pṛthivyādayo dṛṣṭāntatvenopāttā iti na sthūla eva dārṣṭāntiko bhūtayonirabhyupagamyate /
analyzed: apica sthūlāḥ pṛthivī ādayaḥ dṛṣṭānta tvena upāttāḥ iti na sthūlaḥ eva dārṣṭāntikaḥ bhūtayoniḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: Moreover, since gross things like earth are used as examples, the inferred object, the source of beings, is not accepted as only gross.

analyzed: tasmāt adṛśya tva ādi guṇakaḥ bhūtayoniḥ parameśvaraḥ eva
translated: Therefore, the source of beings, having the qualities of being invisible, etc., is the Supreme Lord alone.

analyzed: a dreśyam a dṛś jñāna indriyaiḥ  a grāhyam karmendriyaiḥ
translated: The unseen, invisible to the sense of knowledge.🔽The ungraspable, not graspable by the organs of action.

analyzed: ūrṇanābhiḥ lūtā kīṭaḥ
translated: The spider is the silkworm.

analyzed: pūrvatra pūrvasmin adhikaraṇe
translated: In the previous section.

analyzed: nahi iti
translated: Not so.

original: 'aktāḥ śarkarā upadadhātī' tyatra 'tejo vai ghṛtaṃ' iti śeṣānnirṇayavadatrāpi adṛśyavādeḥ śeṣānnirṇayaḥ /
analyzed: aktāḥ śarkarāḥ upadadhāti tyatra tejaḥ vai ghṛtam iti śeṣāt nirṇaya vat atra api adṛśya vādeḥ śeṣāt nirṇayaḥ
translated: Just as in the case of 'he lays down the unanointed bricks', the determination is made from the remainder 'ghee is indeed brilliance', so here too the determination of the doctrine of the unseen is from the remainder.

original: yena jñānenākṣaraṃ prakṛtaṃ bhūtayoniṃ puruṣaṃ satyaṃ veda /
analyzed: yena jñānena akṣaram prakṛtam bhūta yonim puruṣam satyam veda
translated: By that knowledge one knows the imperishable, the source of beings, the person, the truth.

analyzed: sarva vidyānām pratiṣṭhā samāptiḥ yasyām
translated: In which all knowledge is established, completed.

analyzed: plavante gacchanti asthāyinaḥ iti plavāḥ
translated: They float, go, are impermanent, hence they are 'floating'.

analyzed: aṣṭādaśa iti ṣoḍaśa ārtvijaḥ yajamānaḥ patnī ca iti aṣṭādaśa
translated: Eighteen, i.e., sixteen priests, the sacrificer, and the wife, make eighteen.

analyzed: yeṣu uktam avaram anityam karma yajñaḥ
translated: In which it is said that the inferior, impermanent rite is sacrifice.

analyzed: apiyanti prāpnuvanti
translated: They go, they attain.

original: pratyakṣādinā karmasādhyāṃllokānanityatayā jñātvā nirvedaṃ vairāgyaṃ gacchet /
analyzed: pratyakṣa ādinā karma sādhyān lokān anitya tayā jñātvā nirvedam vairāgyam gacchet
translated: Having known by perception etc. that the worlds to be attained by rites are impermanent, one should go to indifference, non-attachment.

original: kutaḥ / kṛtena karmaṇā akṛto mokṣo nāsti /
analyzed: kutas kṛtena karmaṇā akṛtaḥ mokṣaḥ na asti
translated: Why? Liberation is not attained without the rite performed.

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa bheda vyapadeśābhyām ca na itarau
translated: And because of the difference in qualifications and designation, the other two are not (the source of beings).

original: itaśca parameśvara eva bhūtayonirnetarau śārīraḥ pradhānaṃ vā /
analyzed: itas ca parameśvaraḥ eva bhūtayoniḥ na itarau śārīraḥ pradhānam vā
translated: And for this reason also, the Supreme Lord alone is the source of beings, not the other two, the embodied one or Prakriti.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why?

analyzed: viśeṣaṇa bheda vyapadeśābhyām
translated: Because of the difference in qualifications and designation.

original: viśinaṣṭi hi prakṛtaṃ bhūtayoniṃ śārīrādvilakṣaṇatvena ' divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ /
analyzed: viśinaṣṭi hi prakṛtam bhūtayonim śārīrāt vilakṣaṇa tvena divyaḥ hi amūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sa bāhya abhyantaraḥ hi ajaḥ
translated: For the source of beings, which is the subject, is distinguished from the embodied one as different: 'The divine, indeed, is the unembodied Purusha, who is both internal and external, and is unborn.

analyzed: a prāṇaḥ hi a manāḥ śubhraḥ muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: He is without breath, without mind, pure.' (Mundaka Upanishad 1.1.4-5).

analyzed: nahi etat divya ādi viśeṣaṇam avidyā pratyupasthāpita nāma rūpa pariccheda abhimāninaḥ tad dharmān sva ātmani kalpayataḥ śārīrasya upapadyate
translated: For this qualification of being divine etc. does not apply to the embodied one, who imagines the attributes of name-and-form, which are superimposed by ignorance, as his own self.

analyzed: tasmāt sākṣāt aupaniṣadaḥ puruṣaḥ iha ucyate
translated: Therefore the person who is directly referred to in the Upaniṣads is spoken of here.

original: tathā pradhānādapi prakṛtaṃ bhūtayoniṃ bhedena vyapadiśati 'akṣarātparataḥ paraḥ' iti /
analyzed: tathā pradhānāt api prakṛtam bhūtayonim bhedena vyapadiśati akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti
translated: Similarly, it designates the primal matter, the source of the elements, as different from the pradhāna, saying, Higher than the Imperishable.

original: akṣaramavyākṛtaṃ nāmarūpabījaśaktirūpaṃ bhūtasūkṣmamīśvarāśrayaṃ tasyaivopādhibhūtaṃ🔽sarvasmādvikārātparo yo 'vikārastasmātparataḥ para iti bhedena vyapadeśātparamātmānamiha
analyzed: akṣaram avyākṛtam nāma rūpa bīja śakti rūpam bhūta sūkṣmam īśvara āśrayam tasya eva upādhi bhūtam  sarvasmāt vikārāt paraḥ yaḥ vikāraḥ tasmāt paratas paraḥ iti bhedena vyapadeśāt paramātmānam iha
translated: The Imperishable is the subtle body of the elements, which is the seed of name and form, the power of manifestation, and is the limiting adjunct of the Lord himself.

analyzed: vivakṣitam darśayati
translated: It is said to be higher than all evolutes, as it is the unevolved. Higher than the highest designates it as different, showing that the highest Self is intended here.

original: nātra pradhānaṃ nāma kiñcitsvatantraṃ tattvamabhyupagamya tasmādbhedavyapadeśa ucyate /
analyzed: na atra pradhānam nāma kiñcid svatantram tattvam abhyupagamya tasmāt bheda vyapadeśaḥ ucyate
translated: Here, no independent principle called pradhāna is accepted, and its difference is not stated from that.

original: kiṃ tarhi yadi pradhānamapi kalpyamānaṃ śrutyavirodhenāvyākṛtādiśabdavācyaṃ bhūtasūkṣmaṃ parikalpyeta parikalpyatām /
analyzed: kim tarhi yadi pradhānam api kalpyamānam śruti avirodhena avyākṛta ādi śabda vācyam bhūta sūkṣmam parikalpyeta parikalpyatām
translated: What then? If the pradhāna, even when imagined, can be conceived as the subtle body of the elements, denoted by words like unevolved, without contradicting the scriptures, let it be imagined.

analyzed: tasmāt bheda vyapadeśāt parameśvaraḥ bhūtayoniḥ iti etat iha pratipādyate  /
translated: Therefore, from the designation of difference, it is taught here that the highest Lord is the source of the elements.

analyzed: kutas ca parameśvaraḥ bhūtayoniḥ
translated: And from what other than the highest Lord is the source of the elements?

analyzed: aśnoti vyāpnoti sva vikāra jātam iti akṣara
translated: The Imperishable is that which pervades its own evolved creation.

analyzed: avyākṛtam avyaktam
translated: The unevolved is the unmanifest.

analyzed: nāma rūpayoḥ bījam īśvaraḥ tasya śakti rūpam
translated: The seed of name and form is the Lord, in the form of His power.

analyzed: rūpa upanyāsāt ca
translated: And because form is mentioned.🔽Moreover, immediately after the passage Beyond the Imperishable, the Supreme, the creation of the principles beginning with Prana

original: apica 'akṣarātparataḥ paraḥ' ityasyānantaram 'etasmājjāyate prāṇaḥ' iti prāṇaprabhṛtīnāṃ
analyzed: api ca akṣarāt paratas paraḥ iti asya anantaram etasmāt jāyate prāṇaḥ iti prāṇa prabhṛtīnām

analyzed: pṛthivī paryantānām tatvānām sargam uktvā tasya eva bhūtayoneḥ sarva vikāra ātmakam rūpam upanyasyamānam

analyzed: paśyāmaḥ agniḥ mūrdhā cakṣuṣī candra sūryau diśaḥ śrotre vāc vivṛtāḥ ca vedāḥ
translated: Fire is the head, the eyes are the moon and sun, the directions are the ears, speech is the revealed Vedas,

original: vāyuḥ prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhyāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā' muṇḍa / / / iti /

analyzed: tat ca parameśvarasya eva ucitam

analyzed: sarva vikāra kāraṇa tvāt  na śārīrasya tanu mahimnaḥ
translated: Because He is the cause of all modifications.🔽Not for the embodied one, whose body is limited.

analyzed: na api pradhānasya ayam rūpa upanyāsaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: Nor is this presentation of form possible for Pradhana.

analyzed: sarva bhūta antarātma tva asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because it cannot be the inner Self of all beings.

analyzed: tasmāt parameśvaraḥ eva bhūtayoniḥ na itarau iti gamyate

analyzed: katham punar bhūtayoneḥ ayam rūpa upanyāsaḥ iti gamyate

analyzed: bhūta yonim hi prakṛtyāḥ etasmāt jāyate prāṇaḥ

analyzed: anye punar manyante na ayam bhūtayoneḥ rūpa upanyāsaḥ

analyzed: etasmāt jāyate prāṇaḥ manaḥ sarva indriyāṇi ca

original: athātmaśabdasāmānādhikaraṇyādupakrame ca 'ko na ātmā kiṃ brahma' iti kevalātmaśabdaprayogādātmaśabdavaśena ca vaiśvānaraśabdaḥ pariṇeya ityucyate /

translated: Now, if it be said that the word Vaiśvānara is to be taken in its secondary sense, on account of the word Ātman occurring in apposition with it, and on account of the question being asked in the passage, Who is the Ātman? what is Brahman? , where the word Ātman is used by itself, we reply that the word Vaiśvānara is not to be taken in a secondary sense, on account of the word Ātman occurring in apposition with it; for the word Ātman is to be taken in its primary sense, on account of the word Vaiśvānara occurring in apposition with it

analyzed: antarikṣam ca tayoḥ madhyam ātatāna sa devaḥ dyu loka ādi avayavaḥ dhyeyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: And the atmosphere between them he has spread out. That God, who is a part of the heavenly world etc., should be meditated upon - this is the meaning.

analyzed: yat yaḥ
translated: He who.

analyzed: puruṣaḥ pūrṇaḥ
translated: The complete Person.

analyzed: yaḥ veda sa sarvatra bhuṅkte
translated: He who knows, he enjoys everywhere.

original: ata eva na devatā bhūtaṃ ca / / / /
analyzed: atas eva na devatā bhūtam ca
translated: For this very reason, he is not a deity, nor an element.

original: yatpunaruktaṃ bhūtāgnerapi mantravarṇe dyulokādisaṃbandhadarśanānmūrdhaiva sutejā ityādyavayavakalpanaṃ tasyaiva bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: yat punar uktam bhūtāgneḥ api mantravarṇe dyu loka ādi saṃbandha darśanāt mūrdhā eva su tejāḥ iti ādi avayava kalpanam tasya eva bhaviṣyati iti
translated: Again, it has been said that since the connection with the heavenly world etc. is seen in the description of the mantras even of the elemental fire, the postulation of parts like the head itself is very bright will apply to it alone.

analyzed: yat śarīrāyāḥ devatāyāḥ vaiśvarya yogāt iti
translated: Because of the association of lordship with the deity whose body is that.

analyzed: tat parihartavyam
translated: That should be refuted.

original: atrocyate ata evoktebhyo hetubhyo na devatā vaiśvānaraḥ /
analyzed: atrā ucyate atas eva uktebhyaḥ hetubhyaḥ na devatā vaiśvānaraḥ
translated: Here it is said: For this very reason, the deity is not Vaisvanara, because of the reasons stated.

analyzed: tathā bhūta agniḥ api na vaiśvānaraḥ
translated: Similarly, the elemental fire also is not Vaisvanara.

analyzed: nahi bhūtāgneḥ auṣṇya prakāśa mātra ātmakasya dyu mūrdha tva ādi kalpanā upapadyate
translated: For the postulation of the head being the light etc. of the elemental fire, which consists of mere heat and light, is not possible.

analyzed: vikārasya vikāra antara ātma tva asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is not possible for a modification to be of the nature of another modification.

original: tathā devatāyāḥ satyapyaiśvaryayoge na dyumūrdhatvādikalpanā saṃbhavati /
analyzed: tathā devatāyāḥ sati api aiśvarya yoge na dyumūrdha tva ādi kalpanā saṃbhavati
translated: And similarly, even though the deity has the quality of sovereignty, it is not possible to imagine it as having a luminous head, etc.

analyzed: akāraṇa tvāt parameśvara adhīna aiśvarya tvāt ca
translated: Because it is not the cause, and because its sovereignty depends on the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: ātma śabda asaṃbhavaḥ ca sarveṣu eṣu pakṣeṣu sthitaḥ eva
translated: And the impossibility of the word self remains in all these views.

analyzed: sākṣāt api avirodham jaiminiḥ
translated: Jaimini thinks that there is no contradiction even in the direct [identification].

original: pūrve jāṭharāgnipratīko jāṭharāgnyupādhiko vā parameśvara upāsya ityuktamantaḥpratiṣṭhitatvādyanurodhena /
analyzed: pūrve jāṭhara agni pratīkaḥ jāṭhara agni upādhikaḥ vā parameśvaraḥ upāsyaḥ iti uktam antar pratiṣṭhita tva ādi anurodhena
translated: It has been said earlier that the Supreme Lord is to be worshipped as symbolized by the gastric fire or as qualified by the gastric fire, in accordance with the statements about being established within, etc.

original: idānīṃ tu vinaiva pratīkopādhikalpanābhyāṃ sākṣādapi parameśvaropāsanaparigrahe na kaścidvirodha iti jaiminirācāryo manyante /
analyzed: idānīm tu vinā eva pratīka upādhi kalpanābhyām sākṣāt api parameśvara upāsana parigrahe na kaścid virodhaḥ iti jaiminiḥ ācāryaḥ manyante
translated: Now, however, the teacher Jaimini thinks that even without the need for the concepts of symbol and qualification, there is no contradiction at all in accepting the worship of the Supreme Lord directly.

original: nanu jāṭharāgnyaparigrahe 'ntaḥpratiṣṭhitatvavacanaṃ śabdadīni ca kāraṇāni virudhyeranniti /
analyzed: nanu jāṭhara agni aparigrahe ntar pratiṣṭhita tva vacanam śabda dīni ca kāraṇāni virudhyeran iti
translated: But if the gastric fire is not accepted, the statement about being established within and the reasons such as the word light would be contradicted.

analyzed: atrā ucyate antar pratiṣṭhita tva vacanam tāvat na virudhyate
translated: To this it is said: The statement about being established within is not contradicted.

analyzed: nahi iha puruṣavidham puruṣe ntar pratiṣṭhitam veda iti jāṭhara agni abhiprāyeṇa idam ucyate
translated: For here it is not said with reference to the gastric fire that one should know him as established within the person in the form of the person.

original: tasyāprakṛtatvādasaṃśabditatvācca /🔽kathaṃ tarhi yatprakṛtaṃ mūrdhādicubukānteṣu puruṣāvayaveṣu puruṣavidhitvaṃ kalpitaṃ tadabhiprāyeṇedamucyate 'puruṣavidhaṃ puruṣe 'ntaḥpratiṣṭhitaṃ
analyzed: tasya a prakṛta tvāt a saṃśabdita tvāt ca  katham tarhi yat prakṛtam mūrdha ādi cubuka anteṣu puruṣa avayaveṣu puruṣa vidhi tvam kalpitam tad abhiprāyeṇa idam ucyate puruṣavidham puruṣe ntar pratiṣṭhitam
translated: Because it is not the topic, and because it is not mentioned.

analyzed: veda iti
translated: But how then is the fact that the individual soul is conceived to be of the form of the individual soul in the parts of the individual soul, beginning with the head and ending with the chin, to be understood? With reference to that, it is said, 'One should know that which is of the form of the individual soul, established within the individual soul.'

original: yathā vṛkṣe śākhāṃ pratiṣṭhitāṃ paśyatīti tadvat /
analyzed: yathā vṛkṣe śākhām pratiṣṭhitām paśyati iti tadvat
translated: Just as one sees a branch established in a tree, so is it.

original: athavā yaḥ prakṛtaḥ paramātmādhyātmamadhidaivataṃ ca puruṣavidhitvopādhistasya yatkevalaṃ sākṣirūpaṃ tadabhiprāyeṇedamucyate 'puruṣe 'ntaḥpratiṣṭhitaṃ 🔽veda' iti /

translated: Or else, that which is the topic, the supreme self, which is the limiting adjunct of the form of the individual soul, both in the individual soul and in the supreme deity, with reference to its mere witness form, it is said, 'One should know that which is established within the individual soul.'

original: niścite ca pūrvāparālocanavaśena paramātmaparigrahe tadviṣaya eva vaiśvānaraśabdaḥ kenacidyogena vartiṣyate /🔽viśvaścāyaṃ naraśceti /
analyzed: niścite ca pūrva apara ālocana vaśena paramātma parigrahe tad viṣayaḥ eva vaiśvānara śabdaḥ kenacid yogena vartiṣyate  viśvaḥ ca ayam naraḥ ca iti
translated: And when the supreme self is ascertained by the power of considering the beginning and end, the word 'Vaiśvānara' will apply to it in some way.🔽This is the all and the man.

analyzed: viśveṣām vā ayam naraḥ
translated: This is the man of the all.

analyzed: viśve vā narāḥ asya iti viśvānaraḥ
translated: Or the all are the men of this, thus it is Vaiśvānara.

analyzed: paramātmā
translated: The supreme self.

analyzed: sarva ātma tvāt

analyzed: viśvānaraḥ eva vaiśvānaraḥ

analyzed: taddhitaḥ na anya arthaḥ

analyzed: rākṣasa vāyasa ādi vat
translated: Like Rākṣasa and Vāyasa.

analyzed: agni śabdaḥ pi agraṇī tva ādi yoga āśrayaṇena paramātma viṣayaḥ eva bhaviṣyati

analyzed: yathā prastha mita yavāḥ prasthāḥ iti ucyante tadvat

translated: And although in the case of barley, the inherent measure is manifested by the connection with the prastha,

analyzed: evam anusmṛti nimittā parameśvare prādeśa mātra śrutiḥ iti bādariḥ ācāryaḥ manyate

original: iti śrīmacchaṅkarabhagavatpādakṛtau śārīrakamīmāṃsābhāṣye prathamādhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrīmat śaṅkara bhagavat pāda kṛtau śārīraka mīmāṃsā bhāṣye prathama adhyāyasya dvitīyaḥ pādaḥ  /
translated: Thus ends the second chapter of the first section of the commentary on the Vedānta Sūtras composed by the revered Śaṅkara.

original: FN / avimukte avidyopādhikalpitāvacchede jīvātmi bhedakalpanayā pratiṣṭhita upāsyaḥ /
analyzed: avimukte avidyā upādhi kalpita avacchede bheda kalpanayā pratiṣṭhitaḥ upāsyaḥ
translated: In the undivided, which is the individual soul limited by the adjuncts of ignorance, one should worship by imagining the difference.

analyzed: varaṇā bhrūḥ
translated: The eyebrows are the barrier.

analyzed: vimīyate jñāyate  abhivimīmīte nirmimīte
translated: It is measured, known.🔽It is measured by all, it is created.

analyzed: prathama adhyāye tṛtīyaḥ pādaḥ
translated: In the first chapter, the third section.

analyzed: atra aspaṣṭa brahma liṅgānām prāyas jñeya brahma viṣayāṇām vicāraḥ
translated: Here, the discussion is mainly about the Brahman to be known, which has unclear indications of Brahman.

analyzed: evam pāda trayeṇa api vākya vicāraḥ
translated: Thus, the consideration of the sentence is also by the three sections.

analyzed: dyu bhū ādi adhikaraṇam sū
translated: The section on Dyu, Bhu, etc. Sutra.

analyzed: dyu bhū ādi āyatanam sva śabdāt  /
translated: The abode of Dyu, Bhu, etc. is by its own word.

original: idaṃ śrūyate 'yasmindyauḥ pṛthivī cāntarikṣamotaṃ manaḥ saha prāṇaiśca sarvaiḥ /
analyzed: idam śrūyate yasmin dyauḥ pṛthivī ca antarikṣam ā utam manaḥ saha prāṇaiḥ ca sarvaiḥ
translated: This is heard: In whom heaven, earth, and the atmosphere are contained, along with the mind and all the vital airs,

original: tamevaikaṃ jānatha ātmānamanyā vāco vimucyathāmṛtasyaiṣa setuḥ' muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: tam eva ekam jānatha ātmānam anyāḥ vācaḥ vimucyatha amṛtasya eṣa setuḥ muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: Know that One only to be the Self, and let go of other words. This is the dam of immortality.' (Mundaka Upanishad 1.2.7)

analyzed: atra yat etat dyu prabhṛtīnām ota tva vacanāt āyatanam kiñcid avagamyate
translated: Here, some abode is understood from the statement that the sun and so on are woven.

analyzed: tat kim param brahma syāt āhosvit artha antaram iti saṃdihyate
translated: Is that the supreme Brahman, or is it something else? This is doubted.

analyzed: tatra artha antaram kim api āyatanam syāt iti prāptam
translated: There, it is concluded that some other abode should be accepted.

analyzed: kasmāt amṛtasya eṣa setuḥ iti śravaṇāt
translated: Why? Because it is heard as 'This is the dam of immortality.'

analyzed: pāravān hi loke setuḥ prakhyātaḥ
translated: For in the world, a dam is known to have a further shore.

original: naca parasya brahmaṇaḥ pāravattvaṃ śakyamabhyupagantuṃ /🔽'anantamapāram' bṛha / / /
analyzed: na ca parasya brahmaṇaḥ pāravat tvam śakyam abhyupagantum  anantam apāram bṛha
translated: And it is not possible to accept that the supreme Brahman has a further shore.

analyzed: iti śravaṇāt
translated: Because it is heard as 'infinite and boundless' (Brhadaranyaka Upanishad 2.1.1).

original: arthāntare cāyatane parigṛhyamāṇe smṛtiprasiddhaṃ pradhānaṃ parigrahītavyaṃ /
analyzed: artha antare ca āyatane parigṛhyamāṇe smṛti prasiddham pradhānam parigrahītavyam
translated: If something else is accepted as the abode, the prakriti known from smrti should be accepted.

analyzed: tasya kāraṇa tvāt āyatana tva upapatteḥ
translated: Because it is logically possible for it to be the abode, since it is the cause.

analyzed: śruti prasiddhaḥ vā vāyuḥ syāt
translated: Or the wind known from the Vedas may be accepted.

original: 'vāyurvai gautama tatsūtraṃ vāyunā vai gautama sūtreṇāyaṃ ca lokaḥ sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃdṛbdhāni bhavanti' bṛha / / /
analyzed: vāyuḥ vai gautama tat sūtram vāyunā vai gautama sūtreṇa ayam ca lokaḥ sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃdṛbdhāni bhavanti bṛha
translated: 'O Gautama, the wind is that thread. O Gautama, by the thread of the wind, this world and all beings are woven together.' (Chandogya Upanishad 8.1.1)

analyzed: iti vāyoḥ api vidhāraṇa tva śravaṇāt
translated: Thus, even from the wind, the quality of supporting is heard.

analyzed: śārīraḥ vā syāt
translated: Or it may be the embodied Self.

original: tasyāpi bhoktṛtvādbhogyaṃ prapañcaṃ pratyāyatanatvopapatterityevaṃ prāpta idamāha dyubhvādyāyatanamiti /
analyzed: tasya api bhoktṛ tvāt bhogyam prapañcam pratyāyatana tva upapatteḥ iti evam prāptaḥ idam āha dyu bhū ādi āyatanam iti
translated: Since that also is the experiencer, it is proper that the universe, which is to be experienced, should be its abode. Thus it is concluded. To this, it says: The abode of heaven, earth, etc.

original: dyauśca bhūśca dyubhuvau dyubhuvāvādī yasya tadidaṃ dyubhvādi /
analyzed: dyauḥ ca bhūḥ ca dyu bhuvau dyu bhuvau ādī yasya tat idam dyu bhu ādi
translated: Heaven and earth are the two worlds. That which has heaven and earth as its beginning is this heaven, earth, etc.

original: yadetadasminvākye dyauḥ pṛthivyantarikṣaṃ manaḥ prāṇā ityevamasmākaṃ jagadotatvena nirdiṣṭaṃ tasyāyatanaṃ paraṃ brahma bhavitumarhati /
analyzed: yat etat asmin vākye dyauḥ pṛthivī antarikṣam manaḥ prāṇāḥ iti evam asmākam jagat ota tvena nirdiṣṭam tasya āyatanam param brahma bhavitum arhati
translated: That which is indicated as the universe in this sentence - heaven, earth, space, mind, life-breath, etc. - its abode should be the supreme Brahman.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: sva śabdāt ātma śabdāt iti arthaḥ
translated: From its own word. The meaning is from the word 'Self'.

original: ātmaśabdo hīha bhavati 'tamevaikaṃ jānatha ātmānam' iti /
analyzed: ātma śabdaḥ hi iha bhavati tam eva ekam jānatha ātmānam iti
translated: For this word 'Self' occurs here: 'Know that Self alone'.

analyzed: ātma śabdaḥ ca paramātma parigrahe samyak avakalpate na artha antara parigrahe
translated: And the word 'Self' is properly applicable to the supreme Self, not to anything else.

original: kvacicca svaśabdenaiva brahmaṇa āyatanatvaṃ śrūyate' sanmūlāḥ somyemāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sadāyatanāḥ satpratiṣṭhāḥ' chā / / / iti /
analyzed: kvacid ca sva śabdena eva brahmaṇaḥ āyatana tvam śrūyate sat mūlāḥ somya imāḥ sarvāḥ prajāḥ sat āyatanāḥ sat pratiṣṭhāḥ chā iti
translated: And in some places, the abode-ness of Brahman is heard by its own word: 'All these beings, my child, have their root in Being, their abode in Being, their goal in Being' (Ch. U. 5.10.1).

original: svaśabdenaiva ceha purastādupariṣṭācca brahma saṃkīrtyate 'puruṣa evedaṃ viśvaṃ karma tapo brahma parāmṛtam' iti /
analyzed: sva śabdena eva ca iha purastāt upariṣṭāt ca brahma saṃkīrtyate puruṣaḥ eva idam viśvam karma tapaḥ brahma para amṛtam iti
translated: And Brahman is mentioned by its own name in the passages above and below, This universe is that person, action, austerity, Brahman, the highest immortality

original: 'brahmaivedamamṛtaṃ purastādbrahma paścādbrahma dakṣiṇaścottareṇa' muṇḍa / / / iti ca /🔽tatra tvāyatanāyatanayadbhāvaśravaṇāt /
analyzed: brahma eva idam amṛtam purastāt brahma paścāt brahma dakṣiṇaḥ ca uttareṇa muṇḍaḥ iti ca  tatra tu āyatana āyatana yadbhāva śravaṇāt
translated: And Brahman is mentioned by its own name in the passages quoted above and below, This universe is only the manifestation of the one Person, his work, his austerity, his Brahman, his immortality, and, Brahman is immortal, Brahman is in the east, Brahman is in the west, Brahman is in the south, Brahman is in the north Mu Up , , 0🔽Here, however, the doubt may arise that Brahman is manifold, because the text speaks of the abode and the nonabode, and because the text ascribes to Brahman the quality of being the abode of all things, in the passage, In it all this has its abode, by which it abides Ch Up , , 0

analyzed: sarvam brahma iti ca sāmānādhikaraṇyāt
translated: And because the text speaks of Brahman as the object of the copulative compound, all is Brahman, in the passage, All this is Brahman, all this is Self Bṛ Up , , 0

original: yathānekātmako vṛkṣaḥ śākhā skandho mūlaṃ cetyevaṃ nānāraso vicitra ātmetyāśaṅkā saṃbhavati /
analyzed: yathā aneka ātmakaḥ vṛkṣaḥ śākhā skandhaḥ mūlam ca iti evam nānā rasaḥ vicitraḥ ātmā iti āśaṅkā saṃbhavati
translated: Thus the doubt may arise that the Self is manifold, of various nature, like a tree which has many branches, a trunk, and roots

original: tāṃ nivartayituṃ sāvadhāraṇamāha 'tamevaikaṃ jānatha ātmānam' iti /
analyzed: tām nivartayitum sa avadhāraṇam āha tam eva ekam jānatha ātmānam iti
translated: In order to remove this doubt the text declares with reference to the Self, Know that one only to be the Self Bṛ Up , , 0

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati na kāryaprapañcaviśiṣṭo vicitra ātmā vijñeyaḥ /
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati na kārya prapañca viśiṣṭaḥ vicitraḥ ātmā vijñeyaḥ
translated: The meaning of this is that the Self is not to be known as qualified by the manifold world of effects

analyzed: kin tarhi avidyā kṛtam kārya prapañcam vidyayā pravilāpayantaḥ tam eva ekam āyatana bhūtam ātmānam jānatha ekarasam iti
translated: But rather, having by true knowledge dissolved the manifold world of effects which is the product of Nescience, know that one only which is the abode of all things, and which is of one uniform nature

original: yathā yasmānnāste devadattastadānayetyukta āsanamevānayati na devadattam /
analyzed: yathā yasmāt na āste devadattaḥ tadā ānaya iti ukte āsanam eva ānayati na devadattam
translated: Just as when it is said, Bring Devadatta, because he is not present, one brings only the seat, not Devadatta

analyzed: tadvat āyatana bhūtasya eva eka rasasya ātmanaḥ vijñeya tvam upadiśyate
translated: In the same way, it is taught that the Self, which is the abode, is of one essence, and is to be known.

original: vikārānṛtābhisaṃdhasya cāpavādaḥ śrūyate 'mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyumāpnoti ya iha nāneva paśyati' kā / / / iti /
analyzed: vikāra anṛta abhisaṃdhasya ca apavādaḥ śrūyate mṛtyoḥ sa mṛtyum āpnoti yaḥ iha nānā iva paśyati kā iti
translated: And it is heard that there is a prohibition for one who clings to the untruth of modification: 'He who sees diversity here attains death from death' (Ka. 2.1.10).

original: sarvaṃ brahmeti tu sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ prapañcapravilāpanārthaṃ nānekarasatāpratipādanārtham /
analyzed: sarvam brahma iti tu sāmānādhikaraṇyam prapañca pravilāpana artham na aneka rasa tā pratipādana artham
translated: But the statement 'all is Brahman' in the same way is for the purpose of dissolving the world, not for the purpose of teaching that there is not one essence.

original: 'sa yathā saindhavaghano 'nantaro 'bāhyaḥ kṛtsno rasaghana evaivaṃ vā are 'yamātmānantaro 'bāhyaḥ kṛtsnaḥ prajñānaghana eva' bṛha / / /
analyzed: sa yathā saindhava ghanaḥ nantaraḥ bāhyaḥ kṛtsnaḥ rasa ghanaḥ eva evam vai are yam ātmā anantaraḥ bāhyaḥ kṛtsnaḥ prajñāna ghanaḥ eva bṛha
translated: 'As the lump of salt is not internal or external, but is entirely a mass of taste, so, my dear, is this Self not internal or external, but is entirely a mass of knowledge' (Br. 4.5.13).

analyzed: iti eka rasa tā śravaṇāt
translated: Thus, because it is heard that it is of one essence.

analyzed: tasmāt dyubhva ādi āyatanam param brahma
translated: Therefore, the abode of heaven, earth, etc. is the supreme Brahman.

original: yattūktaṃ / setuśruteḥ setośca pāravattvopapatterbrahmaṇor'thāntareṇa dyubhvādyāyatanena bhavitavyamiti /
analyzed: yat tu uktam setu śruteḥ setoḥ ca pāravat tva upapatteḥ brahmaṇā ūrtha antareṇa dyubhvā ādi āyatanena bhavitavyam iti
translated: But it has been said that because of the mention of a dam and because it is proper that the dam should have a further shore, the abode of heaven, earth, etc. must be something other than Brahman.

original: atrocyate vidhāraṇatvamātramatra setuśrutyā vivakṣyate na pāravattvādi /
analyzed: atrā ucyate vidhāraṇa tva mātram atra setu śrutyāḥ vivakṣyate na pāravat tva ādi
translated: To this it is said: here, by the mention of the dam, only the quality of holding is intended, not having a further shore, etc.

original: nahi mṛddārumayo loke seturdṛṣṭa ityatrāpi mṛddārumaya evaseturabhyupagamyate /
analyzed: nahi mṛd dāru mayaḥ loke setuḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti atra api mṛd dāru mayaḥ eva setuḥ abhyupagamyate
translated: For in the world a dam made of clay or wood is not seen, yet here also a dam made of clay or wood is accepted.

original: setuśabdārtho 'pi vidhāraṇatvamātrameva na pāravattvādi ṣiño bandhanakarmaṇaḥ setuśabdavyutpatteḥ /
analyzed: setu śabda arthaḥ pi vidhāraṇa tva mātram eva na pāravat tva ādi bandhana karmaṇaḥ setu śabda vyutpatteḥ
translated: And the meaning of the word 'dam' is merely the act of holding back, not having a shore, etc., because the word 'dam' is derived from the root 'si' meaning to bind.

original: apara āha 'tamevaikaṃ jānatha ātmānam' iti yadetatsaṃkīrtitamātmajñānaṃ /
analyzed: aparaḥ āha tam eva ekam jānatha ātmānam iti yat etat saṃkīrtitam ātma jñānam
translated: Another says: That knowledge of the Self which is referred to here by the statement 'Know that One Self alone',

analyzed: yat ca etat anyāḥ vācaḥ vimuñcathaḥ iti vāc vimocanam  tat atra amṛta tva sādhana tvāt
translated: and that release from speech which is referred to by the statement 'Release speech from other things',🔽that is referred to here by the statement 'This is the dam of immortality' as the means of attaining immortality,

original: 'amṛtasyaiṣa setuḥ' iti setuśrutyā saṃkīrtyate na tu dyubhvādyāyatanam /
analyzed: amṛtasya eṣa setuḥ iti setu śrutyā saṃkīrtyate na tu dyu bhu ādi āyatanam
translated: but not the abode of heaven, earth, etc., by the reference to it as a dam.

analyzed: tatra yat uktam setu śruteḥ brahmaṇā ūrtha antareṇa dyubhvā ādi āyatanena bhāvyam iti etat ayuktam  /
translated: Therefore what was said, that because of the reference to it as a dam, the abode of heaven, earth, etc., must be something different from Brahman, is not correct.

original: FN / amṛtasyeti śravaṇāt seturiti śravaṇāditi yojanā /
analyzed: amṛtasya iti śravaṇāt setuḥ iti śravaṇāt iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: because of the hearing of 'of immortality' and because of the hearing of 'dam'.

analyzed: setuḥ iti śravaṇāt iti vyācaṣṭhe pāravān hi iti
translated: He explains the hearing of 'dam' by saying 'because of the hearing of dam, it is one having a shore'.

analyzed: saṃdṛbdhani saṃgrathitāni
translated: The bonds are tied together.

analyzed: sāmānādhikaraṇyāt vicitraḥ ātmā iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The connection is: the Self is variegated, because of the co-reference.

original: vikāre 'nṛte kalpite abhisaṃdho 'bhimāno yasya /🔽sinoti badhnātīti setuḥ /🔽padārthaikadeśo vidhāraṇamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: vikāre kalpite abhisaṃdhaḥ bhimānaḥ yasya  sinoti badhnāti iti setuḥ  padārtha eka deśaḥ vidhāraṇam iti arthaḥ
translated: He who has a purpose, an intention, in regard to a modification which is unreal, imagined.🔽A dam is that which binds, i.e. it is a part of the object which holds back.🔽The meaning is: a part of the object which holds back.

analyzed: mukta upasṛpya vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because it is spoken of as the goal of the liberated.

analyzed: itas ca param eva brahma dyubhva ādi āyatanam
translated: And for this reason also, the highest Brahman is the abode of the syllable 'dyauḥ' etc.

analyzed: yasmāt mukta upasṛpya tā asya vyapadiśyamānā dṛśyate
translated: Because its being the goal of the liberated is seen to be spoken of.

analyzed: muktaiḥ upasṛpyam mukta upasṛpyam
translated: The goal of the liberated is the goal of those who are liberated.

analyzed: deha ādiṣu anātmasu aham asmi iti ātma buddhiḥ avidyā
translated: Ignorance is the notion of the self in the non-self, such as the body, thinking 'I am this'.

original: tatastatpūjanādau rāgastatparibhavādau dveṣastaducchedadarśanādbhayaṃ mohaścetyevamayamanantabhedo 'narthavrātaḥ saṃtataḥ sarveṣāṃ naḥ pratyakṣaḥ
analyzed: tatas tad pūjana ādau rāgaḥ tad paribhava ādau dveṣaḥ tad uccheda darśanāt bhayam mohaḥ ca iti evam ayam ananta bhedaḥ nartha vrātaḥ saṃtataḥ sarveṣām naḥ pratyakṣaḥ
translated: From that, there is attachment to its worship etc., aversion to its insult etc., and delusion from seeing its destruction - thus this endless multitude of evils, which is manifest to all of us, is continuous.

analyzed: tad viparyayeṇa avidyā rāga dveṣa ādi doṣa muktaiḥ upasṛpyam gamyam etat iti dyu bhvā ādi āyatanam prakṛtya vyapadeśaḥ bhavati
translated: When that is reversed, there is the designation that this is the abode of the syllable 'dyauḥ' etc., which is to be reached by those who are free from the faults of ignorance, attachment, aversion etc.

analyzed: katham bhidyate hṛdaya granthiḥ chidyante sarva saṃśayāḥ
translated: How so? 'The knot of the heart is broken, all doubts are cut off,

original: kṣīyante cāsya karmāṇi tasmindṛṣṭe parāvare' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: kṣīyante ca asya karmāṇi tasmin dṛṣṭe parāvare muṇḍa
translated: and his actions are destroyed when the highest and the lowest is seen' (Mu. 3.2.8).

original: ityuktvā bravīti 'tathā vidvānnāmarūpādvimuktaḥ parātparaṃ puruṣamupaiti divyam' muṇḍa / / / iti /
analyzed: iti uktvā bravīti tathā vidvān nāma rūpāt vimuktaḥ parātparam puruṣam upaiti divyam muṇḍaḥ iti
translated: Having said this, he says, 'The knower of Brahman, being released from name and form, attains the divine Purusha who is higher than the high.' (Mundaka Upanishad 3.2.8)

original: brahmaṇaśca muktopasṛpyatvaṃ prasiddhaṃ śāstre 'yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye 'sya hṛdi śritāḥ /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ ca mukta upasṛpya tvam prasiddham śāstre yadā sarve pramucyante kāmāḥ ye hṛdi śritāḥ
translated: And it is well known in the scriptures that Brahman is to be attained by the liberated souls: 'When all the desires that lie in the heart are removed,

original: atha martyo 'mṛto bhavatyatra brahma samaśnute' bṛha / / /
analyzed: atha martyaḥ mṛtaḥ bhavati atra brahma samaśnute bṛha
translated: then the mortal becomes immortal, and attains Brahman here.' (Katha Upanishad 2.3.14)

analyzed: iti evamādau
translated: And so on.

analyzed: pradhāna ādīnām tu na kvacid mukta upasṛpyam asti prasiddham
translated: But in the case of Pradhana and others, there is no well-known attainment by the liberated souls anywhere.

original: apica 'tamevaikaṃ jānatha ātmānamanyā vāco vimuñcathāmṛtasyaiva setuḥ' iti vāgvimokapūrvakaṃ vijñeyatvamiha dyubhvādyāyatanasyocyate /
analyzed: apica tam eva ekam jānatha ātmānam anyāḥ vācaḥ vimuñcatha amṛtasya eva setuḥ iti vāc vimoka pūrvakam vijñeya tvam iha dyubhva ādi āyatanasya ucyate
translated: Moreover, here in the Dyaus and Bhurja section, the substratum is said to be knowable after the renunciation of other words, as in 'Know that One alone as the Self, and release other words. It is the very bridge of immortality.'

original: tacca śrutyantare brahmaṇo dṛṣṭam 'tameva dhīro vijñāya prajñāṃ kurvati brāhmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: tat ca śruti antare brahmaṇaḥ dṛṣṭam tam eva dhīraḥ vijñāya prajñām kurvati brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: And that is seen in another scripture of Brahman: 'The wise Brahmana, having known Him alone, makes wisdom.

original: nānudhyāyādvahūñśabdānvāco viglāpanaṃ hi tat' bṛha / / / iti /
analyzed: na anudhyāyāt vahūn śabdān vācaḥ viglāpanam hi tat bṛhaḥ iti
translated: He should not meditate on many words, for that is the distraction of speech.' (Taiitiriya Upanishad 2.4)

analyzed: tasmāt api dyubhva ādi āyatanam param brahma
translated: Therefore, the substratum of Dyaus and Bhurja is the Supreme Brahman.

analyzed: prajñā vākya artha dhī
translated: Wisdom is the understanding of the meaning of a sentence.

analyzed: brāhmaṇa padam anukta dvija upalakṣaṇam
translated: The word Brahmin is a metonym for the twice-born who are not mentioned.

analyzed: na anumānam a tad śabdāt  /
translated: Inference is not [acceptable], because there is no word for that.

original: atrocyate trimātreṇoṅkāreṇālambanena paramātmānamabhidhyāyataḥ phalaṃ brahmalokaprāptiḥ krameṇa ca samyagdarśanotpattiriti kramamuktyabhiprāyametadbhaviṣyatītyadoṣaḥ

original: 'atha yadidamasminbrahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharo 'sminnantarākāśastasminyadantastadanveṣṭavyaṃ tadbhāva vijijñāsitavyam' /

translated: There, the small space that is heard in the small heart-lotus, is it the elemental space or is it the individual soul or is it the supreme Self? This is doubted.

analyzed: kutas saṃśayaḥ
translated: From where is the doubt?

analyzed: ākāśa brahma pura śabdābhyām

original: ākāśaśabdo hyayaṃ bhūtākāśe parasmiṃśca prayujyamāno dṛśyate /

original: tathā brahmapuramiti kiṃ jīvo 'tra brahmanāmā tasyedaṃ puraṃ śarīraṃ brahmapuramathavā parasyaiva brahmaṇaḥ puraṃ brahmapuramiti /

analyzed: tasya ca dahara āyatana apekṣayā dahara tvam

translated: And the passage, As great as is this space within the heart, it is so great as this space is in the heaven, declares the internal space to be the object compared to, and the external space to be the object compared, the difference between them being due to the difference of their being internal and external, and it declares that heaven, earth, and so on are contained in the internal space

analyzed: avakāśa ātmanā ākāśasya eka tvāt

original: athavā jīvo dahara iti prāptam /🔽brahmapuraśabdāt /🔽jīvasya hīdaṃ puraṃ saccharīraṃ brahmapuramityucyate /🔽tasya svakarmaṇopārjitatvāt /
analyzed: athavā jīvaḥ daharaḥ iti prāptam  brahma pura śabdāt  jīvasya hi idam puram sat śarīram brahma puram iti ucyate  tasya sva karmaṇā upārjita tvāt
translated: Or else the small ether must be the individual soul,🔽because the word Brahman is used in the passage, The Brahman which is within the heart, smaller than a corn of rice, smaller than a corn of barley, smaller than a mustardseed, smaller than a grain of sesamum, smaller than a kernel of the sesamum🔽For the individual soul is called the Brahman which is within the heart, because it is the city of the Brahman, ie the body of Brahman, which is produced by its own works
