translated: The doubt as to the individual soul, which had arisen from the reflection of something else, has been set aside as impossible.

original: athedānīṃ mṛtasyevāmṛtasekātpunaḥ samutthānaṃ jīvāśaṅkāyāḥ kriyate uttarasmātprajāpatyādvākyāt /🔽tatrahi 'ya ātmāpahatapāpmā' ityapahatapāpmatvādiguṇakamātmānamanveṣṭavyaṃ vijijñāsitavyaṃ ca pratijñāya 'ya eṣo 'kṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyata eṣa
analyzed: atha idānīm mṛtasya iva amṛta sekāt punar samutthānam jīva āśaṅkāyāḥ kriyate uttarasmāt prajāpatyāt vākyāt  tatra hi yaḥ ātmā apahata pāpmā iti apahata pāpma tva ādi guṇakam ātmānam anveṣṭavyam vijijñāsitavyam ca pratijñāya yaḥ eṣa u kṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate eṣa
translated: Now, however, the doubt as to the individual soul is revived, as it were, rising again from the dead, by the subsequent passage from the Prajāpati doctrine.

original: chā / / / iti bruvannakṣisthaṃ draṣṭāraṃ jīvamātmānaṃ nirdiśati /
analyzed: iti bruvan nakṣi stham draṣṭāram jīvam ātmānam nirdiśati
translated: For there, having declared that the soul, which is endowed with the qualities of being free from sin, etc., is to be sought out and desired to be known, ‘He who is the person seen in the eye, he who is heard in the ear, he who is thought in the mind, he who is seen in the body, he is the Self, the immortal, the fearless. He is Brahman’ (Chānd. 8.7.1), it points out as the Self the individual soul, the seer residing in the eye.🔽‘He who is seen in the eye’—this shows that the individual soul is the object of perception.

analyzed: etam tu eva te bhūyas nuvyākhyāsyāmi chā
translated: 'But I will explain this matter to you again' (Ch. 7.2.2).🔽🔽

original: iti ca tameva punaḥ punaḥ parāmṛśya 'ya eṣa svapne mahīyamānaścaratyeṣa ātmā' chā / / /
analyzed: iti ca tam eva punar punar parāmṛśya yaḥ eṣa svapne mahīyamānaḥ carati eṣaḥ ātmā chā
translated: And again, in the passage, 'I will explain him further to you' (Ch. Up. 8, 1, 1), he refers again and again to the same individual soul.

original: iti 'tadyatraitatsuptaḥ samastaḥ saṃprasannaḥ svapnaṃ na vijānātyeṣa ātmā' iti ca jīvamevāvasthāntaragataṃ vyācaṣṭe /
analyzed: iti tat yatra etat suptaḥ samastaḥ saṃprasannaḥ svapnam na vijānāti eṣaḥ ātmā iti ca jīvam eva avasthā antara gatam vyācaṣṭe
translated: And in the passage, 'He who moves about, honoured in a dream, he is the Self' (Ch. Up. 8, 3, 1), and in the passage, 'When one is asleep, composed, and at rest, and sees no dream whatever, he is the Self' (Ch. Up. 8, 11, 1), he describes the individual soul only, which has entered into another state.

analyzed: tasya eva ca apahata pāpma tva ādi darśayati etat amṛtam abhayam etat brahma iti
translated: And he declares of the same soul that it is free from sin, and so on, in the passage, 'This is the immortal, the fearless, this is Brahman' (Ch. Up. 8, 12, 3).

original: nāhaṃ khalvayamevaṃ saṃpratyātmānaṃ jānātyayamahamasmīti no evemāni bhūtāni' chā / / / /🔽iti ca suṣuptāvasthāyāṃ doṣamupalabhya 'etaṃ tveva te bhūyo 'nuvyākhyāsyāmi no evānyatraitasmāt
analyzed: na aham khalu ayam evam saṃprati ātmānam jānāti ayam aham asmi iti na u eva imāni bhūtāni chā  iti ca suṣupta avasthāyām doṣam upalabhya etam tu eva te bhūyas nuvyākhyāsyāmi no eva anyatra etasmāt
translated: And in the passage, 'Verily, I do not know him as I am he, nor do these beings' (Ch. Up. 8, 11, 1), he points out a defect in the state of deep sleep.

analyzed: iti ca upakramya śarīra saṃbandha nindā pūrvakam eṣa saṃprasādaḥ smāt śarīrāt samutthāya
translated: And in the passage, 'I will explain him further to you, not otherwise than he is' (Ch. Up. 8, 12, 1), he begins by saying, 'I will explain him further to you, not otherwise than he is,' and then, after censuring the connection with the body, he declares, 'This tranquil soul, having risen from this body,

original: paraṃ jyotirupasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyate sa uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ' iti jīvameva
analyzed: param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate saḥ uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ iti jīvam eva
translated: having attained the highest light, becomes manifest in its own form. That is the highest person' (Ch. Up. 8, 12, 3).🔽And in the passage, 'This Self indeed is to be seen, to be heard about, to be perceived, and to be known;

analyzed: śarīrāt samutthitam uttamapuruṣam darśayati
translated: It shows the highest Person to have risen from the body.

analyzed: tasmāt asti saṃbhavaḥ jīve pārameśvarāṇām dharmāṇām
translated: Therefore, it is possible for the qualities of the Supreme Lord to exist in the individual soul.

original: ataḥ 'daharo 'sminnantarākāśaḥ' iti jīva evokta iti cetkaścidbrūyāt /
analyzed: atas daharaḥ smin antarākāśaḥ iti jīvaḥ eva uktaḥ iti ced kaścid brūyāt
translated: If someone were to say that therefore the individual soul alone is referred to in the statement the small space within,

analyzed: tam prati brūyāt āvirbhūta svarūpaḥ tu iti
translated: to him one should say: But he whose nature has become manifest.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ pūrva pakṣa vyāvṛtti arthaḥ
translated: The word but is for the purpose of excluding the prima facie view.

analyzed: na uttarasmāt api vākyāt iha jīvasya āśaṅkā saṃbhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that even from the subsequent passage, there is no possibility of doubt regarding the individual soul here.

analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: yatas tatra api āvirbhūta svarūpaḥ jīvaḥ vivakṣyate
translated: Because there also, the individual soul whose nature has become manifest is intended.

analyzed: āvirbhūtam sva rūpam asya iti āvirbhūta svarūpaḥ
translated: He whose nature has become manifest is one whose nature has become manifest.

analyzed: bhūta pūrva gatyāḥ jīva vacanam
translated: The word individual soul is used in the sense of having existed before.

original: etaduktaṃ bhavati 'ya eṣo 'kṣiṇi ityakṣilakṣitaṃ draṣṭāraṃ nirdiśyodaśarāvabrāhmaṇenainaṃ
analyzed: etat uktam bhavati yaḥ eṣa u kṣiṇi iti akṣi lakṣitam draṣṭāram nirdiśya uda śarāva brāhmaṇena enam
translated: This is what is meant: He who is in the eye - having indicated the seer characterized by the eye, by the section on the udumbara post,🔽having made him rise above the state of being the self of the body, by saying But this very one,

original: śarīrātmatāyā vyutthāpya 'etaṃ tveva te' iti punaḥpunastameva vyākhyāyeyatvenākṛṣya
analyzed: śarīra ātma tāyāḥ vyutthāpya etam tu eva te iti punar punar tam eva vyākhyāyeyatvena ākṛṣya
translated: having explained him again and again as the one to be explained, having drawn him forth,

analyzed: svapna suṣupta upanyāsa krameṇa param jyotiḥ upasaṃpadya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate iti
translated: by the sequence of presenting dreams and deep sleep, by saying having attained the supreme light, he becomes manifest in his own form,

original: yadasya pāramārthikaṃ svarūpaṃ paraṃ brahma tadrūpatayainaṃ jīvaṃ vyācaṣṭe na jaivena rūpeṇa /
analyzed: yat asya pāramārthikam svarūpam param brahma tad rūpatayā enam jīvam vyācaṣṭe na jaivena rūpeṇa
translated: He explains the individual soul in the form of that which is its real nature, the supreme Brahman, not in the form of the individual soul.

analyzed: yat param jyotiḥ ūpasaṃpattavyam śrutam tat param brahma
translated: The supreme Brahman is that which is declared to be the supreme light to be attained.

analyzed: tat ca apahata pāpma tva ādi dharmakam
translated: And that is characterized by the removal of evil and so on.

original: tadeva ca jīvasya pāramārthikaṃ svarūpaṃ 'tattvamasi' ityādiśāstrebhyaḥ /
analyzed: tat eva ca jīvasya pāramārthikam svarūpam tat tvam asi ityādi śāstrebhyaḥ
translated: And that alone is the real nature of the individual soul, according to scriptures such as That art thou.

analyzed: na itarat upādhi kalpitam
translated: Not the other, which is imagined due to limiting adjuncts.

original: yāvadeva hi sthāṇāviva puruṣabuddhiṃ dvaitalakṣaṇāmavidyāṃ nivartayankūṭasthanityadṛksvarūpamātmānamahaṃ brahmāsmīti na pratipadyate tāvajjīvasya
analyzed: yāvat eva hi sthāṇau iva puruṣa buddhim dvaita lakṣaṇām avidyām nivartayan kūṭastha nitya dṛś svarūpam ātmānam aham brahma asmi iti na pratipadyate tāvat jīvasya
translated: As long as one does not realize the Self to be Brahman, thinking I am Brahman, in the form of the eternally unchanging seer, by removing the ignorance characterized by duality, which is like the notion of a person in a post, for that long

analyzed: jīva tvam
translated: the individual soul is an individual soul.

analyzed: yadā tu deha indriya manaḥ buddhi saṃghātāt vyutthāpya śrutyā pratibodhyate
translated: But when one is awakened by scripture, having been roused from the aggregate of body, senses, mind and intellect,

analyzed: na asi tvam deha indriya manaḥ buddhi saṃghātaḥ
translated: You are not the aggregate of body, senses, mind and intellect.

analyzed: na asi saṃsārī
translated: You are not a transmigrator.

original: kiṃ tarhi tadyatsatyaṃ sa ātmā caitanyamātrasvarūpastattvamasīti /
analyzed: kim tarhi tat yat satyam saḥ ātmā caitanya mātra svarūpaḥ tat tvam asi iti
translated: What then? That which is true, that Self, which is of the nature of pure consciousness, that are you.

original: tadā kūcasthanityadṛksvarūpamātmānaṃ pratibudadhyāsmāccharīrādyabhimānātsamuttiṣṭhansa eva kūṭasthanityadṛksvarūpa ātmā bhavati /
analyzed: tadā kūca stha nitya dṛś svarūpam ātmānam pratibudadhya asmāt śarīra ādi abhimānāt samuttiṣṭhan saḥ eva kūṭastha nitya dṛś svarūpaḥ ātmā bhavati
translated: Then he would awaken to the Self, which is of the nature of the changeless and eternal seer, from the notion of identification with the body etc., and rising up from that, he becomes the very Self, which is of the nature of the changeless and eternal seer.

original: 'sa yo ha vai tatparamaṃ brahma veda brahmaiva bhavati' muṇḍa / / /
analyzed: sa yaḥ ha vai tat paramam brahma veda brahmā eva bhavati muṇḍa
translated: For instance, He who knows that supreme Brahman becomes Brahman Himself (Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 3.2.9).

analyzed: ityādi śrutibhyaḥ
translated: This is stated in the Vedic texts.

original: tadeva cāsya pāramārthikaṃ svarūpaṃ yena śarīrātsamutthāya svena rūpeṇābhiniṣpadyate /🔽kathaṃ punaḥ svaṃ ca rūpaṃ svenaiva niṣpadyata iti saṃbhavati kūṭasthanityasya suvarṇādīnāṃ
analyzed: tat eva ca asya pāramārthikam svarūpam yena śarīrāt samutthāya svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate  katham punar svam ca rūpam svena eva niṣpadyate iti saṃbhavati kūṭastha nityasya suvarṇa ādīnām
translated: And that alone is His real nature, by which He rises up from the body and manifests Himself in His own form.

analyzed: tu dravya antara saṃparkāt abhibhūta svarūpāṇām anabhivyakta asādhāraṇa viśeṣāṇām kṣāra prakṣepa ādibhiḥ
translated: How is it possible that one who is changeless and eternal should manifest Himself by Himself? But in the case of gold and other substances, whose nature is obscured by contact with other substances, whose specific properties are not manifest, when they are being purified by the application of acids and other reagents,

analyzed: śodhyamānānām sva rūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ syāt
translated: they may manifest themselves in their own form.

analyzed: tathā nakṣatra ādīnām ahani abhibhūta prakāśānām abhibhāvaka viyoge rātrau sva rūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ syāt
translated: Similarly, stars and other heavenly bodies, whose light is obscured by the sun during the day, may manifest themselves in their own form at night when they are separated from their obscurer.

original: natu tathātmacaitanyajyotiṣo nityasya kenacidabhibhavaḥ saṃbhavatyasaṃsargitvādvyomna iva /
analyzed: na tu tathā ātma caitanya jyotiṣaḥ nityasya kenacid abhibhavaḥ saṃbhavati a saṃsargi tvāt vyomnaḥ iva
translated: But the light of the soul’s intelligence, which is eternal, cannot be overpowered by anything, because it is unconnected, like the ether.

analyzed: dṛṣṭa virodhāt ca
translated: And because it is contrary to what is seen.

analyzed: dṛṣṭi śruti mati vijñātayaḥ hi jīvasya svarūpam
translated: For the soul’s nature is seen, heard, thought, and known.

original: tacca śarīrādasamutthitasyāpi jīvasya sadā niṣpannameva dṛśyate /
analyzed: tat ca śarīrāt asamutthitasya api jīvasya sadā niṣpannam eva dṛśyate
translated: And that is always seen to be accomplished for the soul even when not arisen from the body.

original: sarvo hi jīvaḥ paśyanśṛṇvanmanvāno vijānanvyavaharatyanyathā vyavahārānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: sarvaḥ hi jīvaḥ paśyan śṛṇvan manvānaḥ vijānan vyavaharati anyathā vyavahāra anupapatteḥ
translated: For every soul acts, seeing, hearing, reflecting, and knowing, otherwise action would be impossible.

analyzed: tat ced śarīrāt samutthitasya niṣpadyeta prāk samutthānāt dṛṣṭaḥ vyavahāraḥ virudhyeta
translated: And if that were accomplished for one arisen from the body, the seen action prior to arising would be contradicted.

analyzed: atas kimātmakam idam śarīrāt samutthānam
translated: Therefore, what is the nature of this arising from the body?

analyzed: kimātmikā vā svarūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ iti
translated: Or what is the nature of the accomplishment of one’s own nature?

analyzed: atrā ucyate prāk viveka vijñāna utpatteḥ śarīra indriya manaḥ buddhi viṣaya vedanā upādhibhiḥ aviviktam iva jīvasya dṛṣṭi ādi jyotiḥ svarūpam bhavati
translated: To this it is said: Prior to the arising of the knowledge of discrimination, the nature of the soul’s light of sight etc. is as if undifferentiated by the limiting adjuncts of the body, senses, mind, intellect, objects, and experiences.

original: yathā śuddhasya sphaṭikasya svācchyaṃ śauklyaṃ ca svarūpaṃ prāgvivekagrahaṇādraktanīlādyupādhibhiraviviktamiva bhavati /
analyzed: yathā śuddhasya sphaṭikasya svācchyam śauklyam ca svarūpam prāk viveka grahaṇāt rakta nīla ādi upādhibhiḥ aviviktam iva bhavati
translated: As the clearness and whiteness of pure crystal are its own nature, but before the apprehension of discrimination, it seems to be undifferentiated by the limiting adjuncts of redness, blueness, etc.

original: pramāṇajanitavivekagrahaṇāttu parācīnaḥ sphaṭikaḥ svācchyena śauklyena ca svenarūpeṇābhiniṣpadyata ityucyate prāgapi tathaiva san /
analyzed: pramāṇa janita viveka grahaṇāt tu parācīnaḥ sphaṭikaḥ svācchyena śauklyena ca svena rūpeṇa abhiniṣpadyate iti ucyate prāk api tathā eva san
translated: But after the apprehension of discrimination produced by valid means of knowledge, the crystal is said to be fully accomplished with its own clearness and whiteness as its own nature, even though it was so before.

original: tathā dehādyupādhyaviviktasyaiva sato jīvasya śrutikṛtaṃ vivekavijñānaṃ śarīrātsamutthānaṃ vivekavijñānaphalaṃ svarūpeṇābhiniṣpattiḥ kevalātmasvarūpāvagatiḥ
analyzed: tathā deha ādi upādhya viviktasya eva sataḥ jīvasya śruti kṛtam viveka vijñānam śarīrāt samutthānam viveka vijñāna phalam sva rūpeṇa abhiniṣpattiḥ kevala ātma svarūpa avagatiḥ
translated: Similarly, for the individual soul, which is undifferentiated from the limiting adjuncts like the body, the knowledge of discrimination produced by the Vedas, the arising from the body, the fruit of the knowledge of discrimination, is the full accomplishment in its own nature, the realization of the nature of the pure self alone.

analyzed: tathā viveka aviveka mātreṇa eva ātmanoḥ śarīra tvam sa śarīra tvam ca
translated: Thus, the self's being without a body or having a body is due to mere discrimination or non-discrimination.

original: mantravarṇāt 'aśarīraṃ śarīreṣu' kā / / /🔽iti / 'śarīrastho 'pi kaunteya na karoti na lipyate' gī / /
analyzed: mantra varṇāt aśarīram śarīreṣu kā  iti kaunteya na karoti na lipyate
translated: From the words of the mantra: The bodiless one in the bodies (Ka. Up. 2.3.13).

analyzed: iti ca sa śarīra tva aśarīra tva viśeṣa abhāva smaraṇāt
translated: And from the recollection of the absence of distinction between having a body and being without a body: Though dwelling in the body, O son of Kunti, he does not act or is not affected (Gita 13.31).

analyzed: tasmāt viveka vijñāna abhāvāt anāvirbhūta svarūpaḥ san viveka vijñānāt āvirbhūta svarūpaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Therefore, because of the absence of the knowledge of discrimination, he is said to be one whose nature is not manifested, and one whose nature is manifested by the knowledge of discrimination.

analyzed: na tvā anyādṛśau āvirbhāva anāvirbhāvau svarūpasya saṃbhavataḥ sva rūpa tvāt eva
translated: And there is no other kind of manifestation or non-manifestation of the nature possible, because of its being the nature itself.

original: evaṃ mithyājñānakṛta eva jīvaparameśvarayorbhedo na vastukṛtaḥ /
analyzed: evam mithyā jñāna kṛtaḥ eva jīva parameśvarayoḥ bhedaḥ na vastu kṛtaḥ
translated: Thus, the difference between the individual soul and the supreme Lord is created by false knowledge, not by the reality.

analyzed: vyoma vat asaṅga tva aviśeṣāt
translated: Because of the absence of any difference in their non-attachment, like space.

analyzed: kutaścid evam pratipattavyam
translated: And why should one understand it thus?

original: yato 'ya eṣo 'kṣiṇi puruṣo dṛśyate' ityupadiśya 'etadamṛtamabhayametadbrahma' ityupadiśati /
analyzed: yatas yaḥ eṣa u kṣiṇi puruṣaḥ dṛśyate iti upadiśya etat amṛtam abhayam etat brahma iti upadiśati
translated: Because after teaching, This person is seen in the eye, it teaches, This is the immortal, the fearless, this is Brahman.

original: yo 'kṣiṇi prasiddho draṣṭā draṣṭṛtvena vibhāvyate so 'mṛtābhayalakṣaṇādbrahmaṇo 'nyaścetsyāttato 'mṛtābhayabrahmasāmānādh ikaraṇyaṃ na syāt
analyzed: yaḥ kṣiṇi prasiddhaḥ draṣṭā draṣṭṛ tvena vibhāvyate saḥ mṛtābhaya lakṣaṇāt brahmaṇaḥ nyaḥ ced syāt tatas mṛtābhaya brahma sāmānādh ikaraṇyam na syāt
translated: If the well-known seer who is seen in the eye as the seer were different from Brahman, characterized by immortality, fearlessness, and so on, then there would be no co-reference with the immortal, fearless Brahman.

analyzed: na api praticchāyā ātmā ayam akṣi lakṣitaḥ nirdiśyate
translated: Nor is the reflected self indicated by the eye.

analyzed: prajāpateḥ mṛṣāvādi tva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to Prajapati being a liar.

original: tathā dvitīye 'pi paryāye 'ya eṣaḥ svapne mahīyamānaścarati' iti na prathamaparyāyanirdiṣṭādakṣipuruṣāddraṣṭuranyo nirdiṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tathā dvitīye pi paryāye yaḥ eṣaḥ svapne mahīyamānaḥ carati iti na prathama paryāya nirdiṣṭāt akṣi puruṣāt draṣṭuḥ anyaḥ nirdiṣṭaḥ
translated: In the same way, in the second section also, where it is said, ‘He who moves about honoured in a dream,’ no other seer is mentioned than the person of the eye mentioned in the first section.

analyzed: etam tu eva te bhūyas nuvyākhyāsyāmi iti upakramāt
translated: For the text begins with the words, ‘I will explain him further to you.’

original: kiñcāhamadya svapne hastinamadrākṣaṃ nedānīṃ taṃ paśyāmīti dṛṣṭameva pratibuddhaḥ pratyācaṣṭe /
analyzed: kiñca aham adya svapne hastinam adrākṣam na idānīm tam paśyāmi iti dṛṣṭam eva pratibuddhaḥ pratyācaṣṭe
translated: Moreover, when he awakes, he denies what he saw in the following way: ‘I saw an elephant in my dream today, but I do not see it now.’

original: draṣṭāraṃ tu tameva pratyabhijānāti ya evāhaṃ svapnamadrākṣaṃ sa evāhaṃ jāgaritaṃ paśyamīti /
analyzed: draṣṭāram tu tam eva pratyabhijānāti yaḥ eva aham svapnam adrākṣam saḥ eva aham jāgaritam paśyami iti
translated: But he recognizes the seer himself, saying, ‘He who saw the dream is the same who sees the waking state.’

original: tathā tṛtīye 'pi paryāye 'nahi khalvayamevaṃ saṃpratyātmānaṃ jānātyayamahamasmīti
analyzed: tathā tṛtīye pi paryāye na hi khalu ayam evam saṃprati ātmānam jānāti ayam aham asmi iti
translated: In the same way, in the third section also, where it is said, ‘But indeed he does not know himself then thus: “I am he,”

original: no evemāni bhūtāni iti suṣuptāvasthāyāṃ viśeṣavijñānābhāvameva darśayati na vijñātāraṃ pratiṣedhati /
analyzed: no eva imāni bhūtāni iti suṣupta avasthāyām viśeṣa vijñāna abhāvam eva darśayati na vijñātāram pratiṣedhati
translated: nor these beings,’ it shows only the absence of the knowledge of particulars in the state of deep sleep, and does not deny the knower.

original: yattu tatra 'vināśamevāpīto bhavati' iti tadapi viśeṣavijñānavināśābhiprāyameva na vijñātṛvināśābhiprāyam /
analyzed: yat tu tatra vināśam eva api itas bhavati iti tat api viśeṣa vijñāna vināśa abhiprāyam eva na vijñātṛ vināśa abhiprāyam

analyzed: deva ādi adhikāre pi aṅguṣṭa mātra śrutiḥ sva aṅguṣṭha apekṣayā na virudhyate  / devānām karmasu na adhikāraḥ

analyzed: darśanāt  tathā ahi kati devāḥ iti upakramya trayaḥ ca trī ca śatā trayaḥ ca trī ca sahasrā  iti nirucya katama te iti asyām pṛcchāyām mahimānaḥ eva eṣām ete trayastriṃśat tu eva

analyzed: devāḥ bṛ

analyzed: prāpnuyāt viṣayān kaiścid ugram tapaḥ caret

analyzed: iti evañjātīyakā prāpta aṇima ādi aiśvaryāṇām yoginām api yugapad aneka śarīra yogam darśayati

analyzed: kimu vaktavyam ājāna siddhānām devānām

translated: And because it is possible for a single deity to assume many forms, it is reasonable that a single deity divides itself into many forms and simultaneously becomes a subsidiary in many sacrifices.

analyzed: kvacid ca ekaḥ vigrahavān anekatra yugapad aṅga bhāvam gacchati

analyzed: nityena arthena nitye saṃbandhe pratīyamāne yat vaidike śabde prāmāṇyam sthitam tasya

translated: And even when the individuals are produced, there is no contradiction seen in the words like 'cow' etc. due to the eternality of the forms.

analyzed: pratyakṣam śrutiḥ

analyzed: prāmāṇyam prati anapekṣa tvāt

analyzed: prāmāṇyam prati sāpekṣa tvāt
translated: Because it is dependent with regard to its authority.

analyzed: prajāḥ iti śrutiḥ  tathā anyatra api sa manasā vācam mithunam samabhavat bṛ

analyzed: utsargaḥ u pi ayam vācaḥ saṃpradāya pravartana ātmakaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: This emission of the Word should be seen as consisting in the propagation of the tradition.

analyzed: anādinidhanāyāḥ anyādṛśasya utsargasya asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because an emission of another kind is impossible for that which is beginningless and endless.

original: tathā 'nāma rūpaṃ ca bhūtānāṃ karmaṇāṃ ca pravartanam /
analyzed: tathā nāma rūpam ca bhūtānām karmaṇām ca pravartanam
translated: Similarly, it is said: The names and forms of beings and the instigation of actions,

analyzed: veda śabdebhyaḥ eva ādau nirmame sa maheśvaraḥ
translated: In the beginning, that great Lord created from the words of the Veda.

original: manu / / iti /🔽' sarveṣāṃ tu sa nāmāni karmāṇi ca pṛthakpṛthak /
analyzed: manu iti  sarveṣām tu sa nāmāni karmāṇi ca pṛthak pṛthak
translated: Manu also says:

analyzed: veda śabdebhyaḥ eva ādau pṛthak saṃsthāḥ ca nirmame
translated: But he created separately the names, actions, and separate institutions of all, from the words of the Veda in the beginning.

analyzed: iti ca
translated: And also:

original: apica cikīrṣitamarthamanutiṣṭhaṃstasya vācakaṃ śabdaṃ pūrvaṃ smṛtvā paścāttamarthamanuṣṭhatīti sarveṣāṃ naḥ pratyakṣametat /
analyzed: apica cikīrṣitam artham anutiṣṭhan tasya vācakam śabdam pūrvam smṛtvā paścāt tam artham anuṣṭhati iti sarveṣām naḥ pratyakṣam etat
translated: Moreover, it is directly perceived by all of us that one who performs a desired action first remembers the word that denotes it, and then performs that action.

original: tathā prajāpaterapi sraṣṭuḥ sṛṣṭeḥ pūrvaṃ vaidikāḥ śabdā manasi prādurbabhūvuḥ /
analyzed: tathā prajāpateḥ api sraṣṭuḥ sṛṣṭeḥ pūrvam vaidikāḥ śabdāḥ manasi prādurbabhūvuḥ
translated: Similarly, it is understood that before creation, the Vedic words manifested in the mind of Prajapati, the creator.

analyzed: paścāt tad anugatān arthān sasarja iti gamyate
translated: And later he created the objects corresponding to them.

original: tathāca śrutiḥ 'sa bhūriti vyāhāratsa bhūmimasṛjata' tai /brā / / / /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ sa bhūḥ iti vyāhārat sa bhūmim asṛjata taibrā
translated: And thus the Shruti says: He uttered 'bhuḥ,' he created the earth. Taittiriya Upanishad.

original: ityevamādikā bhūrādiśabdebhya eva manasi prādurbhūtebhyo bhūrādilokānsṛṣṭāndarśayati /
analyzed: iti evamādikā bhūḥ ādi śabdebhyaḥ eva manasi prādurbhūtebhyaḥ bhūḥ ādi lokān sṛṣṭān darśayati
translated: Thus, the Shruti shows that the worlds such as Bhu, etc. were created from the words such as Bhu, etc. that manifested in the mind.

analyzed: kimātmakam punar śabdam abhipretya idam śabda prabhava tvam ucyate
translated: But what kind of sound is meant when it is said that this (universe) originates from sound?

analyzed: sphoṭam iti āha
translated: He says: the sphota.

original: varṇapakṣe hi teṣāmutpannapradhvaṃsitvānnityebhyaḥ śabdebhyo devādivyaktīnāṃ prabhava ityanupapannaṃ syāt /
analyzed: varṇa pakṣe hi teṣām utpanna pradhvaṃsi tvāt nityebhyaḥ śabdebhyaḥ deva ādi vyaktīnām prabhavaḥ iti anupapannam syāt
translated: For if they were letters, it would be impossible for the individual gods and so on to originate from eternal sounds, because they would be produced and destroyed.

analyzed: utpanna dhvaṃsinaḥ ca varṇāḥ
translated: And letters are produced and destroyed.

analyzed: pratyuccāraṇam anyathā ca anyathā ca pratīyamāna tvāt
translated: Because they are perceived differently each time they are uttered.

original: tathāhi adṛśyamāno 'pi puruṣaviśeṣo 'dhyayanadhvaniśravaṇādeva viśeṣato nirdhāryate devadatto 'yamadhīte yajñadatto 'yamadhīte iti /
analyzed: tathā hi adṛśyamānaḥ pi puruṣa viśeṣaḥ dhyayana dhvani śravaṇāt eva viśeṣataḥ nirdhāryate devadattaḥ yam adhīte yajñadattaḥ yam adhīte iti
translated: For thus, even a particular person who is not seen is specifically determined just from hearing the sound of recitation: This is Devadatta reciting, This is Yajnadatta reciting.

analyzed: na ca ayam varṇa viṣayaḥ nyathātva pratyayaḥ mithyājñānam
translated: And this cognition of difference regarding letters is not false knowledge.

analyzed: bādhaka pratyaya abhāvāt  na ca varṇebhyaḥ ṛtha avagatiḥ yuktā
translated: Because there is no contradictory cognition.🔽And the understanding of meaning from letters is not proper.

analyzed: na hi ekaikaḥ varṇa ūrtham pratyāyayet
translated: For not a single letter would convey the meaning,

analyzed: vyabhicārāt
translated: because of deviation.

analyzed: na ca varṇa samudāya pratyayaḥ sti
translated: And there is no cognition of a collection of letters.

analyzed: kramavat tvāt varṇānām
translated: Because letters have a sequence.

analyzed: pūrva pūrva varṇa anubhava janita saṃskāra sahitaḥ ntyaḥ varṇa ūrtham pratyāyayiṣyati iti yadi ucyeta
translated: If it is said that the final letter, along with the impressions produced by the experience of each preceding letter, will convey the meaning,

analyzed: tat na
translated: that is not so.

original: saṃbandhagrahaṇāpekṣo hi śabdaḥ svayaṃ pratīyamānor'thaṃ pratyāyayeddhūmādivat /
analyzed: saṃbandha grahaṇa apekṣaḥ hi śabdaḥ svayam pratīyamāna ūrtham pratyāyayet dhūma ādi vat
translated: For a word, when it is itself cognised, would convey its meaning, in dependence on the apprehension of the relation (between the word and its meaning), just as smoke (conveys the idea of fire).

analyzed: na ca pūrva pūrva varṇa anubhava janita saṃskāra sahitasya antya varṇasya pratītiḥ asti
translated: And there is no cognition of the last letter, along with the impressions produced by the cognition of the preceding letters.

analyzed: a pratyakṣa tvāt saṃskārāṇām
translated: Because impressions are not perceptible.

original: kāryapratyāyitaiḥ saṃskāraiḥ sahito 'ntyo varṇorthaṃ pratyāyayiṣyatīti cet / na /
analyzed: kārya pratyāyitaiḥ saṃskāraiḥ sahitaḥ ntyaḥ varṇa ūrtham pratyāyayiṣyati iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the last letter, along with the impressions inferred from their effects, will convey the meaning, that is not so.

analyzed: saṃskāra kāryasya api smaraṇasya krama varti tvāt
translated: Because the memory, which is the effect of the impressions, also occurs in sequence.

analyzed: tasmāt sphoṭaḥ eva śabdaḥ
translated: Therefore, the word is a sphoṭa (a whole consisting of letters).

original: sa caicaikavarṇapratyayāhitasaṃskārabīje 'ntyavarṇapratyayajanitapari pāke pratyayinyekapratyayaviṣayatayā jhaṭiti pratyavabhāsate /
analyzed: sa ca e ca eka varṇa pratyaya āhita saṃskāra bīje pāke pratyayini eka pratyaya viṣaya tayā jhaṭiti pratyavabhāsate
translated: And that (sphoṭa) appears suddenly as the object of a single cognition, in the knower, who is matured by the last letter-cognition, in which the seed of impressions is produced by the cognitions of the individual letters.

analyzed: na ca ayam eka pratyayaḥ varṇa viṣayā smṛtiḥ
translated: And this single cognition is not a memory having the letters as its object.

analyzed: varṇānām aneka tvāt eka pratyaya viṣaya tva anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the letters are many, it is not possible for them to be the object of a single cognition.

analyzed: tasya ca pratyuccāraṇam pratyabhijñāyamāna tvāt nitya tvam
translated: And because it is recognised as the same on each utterance, it is eternal.

analyzed: bheda pratyayasya varṇa viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the cognition of difference has the letters as its object.

analyzed: tasmāt nityāt śabda sphoṭa rūpāt abhidhāyakāt kriyā kāraka phala lakṣaṇam jagat abhidheya bhūtam prabhavati iti
translated: Therefore, the universe consisting of action, means and results, which is the object of denotation, originates from the eternal word-sphoṭa, which is the denotator.

original: varṇā eva tu na śabdaḥ iti bhagavānupavarṣaḥ /
analyzed: varṇāḥ eva tu na śabdaḥ iti bhagavān upavarṣaḥ
translated: But the revered Upamanyu says that the letters themselves are not the word.

analyzed: nanu utpannapradhvaṃsi tvam varṇāt muktam tat na
translated: But it has been said that the letters are produced and destroyed. That is not so.

analyzed: te eva iti pratyabhijñānāt
translated: Because of the recognition that they are the same.

analyzed: sādṛśyāt pratbhijñānam keśa ādiṣu iva iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the recognition is due to similarity, like in the case of hair etc., that is not so.

analyzed: pratyabhijñānasya pramāṇa antareṇa bādhā anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the contradiction of recognition by another means of knowledge is not possible.

analyzed: pratyabhijñānam ākṛti nimittam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that recognition is based on the universal, that is not so.

analyzed: vyakti pratyabhijñānāt
translated: Because of the recognition of the individual.

original: yadi hi pratyuccāraṇaṃ gavādivyaktivadanyā anyā varṇavyaktayaḥ pratīyeraṃstata ākṛtinimittaṃ pratyabhijñānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi hi pratyuccāraṇam gavā ādi vyakti vat anyāḥ anyāḥ varṇa vyaktayaḥ pratīyeran tatas ākṛti nimittam pratyabhijñānam syāt
translated: If the individual letters were recognized as different in each utterance, like the individual cows etc., then the recognition would be based on the universal.

analyzed: na tu etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: varṇa vyaktayaḥ eva hi pratyuccāraṇam pratyabhijñāyante
translated: For the individual letters themselves are recognized in each utterance.

original: dvirgośabda uccārita iti hi pratipattirna tu dvau gośabdāviti /
analyzed: dvis go śabdaḥ uccāritaḥ iti hi pratipattiḥ na tu dvau go śabdau iti
translated: The understanding is the word 'go' is uttered twice, not two words 'go' are uttered.

original: nanu varṇā apyuccāraṇabhedena bhinnaḥ pratīyante devadattayajñadattayoradhyayanadhvaniśravaṇādeva bhedapratīterityuktam /🔽atrābhidhīyate sati varṇaviṣaye niścite pratyabhijñāne saṃyogavibhāgābhivyaṅgyatvādvarṇānāmabhivyañjakavaicitryanimitto 'yaṃ varṇaviṣayo vicitraḥ
analyzed: nanu varṇāḥ api uccāraṇa bhedena bhinnaḥ pratīyante devadatta yajñadattayoḥ adhyayana dhvani śravaṇāt eva bheda pratīteḥ iti uktam  atra abhidhīyate sati varṇa viṣaye niścite pratyabhijñāne saṃyoga vibhāga abhivyaṅgya tvāt varṇānām abhivyañjaka vaicitrya nimittaḥ yam varṇa viṣayaḥ vicitraḥ
translated: But it has been argued that the letters are also perceived to be different on account of the difference in their utterance, because the difference is perceived even from hearing the study of Devadatta and Yajnadatta.

analyzed: pratyayaḥ na sva rūpa nimittaḥ
translated: To this it is said: When the recognition of letters is certain, this diverse cognition regarding letters is due to the diversity of manifestation caused by conjunctions and disjunctions, and is not due to the difference in their nature.

analyzed: apica varṇa vyakti bheda vādinā api pratyabhijñāna siddhaye varṇa ākṛtayaḥ kalpayitavyāḥ
translated: Moreover, even one who asserts the difference of individual letters must imagine the forms of letters in order to establish recognition.

analyzed: tāsu ca para upādhikaḥ bheda pratyayaḥ iti abhyupagantavyam
translated: And in those [forms], it must be accepted that the cognition of difference is due to external factors.

original: tadvaraṃ varṇavyaktiṣveva paropādhiko bhedapratyayaḥ svarūpanimittaṃ ca pratyabhijñānamiti kalpanālāghavam /
analyzed: tat varam varṇa vyaktiṣu eva para upādhikaḥ bheda pratyayaḥ svarūpa nimittam ca pratyabhijñānam iti kalpanā lāghavam
translated: It is better to consider that the cognition of difference regarding individual letters is due to external factors, and that recognition is due to their nature. Thus there is simplicity in the assumption.

original: eṣa eva ca varṇaviṣayasya bhedapratyayasya bādhakaḥ pratyayo yatpratyabhijñānam /
analyzed: eṣaḥ eva ca varṇa viṣayasya bheda pratyayasya bādhakaḥ pratyayaḥ yat pratyabhijñānam
translated: And this very recognition is the cognition that contradicts the cognition of difference regarding letters.

original: kathaṃ hyekasminkālaṃ bahūnāmuccārayatāmeka eva sangakāro yugapadanekarūpaḥ syāt /
analyzed: katham hi ekasmin kālam bahūnām uccārayatām ekaḥ eva san gakāraḥ yugapad aneka rūpaḥ syāt
translated: For how could a single sound, the letter g, uttered simultaneously by many people at the same time, have many forms simultaneously,

analyzed: udāttaḥ ca anudāttaḥ ca svaritaḥ ca sa anunāsikaḥ ca niranunāsikaḥ ca iti
translated: such as udātta, anudātta, svarita, nasal, and non-nasal?

original: athavā dhvanikṛto 'yaṃ pratyayabhedo na varṇakṛta ityadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: athavā dhvani kṛtaḥ yam pratyaya bhedaḥ na varṇa kṛtaḥ iti adoṣaḥ
translated: Or, this distinction of the effect is due to the sound, not to the letter, so there is no fault.

original: kaḥ punarayaṃ dhvanirnāma /🔽yo dūrādākarṇayato varṇavivekamapratipadyamānasya karṇapathamavatarati /
analyzed: kaḥ punar ayam dhvaniḥ nāma  yaḥ dūrāt ākarṇayataḥ varṇa vivekam a pratipadyamānasya karṇa patham avatarati
translated: What, then, is this thing called sound?🔽It is that which enters the ear of one who hears from a distance without understanding the distinction of letters.

analyzed: pratyāsīdataḥ ca paṭu maṭu tva ādi bhedam varṇeṣu āsañjayati
translated: And as it approaches, it imparts the distinction of sharpness and dullness to the letters.

analyzed: tad nibandhanāḥ ca udātta ādayaḥ viśeṣāḥ na varṇa svarūpa nibandhanāḥ
translated: And the distinctions such as udātta are based on that, not on the form of the letters.

analyzed: varṇānām pratyuccārāṇam pratyabhijñāyamāna tvāt
translated: Because the letters are recognized as being the same when pronounced.

analyzed: evam ca sati sa ālambanāḥ udātta ādi pratyayāḥ bhaviṣyanti
translated: And in this way, the notions of udātta and so on will have an object.

original: itaradhā hi varṇānāṃ pratyabhijñāyamānānāṃ nirbhedatvātsaṃyogavibhāgakṛtā udāttādiviśeṣāḥ kalperan /
analyzed: itaradhā hi varṇānām pratyabhijñāyamānānām nirbheda tvāt saṃyoga vibhāga kṛtāḥ udātta ādi viśeṣāḥ kalperan
translated: For otherwise, if the letters were recognized as being without distinction, the distinctions such as udātta would be imagined to be made by conjunction and disjunction.

original: saṃyogavibhāgānāṃ cāpratyakṣatvācca tadāśrayā viśeṣā varṇeṣvadhyavasituṃ śakyanta ityato nirālambanā evaita udāttādipratyayāḥ syuḥ /
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāgānām ca apratyakṣa tvāt ca tad āśrayāḥ viśeṣāḥ varṇeṣu adhyavasitum śakyante iti atas nirālambanāḥ eva ete udātta ādi pratyayāḥ syuḥ
translated: And because conjunctions and disjunctions are not perceptible, the specific differences based on them cannot be ascertained in the case of letters. Therefore, these notions of udātta and so on must be baseless.

original: apica naivaitadabhiniveṣṭavyamudāttādibhedena varṇānāṃ pratyabhijñāyamānānāṃ bhedo bhavediti /
analyzed: apica na eva etat abhiniveṣṭavyam udātta ādi bhedena varṇānām pratyabhijñāyamānānām bhedaḥ bhavet iti
translated: Moreover, it should not be insisted that the letters, which are recognized as being of the nature of udātta and so on, must be different when they are distinguished by udātta and so on.

analyzed: na hi anyasya bhedena anyasya a bhidyamānasya bhedaḥ bhavitum arhati
translated: For the difference of one thing cannot result from the difference of another thing which is not itself different.

analyzed: nahi vyakti bhedena jātim bhinnām manyante
translated: For people do not consider a universal to be different when the individuals are different.

analyzed: varṇebhyaḥ ca artha pratīteḥ saṃbhavāt sphoṭa kalpanā anarthikā
translated: And since the cognition of meaning is possible from the letters, the postulation of a sphoṭa is pointless.

analyzed: na kalpayāmi aham sphoṭam pratyakṣam eva tu enam avagacchāmi
translated: I do not postulate a sphoṭa, but I perceive it directly.

original: ekaikavarṇagrahaṇāhitasaṃskārāyāṃ buddhau jhaṭiti pratyava ūbhāsanāditi cet / na /
analyzed: ekaika varṇa grahaṇa āhita saṃskārāyām buddhau jhaṭiti pratyavaḥ ū bhāsanāt iti ced na
translated: Because it appears suddenly in the cognition produced by the impressions deposited by the apprehension of each letter. If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: asyāḥ api buddheḥ varṇa viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because this cognition also has letters as its object.

analyzed: ekaika varṇa grahaṇa uttara kālā hi iyam ekā buddhiḥ gauḥ iti samasta varṇa viṣayā na artha antara viṣayā
translated: For this single cognition that arises after the apprehension of each letter, having the complete set of letters as its object, does not have a different object.

analyzed: katham etat avagamyate
translated: How is this known?

original: yato 'syāmapi buddhau gakārādayo varṇā anuvartante natu dakārādayaḥ /
analyzed: yatas syām api buddhau gakāra ādayaḥ varṇāḥ anuvartante na tu dakāra ādayaḥ
translated: Because in this cognition also, the letters 'ga' etc. continue, but not the letters 'da' etc.

original: yadi hyasyā buddhergakārādibhyor'thāntaraṃ sphoṭo viṣayaḥ syāttato dakārādaya iva gakārādayo 'pyasyā buddhervyāvarteran /
analyzed: yadi hi asyāḥ buddheḥ gakāra ādibhyaḥ artha antaram sphoṭaḥ viṣayaḥ syāt tatas dakāra ādayaḥ iva gakāra ādayaḥ pi asyāḥ buddheḥ vyāvarteran
translated: If the sphoṭa, which is something different from the letters 'ga' etc., were the object of this cognition, then the letters 'ga' etc. would be excluded from this cognition, just like the letters 'da' etc.

analyzed: na tu tathā asti
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: tasmāt iyam eka buddhiḥ varṇa viṣayā eva smṛtiḥ
translated: Therefore, this single cognition is only a memory of the letters.

analyzed: nanu aneka tvāt varṇānām na eka buddhi viṣaya tā upapadyate iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that because the letters are many, they cannot be the object of a single cognition.

analyzed: tat pratibrūmaḥ saṃbhavati anekasya api eka buddhi viṣaya tvam
translated: We reply: It is possible for many things to be the object of a single cognition.

original: paṅ ktirvanaṃ senā daśa śataṃ sahasramityādidarśanāt /
analyzed: paṅ ktiḥ vanam senā daśa śatam sahasram ityādi darśanāt
translated: Because we see examples like 'a clump', 'a forest', 'an army', 'ten', 'a hundred', 'a thousand', etc.

original: yā tu gaurityeko 'yaṃ śabda iti buddhiḥ /
analyzed: yā tu gauḥ iti ekaḥ yam śabdaḥ iti buddhiḥ
translated: But the cognition that 'this is the single word cow

analyzed: sā bahuṣu eva varṇeṣu eka artha avaccheda nibandhanā aupacārikī vana senā ādi buddhi vat eva
translated: is a figurative usage based on the exclusion of multiple meanings in many letters, like the cognition of a forest, an army, etc.

original: atrāha yadi varṇā eva sāmastyenaikabuddhiviṣayatāmāpadyamānāḥ padaṃ syustato jārā rājā kapiḥ pikaḥ ityādiṣu padaviśeṣapratipattirna syāt /
analyzed: atra āha yadi varṇāḥ eva sāmastyena eka buddhi viṣaya tām āpadyamānāḥ padam syuḥ tatas jārāḥ rājā kapiḥ pikaḥ ityādiṣu pada viśeṣa pratipattiḥ na syāt
translated: Here it is said: If the letters themselves, when becoming the object of a single cognition, were to be the word, then the understanding of specific words like 'jara' (old), 'raja' (king), 'kapi' (monkey), 'paka' (cooking) would not be possible.

original: ta eva hi varṇā itaratra cetaratra ca pratyavabhāsanta iti /
analyzed: te eva hi varṇāḥ itaratra ca itaratra ca pratyavabhāsante iti
translated: For those very letters manifest themselves in one place and in another.

original: atra vadāmaḥ satyapi samastavarṇapratyavamarśe yathā kramānurodhinya eva pipīlikāḥ paṅ ktibuddhimārohanti /
analyzed: atra vadāmaḥ sati api samasta varṇa pratyavamarśe yathā krama anurodhinyaḥ eva pipīlikāḥ paṅ kti buddhim ārohanti
translated: To this we reply: Even though there is a recollection of all the letters, just as ants, following the order, ascend the idea of a line,

analyzed: evam krama anurodhane eva varṇāḥ pada buddhim ārokṣyanti
translated: in the same way, the letters, following the order, will ascend the idea of a word.

analyzed: tatra varṇānām aviśeṣe pi krama viśeṣa kṛtā pada viśeṣa pratipattiḥ na virudhyate
translated: Even though there is no difference among the letters, the cognition of a particular word produced by a particular order is not contradictory.

original: vṛddhavyavahāre ceme varṇāḥ kramādyanugṛhītā gṛhītārthaviśeṣasaṃbandhāḥ santaḥ svavyavahāro
analyzed: vṛddha vyavahāre ca ime varṇāḥ krama ādi anugṛhītāḥ gṛhīta artha viśeṣa saṃbandhāḥ santaḥ sva vyavahāraḥ
translated: And these letters, favored by order etc. in the usage of the elders, having the connection with the particular object grasped, in their own usage

analyzed: pi ekaika varṇa grahaṇa anantaram samasta pratyavamarśinyām buddhau tādṛśāḥ eva pratyavabhāsamānāḥ tam
translated: also, appearing in the cognition that recollects all of them after the apprehension of each letter, will infallibly convey that

analyzed: tam artham avyabhicāreṇa pratyāyayiṣyanti iti varṇa vādinaḥ laghīyasī kalpanā
translated: object. Thus for the proponents of letters, the assumption is less cumbersome.

translated: And because of the well-known usage and because of the well-known usage in the supplementary passages.

original: naca jyotirmaṇḍalasya hṛdayādinā vigraheṣu cetanayārthitvādinā vā yogo 'vagantuṃ śakyate mṛtādivadacetanatvāvagamāt /
analyzed: na ca jyotiḥ maṇḍalasya hṛdaya ādinā vigraheṣu cetanayā arthi tva ādinā vā yogaḥ vagantum śakyate mṛta ādi vat acetana tva avagamāt
translated: And it cannot be understood that the luminous sphere is connected with the heart, etc., or with desire, etc., as a conscious being, because of the understanding that it is insentient, like a corpse, etc.

analyzed: etena agni ādayaḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: By this, Agni and others are explained.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This may be said:

analyzed: mantra arthavāda itihāsa purāṇa lokebhyaḥ deva ādānām vigrahavat tva ādi avagamāt ayam adoṣaḥ iti
translated: Since the existence of bodies, etc. of gods is understood from mantras, Arthavadas, Itihāsas, Purāṇas and worldly usage, this is not a fault.

analyzed: na iti ucyate
translated: It is said: No.

analyzed: nahi tāvat lokaḥ nāma kiñcid svatantram pramāṇam asti
translated: For there is no such thing as worldly usage which is an independent means of knowledge.

original: pratyakṣādibhya eva hyavicāritaviśeṣebhyaḥ pramāṇebhyaḥ prasiddhyanartho lokātprasidhyatītyucyate /
analyzed: pratyakṣa ādibhyaḥ eva hi avicārita viśeṣebhyaḥ pramāṇebhyaḥ prasiddhi anarthaḥ lokāt prasidhyati iti ucyate
translated: For what is well-known from means of knowledge whose specific nature is not examined, such as perception, etc., is said to be well-known from worldly usage.

analyzed: na ca atra pratyakṣa ādīnām anyatamam pramāṇam asti
translated: And here there is no means of knowledge such as perception, etc.

analyzed: itihāsa purāṇam api pauruṣeya tvāt pramāṇa antara mūlam ākāṅkṣati
translated: And Itihāsas and Purāṇas, being composed by men, require another means of knowledge as their basis.

original: arthavādā api vidhinaikavākyatvātstutyarthāḥ santo na pārthagarthyena devādīnāṃ vigrahādisadbhāve kāraṇabhāvaṃ pratipadyante /
analyzed: arthavādāḥ api vidhinā eka vākya tvāt stuti arthāḥ santaḥ na pārthagarthyena deva ādīnām vigraha ādi sadbhāve kāraṇa bhāvam pratipadyante
translated: Even the Arthavada passages, being syntactically connected with the injunctions and serving the purpose of commending, do not, by themselves, serve as the basis for the existence of the body, etc. of the gods, etc.

original: mantrā api śrutyādiviniyuktāḥ prayogasamavāyino 'bhidhānārthā na kasyacidarthasya pramāṇamityācakṣate /
analyzed: mantrāḥ api śruti ādi viniyuktāḥ prayoga samavāyinaḥ bhidhāna arthāḥ na kasyacid arthasya pramāṇam iti ācakṣate
translated: The Mantras also, which are employed by direct Vedic injunctions and are syntactically connected with the ritual, are expressive of meanings, but they do not constitute the means of knowing any meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt abhāvaḥ deva ādīnām adhikārasya
translated: Therefore, there is no authority of the gods, etc.

analyzed: vajrahastaḥ purandaraḥ ityādayaḥ mantrāḥ saḥ rodīt ityādayaḥ arthavādāḥ
translated: The mantras like 'Vajrahastaḥ Purandaraḥ' (Indra with the thunderbolt in his hand), and the Arthavada passages like 'So'rodīt' (He wept),

analyzed: iṣṭān bhogān hi vaḥ devāḥ ityādi itihāsa purāṇāni
translated: the Itihasa and Purana passages like 'Iṣṭān bhogān hi vo devāḥ' (The gods indeed enjoy the desired pleasures),

analyzed: loke pi yamam daṇḍa hastam
translated: in the world also, Yama with the staff in his hand,

analyzed: indram vajra hastam
translated: Indra with the thunderbolt in his hand,

analyzed: likhanti iti vigraha ādi pañcaka sadbhāvāt anadhikāra doṣaḥ na asti iti arthaḥ
translated: are written. Thus, because the five, beginning with the body, exist, there is no fault of lack of authority. This is the meaning.

analyzed: vigrahaḥ haviṣām bhogaḥ aiśvaryam ca prasanna tā
translated: 'The body, the enjoyment of oblations, the prosperity, the satisfaction,

analyzed: phala pradānam iti etat pañcakam vigraha ādikam iti
translated: and the bestowal of fruits - this set of five is the body, etc.'

analyzed: bhāvam tu bādarāyaṇaḥ sti hi
translated: But Bādarāyaṇa thinks that there is (authority).

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ pūrvapakṣam vyavartayati
translated: The word 'tu' (but) sets aside the prima facie view.

analyzed: bādarāyaṇaḥ tu ācāryaḥ bhāvam adhikārasya deva ādīnām api manyante
translated: But the teacher Bādarāyaṇa maintains that the gods and so on are entitled to the knowledge of Brahman, because it is possible for them to be so entitled.

original: yadyapi madhvādividyāsu devatādivyāmiśrāsvāsaṃbhavo 'dhikārasya tathāpyasti hi śuddhāyāṃ brahmavidyāyāṃ saṃbhavaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api madhu ādi vidyāsu devatā ādi vyāmiśrāsu āsaṃbhavaḥ dhikārasya tathā api asti hi śuddhāyām brahmavidyāyām saṃbhavaḥ
translated: Although it is impossible for the gods and so on to be entitled to the knowledge of Brahman, which is mixed with the knowledge of the gods and so on, as in the case of the knowledge of Soma and so on, still it is possible for them to be entitled to the pure knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: arthi tva sāmarthya pratiṣedha ādi apekṣa tvāt adhikārasya
translated: Because the title to knowledge depends on the presence of desire, capacity, prohibition, and so on.

analyzed: na ca kvacid asaṃbhavaḥ iti etāvatā yatra saṃbhavaḥ tatra api adhikāraḥ upodyeta
translated: And it cannot be said that where it is impossible, there the title does not exist; for then it would follow that where it is possible, there also the title does not exist.

original: manuṣyāṇāmapi na sarveṣāṃ brāhmaṇādīnāṃ sarveṣu rājasūyādiṣvadhikāraḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: manuṣyāṇām api na sarveṣām brāhmaṇa ādīnām sarveṣu rājasūya ādiṣu adhikāraḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And among men also, not all Brahmins and so on are entitled to all rites, such as the Rājasūya.

analyzed: tatra yaḥ nyāyaḥ saḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: The same reasoning will apply here also.

original: brahmavidyāṃ ca prakṛtya bhavati darśanaṃ śrautaṃ devādyadhikārasya sūcakam 'tadyo yo devānāṃ pratyabudhyata sa eva tadabhavattatharṣīṇāṃ
analyzed: brahma vidyām ca prakṛtya bhavati darśanam śrautam deva ādi adhikārasya sūcakam tat yaḥ yaḥ devānām pratyabudhyata saḥ eva tat abhavat tathā ṛṣīṇām
translated: And with reference to the knowledge of Brahman, there is a Vedic text indicating the title of the gods and so on to that knowledge: 'He who understood it among the gods became that, and so did he among the sages,

analyzed: tathā manuṣyāṇām bṛ iti
translated: and so did he among men' (Br. 1.4.2).

original: 'te hocurhanta tamātmānamanvicchāmo yamātmānamanviṣya sarvāṃśca lokānāpnoti sarvāṃśca kāmān' iti /
analyzed: te ha ūcuḥ hanta tam ātmānam anvicchāmaḥ yam ātmānam anviṣya sarvān ca lokān āpnoti sarvān ca kāmān iti
translated: 'They said, Let us seek that Self, having sought which one obtains all worlds and all desires.'

original: 'indro ha vai devānāmabhipravrāja virocana'surāṇām' chā / / / ityādi ca /
analyzed: indraḥ ha vai devānām abhipravrāja virocana surāṇām chā ityādi ca
translated: And so on.

analyzed: samārtam api gandharva yājñavalkya saṃvāda ādi
translated: And the Smṛti also, such as the dialogue between the Gandharva and Yājñavalkya.

analyzed: yat api uktam jyotiṣi bhāvāt ca iti
translated: And what has been said about the existence in the light, etc.

original: atra brūmaḥ jyotirādiviṣayā api ādityādayo devatāvacanāḥ śabdāścetanāvantamaiśvaryādyupetaṃ taṃ taṃ devatātmānaṃ samarpayanti /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ jyotiḥ ādi viṣayāḥ api āditya ādayaḥ devatā vacanāḥ śabdāḥ cetanāvantam aiśvarya ādi upetam tam tam devatā ātmānam samarpayanti
translated: To this we reply: Even the words denoting deities such as Āditya, which have light, etc. as their objects, refer to the individual souls endowed with consciousness and possessing lordship, etc.

analyzed: mantra arthavāda ādiṣu tathā vyavahārāt
translated: Because they are used in that way in the mantra, Arthavāda, etc.

original: asti hyaiśvaryayogāddevatānāṃ jyotirādyātmabhiścāvasthātuṃ yatheṣṭaṃ ca taṃ taṃ vigrahaṃ grahītuṃ sāmarthyam /
analyzed: asti hi aiśvarya yogāt devatānām jyotiḥ ādi ātmabhiḥ ca avasthātum yathā iṣṭam ca tam tam vigraham grahītum sāmarthyam
translated: For the deities, by their connection with lordship, have the power to exist in the form of light, etc. and to assume such and such a body as they wish.

analyzed: tathā hi śrūyate subrahmaṇya arthavāde medhātitheḥ meṣa iti
translated: Thus it is heard in the Subrahmaṇya Arthavāda of Medhātithi's son in the form of a ram.

original: 'medhātithiṃ ha kāṇvāyanamindro meṣo bhūtvā jahāra' ṣaḍviṃśa / brā / / iti /
analyzed: medhātithim ha kāṇvāyanam indraḥ meṣaḥ bhūtvā jahāra ṣaḍviṃśa iti
translated: 'Indra, in the form of a ram, carried off Medhātithi, the son of Kaṇva' (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 6.2.1.26).

original: smaryate ca 'ādityaḥ puruṣo bhūtvā kuntīmupajagāma ha' iti /
analyzed: smaryate ca ādityaḥ puruṣaḥ bhūtvā kuntīm upajagāma ha iti
translated: And it is remembered: 'Āditya, becoming a man, approached Kuntī' (Mbh. Sabhā 1.1.1).

analyzed: mṛd ādiṣu api cetanāḥ adhiṣṭhitāraḥ bhyupagamyante mṛd abravīt apaḥ bruvan ityādi darśanāt
translated: And in the case of clay, etc. also, conscious beings are accepted as presiding deities, because of such statements as 'Clay spoke, water spoke' (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.2.7).

analyzed: jyotiḥ ādeḥ tu bhūtadhātoḥ āditya ādiṣu acetana tvam abhyupagamyate
translated: But in the case of the elements beginning with light, it is admitted that the sun, etc. are non-sentient.

analyzed: cetanāḥ tu adhiṣṭhitāraḥ devatā ātmanaḥ mantra arthavāda ādi vyavahārāt iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the presiding deities are sentient, on the basis of the usage of mantras and arthavadas, etc.

analyzed: yat api uktam mantra arthavādayoḥ anyāya artha tvāt na devatā vigraha ādi prakāśana sāmarthyam iti
translated: It has also been said that since mantras and arthavadas have a different meaning, they do not have the power to reveal the form, etc. of deities.

original: atra brūmaḥ pratyayāpratyayau hi sadbhāvāsadbhāvayoḥ kāraṇaṃ /
analyzed: atra brūmaḥ pratyaya apratyayau hi sadbhāva asadbhāvayoḥ kāraṇam
translated: To this we say: The cause of existence and non-existence is the presence and absence of a means of knowledge,

analyzed: na anya artha tvam ananya artha tvam vā
translated: not having a different meaning or not having a different meaning.

original: tathāhyanyārthamapi prasthitaḥ pathi patitaṃ tṛṇaparṇādyastītyeva pratipadyate /
analyzed: tathā hi anya artham api prasthitaḥ pathi patitam tṛṇa parṇa ādi asti iti eva pratipadyate
translated: For thus, one who has set out with a different purpose understands that there is grass, leaves, etc. on the path where they have fallen.

analyzed: atra āha viṣamaḥ upanyāsaḥ
translated: Here he says: The example is inappropriate.

original: tatra hi tṛṇaparṇādiviṣayaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pravṛttamasti yena tadastitvaṃ pratipadyate /
analyzed: tatra hi tṛṇa parṇa ādi viṣayam pratyakṣam pravṛttam asti yena tad astitvam pratipadyate
translated: For there is a perception operating on the object of grass, leaves, etc., by which one understands their existence.

original: atra punarvidhyuddeśaikavākyabhāvena stutyarther'thavādena pārthagarthyena vṛttāntaviṣayā pravṛttiḥ śakyādhyavasātum /
analyzed: atra punar vidhi uddeśa eka vākya bhāvena stuti artha irthavādena pārthagarthyena vṛttānta viṣayā pravṛttiḥ śakyā adhyavasātum
translated: But here, the activity can be ascertained by the arthavada, which has the same purpose as the injunction, as having a different meaning and having as its object a story.

original: nahi 'na surāṃ pibet' iti nañvati vākye padatrayasaṃbandhātsurāpānapratiṣedha evaikor'tho 'vagamyate /
analyzed: nahi na surām pibet iti nañvati vākye pada traya saṃbandhāt surā pāna pratiṣedhaḥ eva ekaḥ ūrthaḥ vagamyate
translated: For in the sentence containing the negative particle, 'He shall not drink wine,' only one meaning is understood, the prohibition of drinking wine, because of the connection of the three words.

analyzed: na punar surām pibet iti pada dvaya saṃbandhāt surā pāna vidhiḥ api iti
translated: But it is not so that because of the connection of the two words 'He shall drink wine,' the injunction of drinking wine is also understood.

analyzed: atra ucyate viṣamaḥ upanyāsaḥ  yuktam yat surā pāna pratiṣedhe pada anvayasya eka tvāt avāntaravākya arthasya agrahaṇam
translated: To this it is said: The comparison is inappropriate.🔽It is proper that in the prohibition of drinking wine, the subordinate sentence meaning is not grasped because the syntactical connection is single.

original: vidhyuddeśārthavādayostvarthavādasthāni padāni pṛthaganvayavṛttāntaviṣayaṃ pratipadyānantaraṃ kaimarthyavaśena kāmaṃ vidheḥ stāvakatvaṃ pratipadyante
analyzed: vidhi uddeśa arthavādayoḥ tu arthavāda sthāni padāni pṛthak anvaya vṛttānta viṣayam pratipadya anantaram kaimarthya vaśena kāmam vidheḥ stāvaka tvam pratipadyante
translated: But in the case of the injunction and the explanatory passage, the words occurring in the explanatory passage are first understood to have a separate connection with the subject matter, and then, by the force of the purpose, they are rightly understood to be praise of the injunction.

original: yathāhi 'vāyavyaṃ śvetamālabheta bhūtikāmaḥ' ityatra vidhyuddeśavartināṃ vāyavyādipadānāṃ vidhinā saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi vāyavyam śvetam ālabheta bhūti kāmaḥ iti atra vidhi uddeśa vartinām vāyavya ādi padānām vidhinā saṃbandhaḥ
translated: For example, in the case of 'One desiring prosperity should sacrifice a white (animal) to Vayu,' the words 'to Vayu' etc. occurring in the injunction have a connection with the injunction.

original: naivaṃ 'vāyurvai kṣepiṣṭhā devatā vāyumeva svena bhāgadheyenopadhāvati sa evainaṃ bhūtiṃ gamayati' ityeṣāmarthavādagatānāṃ padānām /
analyzed: na evam vāyuḥ vai kṣepiṣṭhā devatā vāyum eva svena bhāgadheyena upadhāvati saḥ eva enam bhūtim gamayati iti eṣām arthavāda gatānām padānām
translated: But it is not so in the case of the words occurring in the explanatory passage, 'Vayu is indeed the swiftest deity. He approaches Vayu himself with his own share. He alone leads him to prosperity.'

original: nahi bhavati vāyurvā ālabheteti kṣepiṣṭhā devatā vā ālabhetetyādi /
analyzed: nahi bhavati vāyuḥ vai ālabheta iti kṣepiṣṭhāḥ devatāḥ vai ālabheta ityādi
translated: For we do not have such expressions as 'one should sacrifice to Vayu' or 'one should sacrifice to the swiftest deity'.

original: vāyusvabhāvasaṃkīrtanena tvavāntaramanvayaṃ pratipadyaivaṃ viśiṣṭadaivatyamidaṃ karmeti vidhiṃ stuvanti /
analyzed: vāyu svabhāva saṃkīrtanena tu avāntaram anvayam pratipadya evam viśiṣṭa daivatyam idam karma iti vidhim stuvanti
translated: But by mentioning the nature of Vayu, they praise the injunction that this rite is dedicated to such-and-such a deity, understanding the secondary meaning.

original: tadyatra so 'vāntaravākyārthaḥ pramāṇāntaragocaro bhavati tatra tadanuvādenarthavādaḥ pravartate /
analyzed: tat yatra saḥ vāntara vākya arthaḥ pramāṇa antara gocaraḥ bhavati tatra tad anuvādena artha vādaḥ pravartate
translated: Where the meaning of that secondary sentence is within the scope of another means of knowledge, there the explanatory passage proceeds by referring to that.

analyzed: yatra pramāṇa antara viruddhaḥ tatra guṇa vādena
translated: Where it is contradicted by another means of knowledge, there by a praise of the quality.

original: yatra tu tadubhayaṃ nāsti tatra kiṃ pramāṇāntarābhāvādguṇavādaḥ syādāhosvitpramāṇāntarāvirodhādvidyamānavāda iti pratītiśaraṇairvidyamānavāda
analyzed: yatra tu tat ubhayam na asti tatra kim pramāṇa antara abhāvāt guṇa vādaḥ syāt āhosvit pramāṇa antara avirodhāt vidyamāna vādaḥ iti pratīti śaraṇaiḥ vidyamāna vāda
translated: But where both are absent, whether it should be a praise of the quality due to the absence of another means of knowledge, or whether it should be a praise of the existent due to the non-contradiction of another means of knowledge - those who rely on perception should adopt the praise of the existent.

analyzed: āśrayaṇīyaḥ na guṇa vādaḥ
translated: The praise of the quality should not be adopted.

original: etena mantro vyākhyātaḥ /🔽apica vidhibhirevendrādidaivatyāni havīṃṣi codayadbhirapekṣitamindrādīnāṃ svarūpam /
analyzed: etena mantraḥ vyākhyātaḥ  apica vidhibhiḥ eva indra ādi daivatyāni havīṃṣi codayadbhiḥ apekṣitam indra ādīnām svarūpam
translated: By this, the mantra is explained.🔽Moreover, the oblations dedicated to Indra and others, which are enjoined by the injunctions, require the nature of Indra and others.

analyzed: nahi svarūpa rahitāḥ indra ādayaḥ cetasi āropayitum śakyante
translated: For Indra and others, who lack their own nature, cannot be imposed on the mind.

original: naca cetasyanārūḍhāyai tasyai tasyai devatāyai haviḥ pradātuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca cetasi an ārūḍhāyai tasyai tasyai devatāyai haviḥ pradātum śakyate
translated: And it is not possible to offer the oblation to this or that deity without having it present in the mind.

original: śrāvayati ca 'yasyai devatāyai havirgṛhītaṃ syāttāṃ dhyāyedvaṣaṭkariṣyan' ai /brā / / / iti /
analyzed: śrāvayati ca yasyai devatāyai haviḥ gṛhītam syāt tām dhyāyet vaṣaṭkariṣyan aibrā iti
translated: And it is declared: 'When he is about to utter the Vaṣaṭ, he should meditate on the deity to whom the oblation has been taken up' (Aitareya Brāhmaṇa).

analyzed: na ca śabda mātram artha svarūpam saṃbhavati
translated: And the mere word cannot be the form of the meaning.

analyzed: śabda arthayoḥ bhedāt
translated: Because the word and the meaning are different.

original: tatra yādṛśaṃ mantrārthavādayorindrādīnāṃ svarūpamavagataṃ na tattādṛśaṃ śabdapramāṇakena pratyākhyatuṃ yuktam /
analyzed: tatra yādṛśam mantra arthavādayoḥ indra ādīnām svarūpam avagatam na tat tādṛśam śabda pramāṇakena pratyākhyatum yuktam
translated: There, it is not proper to deny by means of the evidence of words that such is the nature of Indra and others as is understood from the Mantras and Arthavādas.

original: itihāsapurāṇamapi vyākhyātena mārgeṇa saṃbhavanmantrārthavādamūlatvātprabhavati devatāvigrahādi sādhayitim /
analyzed: itihāsa purāṇam api vyākhyātena mārgeṇa saṃbhavat mantra arthavāda mūla tvāt prabhavati devatā vigraha ādi sādhayitim
translated: The Itihāsa and Purāṇa also, by the explained method, being based on Mantras and Arthavādas, are able to establish the form of the deities and so on.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi mūlam api saṃbhavati
translated: It is also possible that they are based on perception and so on.

analyzed: bhavati hi asmākam apratyakṣam api cirantanānām pratyakṣam
translated: For, although it is not perceptible to us, it is perceptible to the ancients.

original: tathāca vyāsādayo devādibhiḥ pratyakṣaṃ vyavaharantīti smaryate /
analyzed: tathā ca vyāsa ādayaḥ deva ādibhiḥ pratyakṣam vyavaharanti iti smaryate
translated: And it is remembered that Vyāsa and others had direct dealings with the gods and others.

original: yastu brūyādidānīntanānāmiva pūrveṣāmapi nāsti devādibhirvyavahartuṃ sāmarthyamiti sa jagadvaicitryaṃ pratiṣedhet /
analyzed: yaḥ tu brūyāt idānīntanānām iva pūrveṣām api nā asti deva ādibhiḥ vyavahartum sāmarthyam iti sa jagat vaicitryam pratiṣedhet
translated: But if one should say that the ancients, like the moderns, had no power to converse with the gods, etc., he would deny the variety of the world.

original: idānīmiva ca nānyadapi sārvabhaumaḥ kṣatriyo 'stīti brūyāt /
analyzed: idānīm iva ca na anyat api sārvabhaumaḥ kṣatriyaḥ sti iti brūyāt
translated: And he would say that there was no universal monarch among the Kshatriyas in other times, as there is now.

analyzed: tatas ca rājasūya ādi codanā uparundhyāt
translated: And then he would obstruct the injunction of the Rajasuya and other sacrifices.

analyzed: idānīm iva ca kāla antare pi avyavasthita prāyān varṇa āśrama dharmān pratijānīta
translated: And he would admit that the duties of the castes and orders were for the most part unsettled in other times, as they are now.

analyzed: tatas ca vyavasthā vidhāyi śāstram anarthakam syāt
translated: And then the scriptures enjoining the settled order would be useless.

analyzed: tasmāt dharma utkarṣa vaśāt cirantanāḥ deva ādibhiḥ pratyakṣam vyavajahnuḥ iti śliṣyate
translated: Therefore it is reasonable to suppose that the ancients, by the power of their superior merit, actually conversed with the gods, etc.

analyzed: apica smaranti svādhyāyāt iṣṭa devatā saṃprayogaḥ ityādi
translated: Moreover, they remember: 'The union with the desired deity is through one's own study' (Yo. Sū. 1.28).

analyzed: apaśūdrā adhikaraṇam sū

analyzed: yathā manuṣya adhikāra niyamam apodya deva ādīnām api vidyāsu adhikāraḥ uktaḥ tathā eva dvijāti adhikāra niyama apavādena

analyzed: arthi tva sāmarthyayoḥ saṃbhavāt

analyzed: iti vat śūdraḥ vidyāyām anavakḷptaḥ iti ca niṣedha aśravaṇāt
translated: In the same way, there is no hearing of prohibition like The Śūdra is not entitled to knowledge.

analyzed: bhavati ca liṅgam śūdra adhikārasya upoddhalakam

original: saṃvargavidyāyāṃ hi jānaśrutiṃ pautrāyaṇaṃ śuśrūṣuṃ śūdraśabdena parāmṛśati 'aha hāretvā śūdra tavaiva saha gobhirastu' chāṃ / / iti /

analyzed: evam prāpte brūmaḥ na śūdrasya adhikāraḥ

analyzed: veda adhyayana abhāvāt

analyzed: na ca śūdrasya veda adhyayanam asti

analyzed: upanayana pūrvaka tvāt veda adhyayanasya

analyzed: upanayanasya ca varṇa traya viṣaya tvāt

analyzed: yat tu arthi tvam na tat asati sāmarthye dhikāra kāraṇam bhavati

analyzed: śāstrīya ṛthe śāstrīyasya sāmarthyasya apekṣita tvāt

analyzed: śāstrīyasya ca sāmarthyasya adhyayana nirākaraṇena nirākṛta tvāt

analyzed: nyāyasya sādhāraṇa tvāt

analyzed: na ca atra nyāyaḥ u sti

analyzed: tad viṣaya tvāt

analyzed: śakyate ca ayam śūdra śabdaḥ dhikṛta vaṣayaḥ yojayitum
